title: Easton EDC updates Town Council on foot traffic, Fire & Ice
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton EDC updates Town Council on foot traffic, Fire & Ice

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 504
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Economic Development Corporation Executive Director Holly DeKarske provided an update to the Easton Town Council Monday regarding downtown foot traffic.The corporation signed up for Placer.ai, a data tool which provides insight into foot traffic trends. Data was pulled specific to the Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival in February, as well as year-to-year trends from 2019 to 2024.
According to data provided to the council, North Washington Street saw around 9,200 visits for the two Fire & Ice Festival days this year.
That mark is down from around 11,300 in 2024, though this year's foot traffic was hampered by rain during the festival's second day. DeKarske said this year's foot traffic was "good" until the weather hiccup.
She added that moving forward, her office plans to keep streets open for Fire & Ice to avoid insurance and police costs that are "really hard to recoup."
"We're going to see if we can find a way to mitigate the foot traffic and spread things out in such a way so we wouldn't have to close the streets," DeKarske said.
As for year-to-year numbers, Placer.ai data shows North Washington Street saw around 1 million visitors in 2024. That's down 4.3% compared to 2023, but up 5.6% compared to 2021.
"I think that tool is wonderful," council President Frank Gunsallus told DeKarske. " … It was nice to see the positive growth over the last five years, so thank you for your efforts."
Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery wasn't satisfied with numbers on only foot traffic only.
"Foot traffic is interesting, but for economic development purposes, I think we really should be asking what the revenue generation is for our businesses," Montgomery said.
DeKarske said Easton Economic Development Corporation does that by speaking to businesses after events. Montgomery asked that the town aggregate sales numbers from businesses.
"That's really the only way we can judge whether this is benefitting our businesses or not," Montgomery said. "If you could find a way to do that, or I'd be happy to entertain a request to have a contractor that (businesses) would trust to collect data and aggregate it for us."
"Our job is to get foot traffic into town, and hopefully get the right kind of foot traffic that spends money," DeKarske responded. "It is not my job to get them in your store. That is the job of the business owners."
Montgomery said he'd like to bring the topic up during budget season. "I thought we were getting benefits for our businesses from EEDC," he said.
"Yes, bringing people to town to spend money," said DeKarske.
Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello asked DeKarske what businesses have shared regarding why retail and dining spending is slightly down. DeKarske said the cost of living and the recent presidential election year are two factors.
"People are just being cautious still," she said.
"We still have foot traffic coming into town, but people are dining out less," DeKarske added. "And we also need people who live here to support those businesses as well. And so that has been a little bit of an issue, too."

title: 71-year-old spends season in Glacier National Park
author: Tom McCall
content:
71-year-old spends season in Glacier National Park

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County resident Cheryl Krebeck spent a good chunk of her 72nd year in Montana's Glacier National Park. From April to October, she lived on the west side of the park in the northern Rockies.This curious woman loves to travel and is not letting a little arthritis get in the way.
"Traveling has been my passion, but when I turned 70, I decided I wanted this decade to be my most exciting," she said.
"I want to do more than just visit for a week or two," she said. "I really wanted to get to know this park. I went online, applied and got a job. I was hired to work in a hotel that was built in 1910 by the Great Northern railroad. I was a front desk person from 6 a.m. to 2 p.m."
When she was not making coffee and being a concierge for guests, she had regular challenges — like figuring what to do when a guest accidentally set off bear spray inside the hotel.
When she was not working, she got out into the park.
"Your best friends are the ones who have the same days off as you. You don't want to hike alone — there are a lot of grizzlies out there. That is what you are concerned with. Mountain lions could get you. I never saw one, but I had the feeling they were there," she said.
The more remote part of the park is the east side. When the snow subsides in mid June, the Sun Road opens and connects the two sides of the park.
"You see sharper peaks, more glaciers and more snow on top of the mountains. Most of my animal sightings were on the east side. Partly because there are less people," she said.
She hiked the Highline Trail up at Logan Pass. It reaches 6,600 feet.
"It was high for me. I saw a black bear on that hike. It was nice it was not a grizzly," she said.
Another aspect of the journey was that she was much older than most of her fellow workers. A lot of college students take a summer to do this.
"When I look back to being 19 years old, I don't think I had an appreciation for what 70 might have felt like. Some of the first hikes I went on were with young people. They were kind. It really added to it," she said.
Krebeck thinks her traveling has given her a big sky kind of attitude. She loves being outside and inhaling. She is thinking a trip to the Amazon is next.
"It is a big world out there, and I feel like I have a perspective because I have traveled. Sometimes you meet closed-minded people and can tell they haven't been anywhere. They haven't talked to anybody from anywhere else. There is a big old world out there, and it is worth checking out," she said.

title: Shark vs Seal: Scientists record one-of-a-kind deadly encounter
author: Staff Writer
content:
Shark vs Seal: Scientists record one-of-a-kind deadly encounter

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Seals and great white sharks have co-existed for over six million years and it is well-known they hunt seals.And now scientists are able to confirm they have been hunting them for millions of years.
A report was recently published in the journal Comptes Rendu Palevol by an international team that includes Calvert Marine Museum Curator of Paleontology Stephen J. Godfrey, Calvert Marine Museum Research Associate Paul R. Murdoch Jr. and St. Mary's College of Maryland's Victor J. Perez.
Until now, no great white shark tooth has ever been found embedded in a fossil seal bone, but the journal article reports on the discovery of the tip of a fossilized great white shark tooth embedded in a fossilized seal heel bone.
The unique two-for-one fossil was surface collected by Murdoch Jr. in Mosaic's South Fort Meade Mine in Florida. The seal bone originated from within the Bone Valley Member of the Peace River Formation of the Pliocene Epoch and is about 4.5 million years old.
The partial tooth is identified as having come from an Early Pliocene great white shark (Carcharodon carcharias). The discovery also represents the first great white shark tooth ever found embedded in any fossil bone, which may have come about as a result of active predation or scavenging.
The presence of the tooth in the seal's hind flipper suggests active pursuit and therefore active predation as opposed to scavenging.
Whatever the nature of the encounter, the seal did not survive given there is no evidence of healing on the fossilized seal bone.
To see the report, go to https://sciencepress.mnhn.fr/en/periodiques/comptes-rendus-palevol. For more information about the Calvert Marine Museum, go to www.calvertmarinemuseum.com.

title: Suicides are at record levels in the U.S.; Men, specifically white men, are driving the wave
author: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Suicides are at record levels in the U.S.; Men, specifically white men, are driving the wave

 August 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 941
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A record number of Americans killed themselves last year, according to new suicide numbers from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.Who is driving the contemporary surge in suicides?"Middle-age white males," said Dr.Caroline Fenkel, chief clinical officer and co-founder of Charlie Health Inc., a Bozeman, Montana-based mental and behavioral health provider specializing in virtual and outpatient care for kids, teens and young adults.Men made up 79.4% of the record 49,449 suicides committed nationally last year, according to the CDC. White men make up 30% of the U.S. population.They accounted for 60% (29,847) of the suicides last year, according to the CDC.Fenkel said men, especially white men, can feel the pressures of societal and throwback gender role expectations - and still not show stigmatized weaknesses of their mental health.Gender roles associated with career expectations in a market-based economy also play a role, Fenkel said, pointing to how society can look down at working class and lower-income men employed in some lower-paying service sector jobs."They are constantly told that they should be successful. That they should be making a lot of money. That they should be providing for or having a family," Fenkel said.Men tend to use guns to kill themselves compared to women who use other means such as attempting overdoses."Women are attempting suicides more often but don't succeed, while men tend to complete suicides at much higher frequency," said Dusti Linnell, an associate professor of practice with Oregon State University's College of Health. She helps lead the university's community mental and behavioral health efforts."The completions are associated with firearms," Linnell said.Guns were used in 54.6% of all U.S. suicides last year, according to the CDC data, outpacing other methods such as poisoning and overdoses (11.6%) and suffocations and self hangings (25.8%).Fenkel said men are more impulsive in their decisions to kill themselves - and are less likely than women to talk about their mental health challenges openly."They are really more likely to self-treat and to self medicate with alcohol," she said. "I think they are less likely to ask for help in general.I think asking for help as a male is seen as a weakness." UPSETTING UPSWINGSuicides have been on the rise in the U.S. since 2000. There were 29,350 suicides reported by U.S. health agencies in 2000. They have increased 68.4% since then and 4.1% since 2019 before all the stressors and shutdowns of the coronavirus pandemic.The 2022 increases include noticeable jumps from 2021 among those ages 45-64 (6.6%) and 65 and older (8.1%) as well as Asians (5.7%) and Hispanics (4.3%).Those all outpace the overall 2.6% jump in suicides from 2021 to 2022.Linnell said she's seen worrisome increases in suicides and suicide attempts by farmers and others working in rural and outdoor vocations as well as continued mental health stigmas and a pronounced counselor shortages making it difficult for those in need to find help.Farmers, farm workers and others working outside have to deal with extreme weather changes including warmer temperatures as well as pesticides and other chemicals.Linnell said lingering stigmas about talking about mental health and suicidal thoughts can be magnified along with social isolations in smaller towns and rural regions."One of the most difficult things to say to another person is that you are thinking of killing yourself or harming yourself," she said.Fenkel said the shortage of mental and behavioral health workers is so pronounced that as many 150 million Americans live in "mental health deserts" where access to services and treatment can be scarce.SOLUTIONS?So what can be done?The growth of telehealth services born out of and magnified after the pandemic has improved access to mental and behavioral resources and sparked the growth of groups such as Montana-based Charlie Health, which was established in 2020.That can allow more therapists and counselors to live and work in smaller towns and rural areas while also seeing patients in bigger cities.It also can offer some privacy for those with mental and behavioral health challenges they might not trust sharing with family or employers. "It can be embarrassing," Linnell said.She said Oregon State is part of efforts in the Pacific Northwest to implement and grow peer-based mental and behavioral health programs.Whether its middle-age or older men or teenagers, it can be easier to talk about sensitive topics such as suicide and self-harm with a friend than family members or employers.High schools and colleges are implementing peer-based mental health programs.Linnell said Oregon State is looking to grow peer-based "Mental Health First Aid" and QPR (Question, Persuade, Refer) programs.The former entails a six-hour training programs to help participants to build skills to help friends and others in need while the other has shorter 90-minute programs aimed suicide prevention.A key goal is for those considering or recovering from self-harm to believe they can get better."It's so important for people to know that recovery is possible," she said. 
 
 Caption: WIKIMEDIA COMMONS/CREATIVE COMMONS/LENART LIPOVŠEK LENART /UNSPLASH.COM
 
Men made up more than 79% of total suicides in the U.S. last year, according to provisional data from the U.S. Centers of Disease Control. White men, who make up 30% of the total population accounted for 60% of the 49,449 suicides nationally, the agency said.
 
AP PHOTO/MARK LENNIHAN, FILE
 
A sculpture called the "Vessel" at the Hudson Yards development in New York City saw a series of suicides after opening in 2019. The U.S. saw a record numbers of suicides last year, according to provisional data from the U.S Centers for Disease Control.
 
Those dealing with suicidal thoughts and mental health crises can call or text 988 for help and resources.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 11
author: Staff Writer

TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 11

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns

 On Sept. 11, 2001, nearly 3,000 people were killed as 19 al-Qaida hijackers seized control of four jetliners, sending two of the planes into New York's World Trade Center, one into the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia, and the fourth into a field in western Pennsylvania. It remains the deadliest terror attack in history.Also on this date:
In 1789, Alexander Hamilton was appointed the first U.S. Secretary of the Treasury.
In 1814, an American fleet scored a decisive victory over the British in the Battle of Lake Champlain in the War of 1812.
In 1936, Boulder Dam — later renamed the Hoover Dam — began operation as President Franklin D. Roosevelt pressed a button in Washington to signal the startup of the dam's first hydroelectric generator.
In 1941, groundbreaking took place for the Pentagon.
In 1954, the Miss America pageant made its network TV debut on ABC.
In 1973, Chilean President Salvador Allende died during a violent military coup led by General Augusto Pinochet.
In 1985, Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds broke Ty Cobb's MLB career hits record with his 4,192nd hit.
In 2008, presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama put aside politics as they visited ground zero together on the anniversary of 9/11 to honor its victims.
In 2012, a mob armed with guns and grenades launched a fiery nightlong attack on a U.S. diplomatic outpost and a CIA annex in Benghazi, Libya, killing U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans.
In 2023, over 4,000 people died and thousands more were missing after heavy rain from Storm Daniel caused two dams to collapse, flooding the city of Derna, Libya.

title: Ravens flock; Local kids honored at NFL game
author: Staff Writer
content:
Ravens flock; Local kids honored at NFL game

 November 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Kent Island High School Interact Club was honored by the Baltimore Ravens with the National Football League team's Honor Rows distinction for their commitment to community service and leadership development, Oct. 13. As part of this recognition, nearly 50 students from Kent Island High School had the incredible opportunity to attend the Ravens game against the Washington Commanders and be celebrated for their contributions."The Interact Club, led by [teacher Lacey] Phelps has been doing remarkable work to support leadership development," Principal Dan Harding said, "under the guidance of Katie McGrath and in partnership with the Giving the Edge Foundation, run by Bobby Woolley and Colleen Williams. This partnership and the outstanding leadership opportunities it has provided for our students were recently recognized in a big way."
Williams shared their organization, Giving The Edge Foundation, was the winning recipient of the "Honor Rows" Program with the Baltimore Ravens, a program salutes youth groups that provide outstanding service to their communities. Honorees are selected by a panel of youth service leaders with the assistance of the Baltimore Ravens, the Governor's Office on Service and Volunteerism and M&T Bank staff. This year, The Edge nominated the Interact Club and Leadership Cohort at Kent Island High School.
The Leadership Cohort started in the spring of 2021 at Kent Island High School by the Giving The Edge Foundation, led by McGrath. The Foundation seeks grants to help support the program and is fully-funded by the Foundation, explained Williams.
Leadership Cohort allows student leaders to understand their "WHY." Over the years the program has grown from a handful of students to over 40+ students who voluntarily meet before school to talk about who they are, what drives their passion, and they even take a personality test. Last year an Interact portion in partnership with the Rotary of Kent Island was launched to encompass a service above self-component. This school year the Interact Club has over 70 students ready to serve and give back to their community.
At the game, the students were welcomed at the Honor Row tent where everyone received a t-shirt and ticket to the game, including VIP access where they were escorted down on the field for pictures and a chance to meet players during warm-ups. While on the field Giving The Edge Foundation was awarded a Governor's Citation for the State of Maryland. The Honor Row was also recognized on the jumbotron during the second quarter.

title: Holiday gallery sale features local artists
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Holiday gallery sale features local artists

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Arts 
 
 800
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A new show is in the works following the astounding success of the November-December annual Holiday Show at the Chestertown RiverArts Gallery. This season, there were plenty of traditional paintings and art pieces but also intricate jewelry, festive holiday crafts and woodworking.Styles ranged from folk, traditional, abstract and whimsical. Patrons could browse or purchase a one-of-a-kind piece over the holidays.
The top sellers this year, RiverArts Board member Carol Droge said, were items like Moravian stars, created by Kris Kelley, the Arts Education Coordinator.
One of Kelley's favorite pieces to make, the stars are made with Tiffany-style stained glass. Each one, Kelley said, takes about an hour to create.
And they made beautiful Christmas decorations.
The stars were placed beside the homemade wreaths, another seasonal best seller.
Like the stars, the design for them is straightforward but elegant. The crafter, Amos Rudderow said they sell as well as anything he's ever done.
Finding everything he needs in his yard, it takes him about 20 minutes to make. The side pieces are hard wood; the uprights are birch branches. The rest is decorative placing using skill Rudderow has honed over the years.
They were a success with the public, selling 22.
Rudderow's wreath-making is closely related to his membership with the All Seasons Garden Club in Chestertown. Since he's retired he's been working with the club on projects, offering scholarships to the science students at the high school since 2013. The club is always looking for new members, meeting on the second Monday of each month during the periods Sept.-Dec. and Feb.-June at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.
For those who enjoy blending their art with their fashion, Ronn Akins' custom jewelry was on display.
Akins works with semi precious metals, silver and gold filled. The whole process requires finding the items, organizing them on a bead board, fusing glass, cutting and then placing the items in a kiln. His work yielded alluring results, selling 17 of them. A piece of his jewelry takes at least three hours to create. "It's a lot of dedication involved," he said, "but I enjoy it."
For traditional art lovers there was plenty to see and purchase as well. There were impressive flower paintings from Amanda King. She enjoys making floral pieces between her job as a nail technician at "P Nails." Her style is mixed media, using traditional paints as well as pressed flowers.
Her piece, "Olivia," was inspired by the daughter of the owner of the "China House." With all of her art, she thinks about a person she likes when she creates. Relatively new to the Chestertown art scene, she was welcomed by RiverArts with open arms in May. Two pieces she submitted for December, one a painting of poinsettias, and another of pressed black sunflowers were both sold.
King thanked the people who encouraged her to move forward with her art, recalling how nervous she was when she first submitted her works to RiverArts. "They automatically called me an artist," King said. "They were all so welcoming and friendly to me."
She offered encouragement to anyone who wants to pursue art. "I think everybody, if they have a positive attitude, can do this. Don't let shut doors be an obstacle."
Patrons at the gallery could go from King's tapestry of organization and colors to the surreal beauty of an abstract painting by Sheila Exum. Born in Chestertown, Exum's been involved in art since she was a child and has been painting for eight years now. Although many of her pieces are sold, including the latest one in Chestertown entitled, "Misty Copeland," a famous ballerina, she also sees art as a chance to give back to the community. King recently donated art to a ballet company in Wilmington and some sports pieces at a silent auction.
Of all the arts, she enjoys painting the most, and hopes to make it a career one day.
She's taking strides because on Feb. 9, her artwork will be displayed courtesy of the Good Aesthetic Gallery presenting the "TIDAL WAVE" group exhibition at the Rehoboth Art League.
King said her pieces are getting bigger and she is currently working on another painting of a ballerina, acknowledging she appreciates the grace in the postures.
The talent all these artists demonstrated this year was commended by those running the gallery.
Droge said, "Everyone has been extremely helpful and it's been a wonderful turnout."
Right now, the gallery walls are bare while they prepare for the next show on March 1, a new idea featuring clay works.
Executive Director, Chris Sade announced the show will be called "Grounded." The instructor for the Studio, Manager Kris Neiman, will head it up and will feature the works of local clay artists.
Participants will hear from these potters and a little about the process as well, adding a workshop element.
"The community will be amazed at what they can do," Sade said.

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
New training center will provide cross-training, easier commute for first responders

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 731
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — First responders are excited about the benefits a new Emergency Services Training Campus will bring to Talbot County.Construction of a 7,200-square-foot campus at 9095 Mistletoe Drive in Easton is nearing, according to Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief Sonny Jones. Once completed, the training campus will be run by the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
The department will coordinate training with the University of Maryland Fire and Rescue Institue, which provides training statewide for firefighters and EMS technicians, including advanced cardiac life support, medical training and emergency vehicle operation training.
Jones and Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, are looking forward to cross-training with public safety partners, including town and county police.
"They're great to work with, but it would be awesome to train with them before the emergency happens," Jones said. "I've always said, the first time I meet one of my public safety partners, I don't want it to be at the scene of an emergency. I want to interact with them beforehand so we have a smooth, unified response to an emergency."
"This will ultimately improve the way we are able to respond to our day-to-day emergencies and our large-scale emergencies because we'll be able to train with our partners," LeCates said.
A drive to Centreville, the location of the closest training facility of this type, is difficult for Talbot County firefighters who may live an hour or more away to schedule, Jones said. With a shorter commute, he expects them to take more training.
"Having this facility here, the University of Maryland and their adjunct instructors can host classes right at this facility," Jones said. "So that someone in Tilghman, instead of having to drive 60 miles, may only have to drive 20 or 25 miles."
At an Aug. 5 Easton Town Council meeting, Jones said the construction contract has been awarded to Willow Construction. The goal is to break ground this September or October on the classroom portion of the building. The fire chief hopes to see the entire project completed before the end of 2025.
"We have, what we feel is an attainable goal that probably … fall to winter of next year … you may see the majority if not all of this campus done," Jones said.
Ward 2 Easton Town Council Member and fire department volunteer Don Abbatiello emphasized that the project is "not being built with town money," but instead through fundraising. He commended the "hard work" from those involved in fundraising efforts.
The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, a nonprofit fundraising arm of the department, has around $2 million left to raise. President Brett Whitehead said all donations through the end of September are being matched by the A. James and Alice B. Clark Foundation.
A key feature of the facility will be a burn building, which Jones said will be made out of "steel with special materials inside that are heat- and flame-resistant" and allow for repeated burning that will help firefighters train in real-life scenarios.
Jones said he used to train in "acquired structures" that were a "one-time deal" for firefighter training, such as farm houses that were meant to be burned down. The burn building is designed for repeated training.
LeCates also said the larger training center will help his department experience "more real-world scenarios." "Now we can bring in wrecked cars … and put simulated patients in them or some of our rescue mannequins in there," he said.
LeCates added that prospective employees may take notice of the facility, a trend that the fire department hopes to see as well. While Jones said his priority is to "make it easier" on current volunteer firefighters, he acknowledges the high costs and packed work schedules that make it difficult for younger, prospective volunteers to commit to training at facilities in Centreville or Princess Anne.
"Now it's harder to get the younger generation," Jones said of the department's recruiting efforts. "We don't have as many that want to volunteer, and the ones we do are awesome, they're absolutely awesome. They come in, they take all the required training, and they're participating just as well as anybody else."
" … We just don't have as much of an infill of younger people as we used to have."
A previous version of this story incorrectly stated which entity is responsible for managing the training campus. The Easton Volunteer Fire Department will be responsible for the management and operation of the facility.

title: Maryland lab analyzes remains of African descent
author: CHRISTINA WALKER somdnewsintern@chespub.com
content:
Maryland lab analyzes remains of African descent

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRISTINA WALKER somdnewsintern@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The remains of at least 15 individuals of possibly African descent are housed in a Calvert laboratory. A statewide project launched last fall aims to reconnect these lost identities with the lineal descendants or communities that the remains are culturally affiliated with.Gov. Wes Moore (D) last fall announced the project, Engaging with Descendant African American Communities, highlighting the collaborative efforts of the Maryland Commission of African American History and Culture and the Maryland Historical Trust.
"The core of this project is love," Chanel C. Johnson, executive director of the Commission and the Banneker-Douglass Museum, said. "It's painting a human picture of individuals that are lost and I'm really honored to be able to be a part of such a big project, a meaningful project."
The Maryland Historical Trust said the project at the Maryland Archaeological Conservation Laboratory, which is located within Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum in St. Leonard, will use genealogical records, land record research and possibly DNA testing to determine how the remains can be appropriately returned to the ground. Work is being down in accordance with the Maryland's Regulations for the Transfer of Human Remains and Associated Funerary Objects.
"There's definitely going to be challenges and new discoveries and maybe some pain uncovered," Johnson said. "The end point is going to be really fantastic and have a real, generational impact."
Johnson said this project should take approximately three years and the museum is focused on heavily documenting the process and the results.
"Having a report documenting all of the research work is going to is paramount," Johnson said, "as well as doing some type of exhibition, maybe some illustrations or facial reconstruction, to really bring to life who these individuals were, what community life was like in the time that they were alive and to really build on the Maryland story."
The trust said most of the remains were recovered in the 1960s through the 1990s. Properties associated with these remains include sites near Deep Creek in Anne Arundel County, the Gott Cemetery in Calvert County, Chapel Point in Charles County, Bennetts Point in Queen Anne's County and Twin Oaks in Wicomico County.
"These individuals were precious. Their lives were precious. Their stories, as all of our stories do, deserve to be told," Johnson said. "We have that opportunity in 2024 with new technology, with a community and with institutions that are dedicated to make sure that these sacred stories are shared."
Elinor Thompson, co-chair of the Ancestral Remains Committee for the commission, said this will be an ongoing project, and the learning opportunities it may provide will last forever.
"As we go along, we're going to learn about the histories of the communities that connect to the Underground Railroad," Thompson said. "It's not going to stop."
The Maryland Historical Trust said the project aims to "actively engage with descendant communities in an ethical and inclusive manner" that results in "a plan for the respectful reburial of the remains that recognizes their cultural importance and historical legacy."
"To really understand American life and how it was shaped you have to have a knowledge and understanding of Black history," Johnson said. "Anytime that we have an opportunity to really amplify, uncover, document and share histories that have been lost … that's a sacred thing."

title: 4-H kids donate police vests to K-9's
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
4-H kids donate police vests to K-9's

 September 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Every first and third Wednesday, the Kent County Sheriff's Office K-9 unit, cooperating with law enforcement in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties, train their dogs.On Wednesday, Sept. 18, they trained at Geno's Automotive in Kent County. After that, the K-9 units were invited to the Kent County Middle School to receive something special.
In a gesture of police support, the Kent Puppy Pals 4-H Dog Club donated a Line of fire Defense Street Fighter vest to Addy, a German Shepherd, handled by Dfc. Craig Lewis of the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office.
Going through Kent County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Scott Lockerman's organization, the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, the Puppy Pals donated a check for $300 in June.
Club Leader of Puppy Pals Kim Montooth explained each year they do a service project. Last year, for instance, they raised money for the Humane Society. This year was exciting for the kids and something different, Montooth said.
Molly's Place also donated $1,000 in a vest for Waylon, a K-9 black lab handled by Pfc. Nick Lang of the Easton Police Department.
In front of about 20 people, the dogs modeled the vests, which are lightweight enough yet specially designed to protect their vital organs.
Then the Puppy Pals kids and their families gathered around to pet the dogs.
After the children met with the dogs and 4-H mom Karri Bryant had a playful tug of war with Addy, they were invited into the school where they witnessed a live demonstration of how Addy sniffs out controlled substances.
Controlled substances were stashed in two classrooms. Led by Lewis, sniffing desks and drawers, Addy alerted to the controlled substance in both rooms in about 30 seconds.
Trainer Mark Carr of Tidewater Strategic Services said the dog doesn't go right to the spot because of the nature of scent itself. The K-9 moves around the perimeter of the room, getting the entire scent. Once she gets a complete picture, she can hone in.
President of the club Trenton Montooth was impressed. At 14 years of age, he has decided he wants to be a K-9 officer.
Lockerman thanked the Puppy Pals and Molly's Place, expressing the importance of their giving by showing the positive impact K-9 dogs make.
"K-9's make the community safer with their presence. Crime rates go down. Schools are much safer. Even the town's property values go up," he said.

title: Powerful forces: 'Ahsoka' must save the universe in new Star Wars spinoff series
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Powerful forces: 'Ahsoka' must save the universe in new Star Wars spinoff series

 August 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fan-favorite former Jedi Knight finally gets her live-action, starring moment in the new Disney+ limited series, "Star Wars: Ahsoka," debuting Wednesday, Aug. 23, on the streamer. Starring Rosario Dawson ("Dopesick") in the title role, the eight-episode series follows Ahsoka Tano as she takes on the not-so-small task of protecting the galaxy from imminent threats.Former Jedi Padawan-turned-Rebel Alliance member Ahsoka is one of the most beloved characters in the Star Wars universe among fans of the franchise's animated films and TV series. Before Dawson's live-action portrayal of Ahsoka in the Disney+ series "The Mandalorian" and "The Book of Boba Fett," the character first appeared in the 2008 animated feature and subsequent TV series "Star Wars: The Clone Wars" as a teenage apprentice of Anakin Skywalker.The new series is set just after the events of the animated series "Rebels" and in the same timeline as "The Mandalorian." Hayden Christensen ("Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones," 2002) reprises his role as Anakin yet again in "Ahsoka," after appearing in 2019's "Star Wars: Episode IX - The Rise of Skywalker," and bringing the character back to life in the spinoff series "Obi-Wan Kenobi" - presumably as a Force ghost, as he is long dead in this timeline.So, who will the baddies in "Ahsoka" be without Darth Vader to represent the dark sideft Returning to portray Grand Admiral Thrawn is "The Witcher" star Lars Mikkelsen, who lent his voice to the chilling Imperial officer in "Rebels." Icy in demeanor and appearance - Thrawn is Chiss and his skin glows blue - he is only the tip of the villain iceberg in "Ahsoka." Portraying even more adversaries challenging the Jedi and the universe at large are Ivanna Sakhno ("High Fidelity") as Shin Hati, Diana Lee Inosanto ("The Last Tour," 2016) as Magistrate Morgan Elsbeth and the late Ray Stevenson ("Das Boot") as Baylan Skoll."Ahsoka" also stars Natasha Liu Bordizzo ("Day Shift," 2022) as Sabine Wren, Mary Elizabeth Winstead ("Kate," 2021) as Hera Syndulla, Eman Esfandi ("The Inspection," 2022) as Ezra Bridger and David Tennant ("Doctor Who") as the voice of droid Huyang, reprising his role from the Clone Wars series.Portraying a character that is as cherished as Ahsoka, and held in such high regard by one of film and TV's most active and vocal fan bases, is a daunting task. Dawson was up for the challenge, however, crediting stunt co-ordinator Ming Qiu ("Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.") with getting her into shape when it came to wielding a lightsaber like a Jedi, as she shared on the Dagobah Dispatch podcast in May: "When Qiu said, 'This one did not make my eyes hurt,' that was the first compliment that I got, and I think I cried."

 On Aug. 13, 1961, on what would become known as Barbed Wire Sunday, East Germany sealed the border between Berlin's eastern and western sectors before building a wall that would divide the city for the next 28 years.Also on this date:
In 1521, Spanish conqueror Hernando Cortez captured Tenochtitlan, present-day Mexico City, from the Aztecs.
In 1792, French revolutionaries arrested and imprisoned King Louis XVI; he would be executed by guillotine the following January.
In 1889, William Gray of Hartford, Connecticut, received a patent for the first coin-operated telephone.
In 1918, Opha May Johnson became the first woman to join the U.S. Marine Corps.
In 1952, Big Mama Thornton first recorded the song "Hound Dog," four years before Elvis Presley's famous version was released.
In 1969, New York City held a ticket-tape parade for Apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong, Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin and Michael Collins.
In 1995, Baseball Hall of Famer Mickey Mantle died at a Dallas hospital of rapidly spreading liver cancer at age 63.
In 2011, seven people were killed when a stage collapsed at the Indiana State Fair during a powerful storm just before a concert was to begin.
In 2020, in an interview on Fox Business Network, President Donald Trump acknowledged that he was starving the U.S. Postal Service of money in order to make it harder to process an expected surge of mail-in ballots.

title: No consensus on dealing with projected deficit
author: DAVID REEL
content:
No consensus on dealing with projected deficit

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last November, progressives in Maryland were thrilled when Democratic candidate Wes Moore was elected governor in a landslide after defeating nine much more well-known opponents in a Democratic primary. They were even more thrilled when progressive Democratic candidates were elected to replace moderate Democratic members and Republican members in the Maryland House of Delegates and the Maryland Senate.Those elections further solidified the Democratic veto- proof supermajorities in both houses of the General Assembly.
Going into the 2014 General Assembly session, progressives seemed to be large and in charge. They looked forward to further advancing their progressive public policy agenda.
As the 90-day session begins to wind down, that has not been the case, especially on tax and budget matters. It is increasingly clear the Democratic supermajorities are not monolithic, nor is the governor fully embracing an aggressive progressive tax and budget agenda.
This outcome was not expected when Gov. Moore presented his proposed state budget in mid-January. Then there was consensus that a balanced state budget would be easily approved before or by the end of the session as required by the Maryland Constitution.
Recently that consensus has been shaken to the core based on five consecutive revised State Board of Revenue Estimates projecting state budget deficits will be the largest since the "Great Recession" which began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009.
Next fiscal year, the deficit is projected to reach $1 billion. In fiscal year 2027, the last year of Gov. Moore's first term, it is projected to grow to $1.3 billion. A year later, it is projected to more than double to $3 billion and could be $4 billion the following fiscal year. These projections do not include the impact of funding to address a $3.1 billion deficit in the state Transportation Trust Fund and $8 billion to fully implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (The Kirwan Report).
As a result, there has been intense and even contentious debate in the Democratic supermajorities on what to do and when to do it. The answer depends on who you ask and where they sit.
The Democratic House majority leader, Democratic chair of the House Ways and Means Committee, and the Democratic chair of the House Appropriations Committee, are united in saying the General Assembly needs to raise taxes and needs to raise them now. The Democratic Senate president and Democratic chair of the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee are saying not so fast, we do not need to raise taxes in this session.
Gov. Moore agrees with the Senate leader's position, there is no need for tax increases for now. Asked if that position would hold beyond the current year, Moore has said, "I just know that the bar for raising taxes not just this year, but for every single year for me, it's going to be a very high bar."
His budget secretary has elaborated on Moore's overall strategy on budgets and taxes going forward by saying, "These revenue trends continue to underscore the necessity of taking bold steps to improve our economy, create jobs and bring new businesses and population to Maryland."
No doubt the Moore administration is aware of the results when Maryland Democratic General Assembly supermajorities approved a wide range of tax and fee increases proposed by progressive Democratic Gov. Martin O'Malley. With a "Change Maryland" message that resonated with Republican, Democratic and unaffiliated voters, Republican Larry Hogan won two terms as governor and now has an opportunity to be elected to the U.S. Senate.
As is almost always the case In Maryland, final decisions over increasing state spending and increasing state taxes and fees will come down to how much and when?
The larger question is how Democratic Party control of the state government will be impacted if the current divide between the shrinking moderate wing of the party and the growing progressive wing of the party on budget and tax matters is not resolved.
One unforeseen obstacle to resolving this divide are comments made recently by one high profile progressive Democratic county executive and agreed to by another.
Anne Arundel County Executive Steuart Pittman said the failure of long-standing progressive "tax reform" goals to gain support in the General Assembly is because "loopholes are everywhere for interests that lobby for loopholes. It's baked into the system. Legislators survive on a diet of campaign contributions to get into office and to stay there. The largest donors tend to be the very interests lobbying for loopholes and opposing a fair distribution of the tax burden."
Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich agreed with that observation.
Such remarks are not going to help advance progressive positions in the General Assembly even when their party has supermajorities.
Given all of the above, one can ask if the dynamics in the state legislature may be open to real change. What if Republican members who are accustomed to being largely irrelevant on budget and tax matters in Annapolis, forge a working relationship with moderate Democratic members on issues of common interest such as spending and taxes?
Likely? No. Probable? No. Possible? Maybe.
In politics anything is possible. Ask Larry Hogan and Wes Moore. I suspect both were told early on when they launched their gubernatorial campaigns that winning was not possible.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Around 28,000 chickens killed in Federalsburg fire
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Around 28,000 chickens killed in Federalsburg fire

 June 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — A chicken house fire in Federalsburg killed approximately 28,000 chickens Sunday morning.According to a release from the State Fire Marshal's office, the fire occurred just before 5:30 a.m. Sunday in a building owned by Possum Hill Farms on Possum Hill Road. No injuries were reported.
Federalsburg Volunteer Fire Company Chief Steve Cox said the fire was in the center of the building. Crews of firefighters worked from both ends to stop the blaze.
The State Fire Marshal's office said the fire took about an hour-and-a-half to control. It listed the cause as an electrical failure in the pump room. Cox said the damage was significant.
"None of that's saveable, they've got to destroy all that," Cox said. "They'll probably tear the chicken house down. So there's really not a save for anybody. We stopped it from going any further, but they can't save anything."
He added that other fire companies were a "big help" in containing the fire, including crews from Denton, Preston and Greenwood, Delaware.
"If I didn't have them, we'd have a worse situation," Cox said.
While the loss of chickens was extreme, State Fire Marshal Deputy Chief Caryn McMahon said the departments were able to prevent the fire from spreading and destroying the barns.
"The fire department controlled it pretty well," McMahon said. "Typically the poultry barns, once they ignite, it spreads pretty quickly because of the dust and materials inside of the barn."

title: Lions get close but can't dethrone Decatur
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions get close but can't dethrone Decatur

 May 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 923
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SALISBURY — Sure, Rich Ferro wanted to win.But with the postseason approaching, Stephen Decatur High's head baseball coach also wanted to use the Bayside Conference championship as a primer for his pitchers.
"The worst thing that we can do is bring in a guy that hasn't been in a situation that's a little bit tight," Ferro said. "I don't care if it's 50-0, you pitch in this environment here, you get a little nerved up. We need to do this so everybody feels that little pit in their stomach; so everybody understands this is real baseball. This is different from the regular season."
Queen Anne's County certainly tried to put a pit in the collective stomachs of the Seahawks Tuesday night at Arthur W. Perdue Stadium, when it trimmed an early four-run deficit to one in the top of the fifth inning. But Decatur answered with a two-out, four-run bottom of the fifth before relievers Ben Powers and Caleb Loring pitched back-to-back 1-2-3 innings to seal an 8-3 victory that gave the Seahawks their third conference championship in four years and second straight.
"It always seems when we play these guys, it's always one inning," Queen Anne's head coach Rick Sutch said. "And it's usually late in the game.
"You got to give them credit," Sutch continued. "They got a lot of two-out hits. It was 4-3 until, we weren't making the quality pitch when it was 0-2, 1-2. So it came back to bite us. But you got to tip your hat to them. They swung the bats when they needed to. And our guys, they hung in there when they needed to. It's always been one inning when it comes down to it."
Decatur (17-2) took a 1-0 lead in the bottom of the first. Queen Anne's starter Noah Palmer walked Brandon Nadeau and Landon Daniel before Johnny Hobgood hit a two-out single through the middle, scoring courtesy runner Owen Phillips.
The Seahawks expanded their lead in the second. Mason Edelman and Spencer Gaylor worked back-to-back walks before Kolten Zender beat out a bunt single to load the bases. Jackson Cheung bounced into a fielder's choice, plating Edelman. Gaylor scored when Nadeau grounded deep in the hole at short. One batter later, Nate Berzonski grounded out to short, scoring Cheung for a 4-0 lead.
Queen Anne's (10-7), which won seven of its final eight regular-season games to earn its first North Bayside title since 1980, didn't get a hit off Seahawks starter Berzonski, who struck out four and walked one over two scoreless innings. Raj Brachewski, the first of five Decatur relievers, set down the side in order in the third.
The Lions got on the board in the fourth. With one out, Jacob Clough lined a shot off the calf of Decatur's third pitcher, Justin Ujelick, who remained in the game. Palmer followed with a double to left that scored Clough, making it 4-1. Ujelick was relieved by Kyle Springle after walking Dulin Clark. Noah Cramer reached on a low throw to first, but Clark was tagged out in a rundown on the play.
Chase Hegedus then hit a 2-2 offering to right field. Courtesy runner Cole Coppage scored, shaving Decatur's lead to 4-2, but Cramer was thrown out at the plate.
"Chance had a good two-out hit and we got thrown out at the plate," Sutch said. "But we have to make that play there."
Nathan Procopio, who relieved Palmer with one out in the third, walked Cheung and yielded a single to Nadeau to open the fourth. But the right-hander retired the next three to keep the Lions within reach.
Queen Anne's crept within 4-3 in the fifth. Ethan Keppler walked. Springler retired Caleb Hutch and Procopio. Travis Sutch then launched a triple over Hobgood's head in center field, scoring Keppler. But the Lions couldn't get the tying run home, as Springler got a called strike three on Clough to end the inning.
Procopio got a pair of groundouts to third to start the bottom of the fifth. But Gaylor stung a double down the left-field line and scored on Zender's single to right. Cheung got plunked on the helmet by a pitch. Nadeau followed with a single to center that scored Zender for a 6-3 edge. Berzonski stroked a single to center, plating Cheung, and Landon Daniel singled to right, scoring courtesy runner Phillips for an 8-3 lead.
"It speaks about what they do and how they care about each other," Ferro said of Decatur's fifth-inning rally. "The success is really based on them wanting each other to be successful."
Powers and Loring took care of the Lions in the sixth and seventh, but like Ferro, Rick Sutch said the game should benefit his team heading into the playoffs.
"We play on Thursday, so we kind of attacked to where we'd have certain guys set up for Saturday and next Tuesday if we get that far," coach Sutch said of his pitching. "So we were kind of doing the same (as Decatur) but we also wanted to give it our best shot at this game without folding the towel early. I think both teams are well prepared to go into the playoffs now after this game."
Notes: Queen Anne's last appearance in the conference championship was 1980, when it earned a 3-1 victory over Stephen Decatur. ... Clough pitched a scoreless sixth inning for the Lions, striking out two and getting a pop out. ... The Lions are the No. 3 seed in the Class 2A East Region II bracket and will host sixth-seeded Wicomico on Thursday at 4 p.m. in a quarterfinal.

author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
301 haunt conjures more attractions

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — Back and more frightening than ever is 301 Devil's Playground, a haunted attraction running until Nov. 9, located at 13335 Alexander Road in Galena."Come visit the scariest Haunted Attractions on the Eastern Shore," their website states, and for good reason.
301 Devil's Playground is the brainchild of Peter Nau, and has been recognized as one of Frightfind's 2021 Top Haunted Houses.
This year, some favorites return. The journey into the House of Hell. Then a haunted 3-D clown experience. This is followed up by lots of chainsaw wielding maniacs, bumps in the dark, monsters waiting in the shadows and chilling twisted dark tunnels.
Also back, heckling crowds who are waiting in line is the character, Biting Bill. If you have thinner skin than Bill, you might want to plug your ears while waiting.

title: Defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne’s County among teams trying to fill graduation holes in an attempt for another deep playoff
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne’s County among teams trying to fill graduation holes in an attempt for another deep playoff

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 North Bayside boys soccer coaches have been busy this preseason — and during the early weeks of the regular season — mending holes in their lineups.Defending division champion Queen Anne's County High, which went 13-3-1 and reached the Class 2A state semifinals a year ago, graduated eight, including six starters.
"The guys that we lost were huge parts," Lions head coach Wade Hosler said.
North Caroline head coach John Austin can sympathize after graduating seven, including 2023 North Bayside Player of the Year Logan Harned.
"I feel as a conference we lost a lot of really good players," Austin said. "Last year's conference was very, very senior heavy."
A handful of those graduates are now playing in the collegiate ranks, with North Caroline's Harned at Neumann (Pa.) University and goalie Gavin O'Brien at Frostburg State, while Queen Anne's has Billy Schindler at Washington College.
The Class 1A ranks also felt graduation's sting. North Dorchester lost 10, while Cambridge-South Dorchester first-year head coach Josh Dohoney is trying to patch holes created by almost half of dozen losses.
In addition to the Vikings, Easton welcomes former standout Avery Brice as its new head coach, while Kent County begins the Dennis Hickman era.
Queen Anne's shared the conference title with James M. Bennett in 2021, but the last North team to win the Bayside championship outright was Kent Island in 2016, when the Bucs topped Stephen Decatur in penalty kicks. The Bucs and Lions look to be on another collision course to decide the North when they meet in Stevensville on Oct. 18, though North Caroline and Easton figure to also be atop the division ranks.
The South's dominance of the conference crown could be extended this year, as Bennett, which lost to eventual Class 3A state champion South River in last year's postseason, returns the bulk of its team from a season ago.
Here's a look at this year's North Bayside teams.
CAMBRIDGE-SD
Head Coach: Josh Dohoney.
Who's Where: Goalie: Nate Huber (Sr.); Backs: Osvaldo Hernandez (Jr.); Evan Kozak (Sr.); Colton Phillips (So.); Gibby Robinson (So.); Midfield: Lucas Harper (So.); Gavin Weber (So.); Ryan Harris (Sr.); Forwards: Will Banks (Jr.); Wyatt Abbott (So.); Marcos Hernandez (Fr.).
Outlook: After one year as an assistant, Dohoney begins his first head coaching job in soccer knowing he'll need to be patient.
"We're very young. Very much a rebuilding squad," said Dohoney, who played at Delmar, Del.
The Vikings graduated more than half a dozen from last year, including center midfielder Randall Johnson. The midfield looks technically sound, but with five sophomores and one freshman starting, Dohoney hopes this will be a season of growth.
COL. RICHARDSON
Head Coach: Dillon Shaheen.
Who's Where: Goalie: Cohen Carels (Sr.); Backs: Cameron Todd (Sr.); Jacklin Novembre (Jr.); Jackson Jean Jr. (Jr.); Caleb Rouser (So.); Midfield: John Beaven (So.); Jack Walls (Jr.); Preston Rickwood (Sr.); Ludver Vasquez (Jr.); Aydan Downie (Sr.); Forwards: Morgan Demir (Sr.); Angel Castro-Rios (Sr.); Skyler Endzel (Fr.); Brody Omohundro (Fr.).
Outlook: Shaheen begins his third year as head coach with his most experienced team he's had. That has translated into victories over Pocomoke and North Dorchester for starters.
"It's been pretty good so far," said Shaheen, who lost three seniors from last year. "Obviously we have a lot of seniors and juniors, and most have been playing at the varsity level for three or four years. I'm pretty confident in our squad this year."
EASTON
Head Coach: Avery Brice.
Who's Where: Goalie: Sam Hutchison (Jr.); Backs: Mario Medina (Sr.); Felix Valentine (Jr.); Brody Byrnes (Sr.); Kai Ferraris (Jr.); Landon Chaney (Sr.); Midfield: Clay Nagle (Sr.); Luke Stanco (Jr.); CJ Chaconas (Sr.); Blake Royer (So.); Ale Monroy (So.); Dominic Stanco (Sr.); Otto Perez-Arreaga (Fr.); Logan Sundt (Jr.); Liam Edgell (Sr.); Forwards: Kyle Ensminger (Jr.); Rodi Fresco Rubio (Jr.).
Outlook: Brice was a center midfielder on Easton's last two teams to win Bayside titles (2013, '14) and helped the Warriors reach the 2A state final in '14 before continuing his playing career at Wesley (Del.) College.
Now, he steps into his first head coaching job.
"Things are shaping up nicely," Brice said. "Could things be better? Yes. That's kind of one thing that we just hope to do every day in the season; just be better than the day before."
While the Warriors have been receptive to their new coach's ideas and style, Brice stressed they must strive for consistency.
"The mindset is you can be really good, but every game you've got to bring it," Brice said.
KENT COUNTY
Head Coach: Dennis Hickman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Leyder Cruz (Sr.); Backs: Noah Iacona (Jr.); Jayden Miller (So.); Stewart Hickman (Jr.); Bryce Jacobs (So.); Midfield: Nick Stead (Sr.); Colbyn Lopez (Jr.); Ethan Clark (Sr.); Forwards: Gabe Parr (So.); Dylan Peralta (Fr.); Sebastian Cousineau (So.).
Outlook: A 1993 graduate of Kent County, Hickman, who played soccer, baseball and wrestled for the Trojans, takes over as head coach after spending the last two years as an assistant.
In an attempt to build a program, Hickman has already achieved one goal in fielding a junior varsity for the first time since 2019.
"We think by having a jayvee, getting them out there on practice, getting them those reps and having some game-time situations and play, that we're only going to be able to build on that moving forward," Hickman said. "It's just the best thing for the program."
That coupled with a varsity roster that includes nine juniors and nine sophomores, could bode well for the future.
As for this year's team, there isn't a lot of experience, though Stewart Hickman has plenty of travel ball experience, as has recruited players over the summer to come out for the team.
KENT ISLAND
Head Coach: Lin Outten.
Who's Where: Goalie: Quinn Burns (Fr.); Backs: Davis Miller (Sr.); Noah Scopp (Sr.); Gavin Neboshynsky (Sr.); Mark Rees (Sr.); Spencer Chappell (Jr.); Elijah James (So.); Midfield: Simon Vujinovic (Sr.); Brendan Thomas (Jr.); Cooper Liebel (So.); Landon Pecor (Jr.); Forwards: AJ Miller (Jr.); Eric Hoffman (Sr.); Ethan Schriver (Sr.); Robert Simkins (Jr.).
Outlook: The Bucs have a lot of experience moving from the midfield into the attack, but are not as experienced in the back. Though seniors Davis Miller, Scopp and Rees return, Outten hopes shifting Neboshynsky and Chappell from midfield to the back bolsters his defense.
AJ Miller netted 10 goals a year ago, and Outten thinks that number will go up, especially with the return of Hoffman, who missed the bulk of last year with an early season injury.
"But really what makes the engine go is the three guys in the middle — Thomas, Vujinovic and Liebel," Outten said.
NORTH CAROLINE

Outlook: The Bulldogs graduated seven from a year ago, including Harned, O'Brien, and also lost leading scorer Kevin Godinez.
Austin thinks his team will be more defensive-minded this season. The defense is led by Shilling, who Austin thinks has college potential. Shilling and company figure to be tested early, as the Bulldogs open with defending conference champion James M. Bennett, Class 2A state semifinalist Queen Anne's, and perennial conference heavyweight Stephen Decatur.
"We have a lot of holes to fill," Austin said. "I think we are where we need to be right now. But the goal is can we just keep getting better as the year goes on, and then when October rolls around, play our best soccer?"
NORTH DORCHESTER
Head Coach: Gabe Guzman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Jayden Coleman (Jr.); Backs: Chris Sanchez (Jr.); Tahjere Pritchett (Jr.); Alex Fonseca-Gonzalez (So.); Martin Chirino Fernandez (Jr.); Midfield: Christian Chase (Jr.); Peyton Bleyer (So.); Daniel Mejia (Sr.); Kegan Henry (Jr.); Forwards: Volcy Nerat (Fr.); Dagoberto Chirino Fernandez.
Outlook: The Eagles graduated 10, including seven starters. Among Guzman's top priorities is getting his freshman to buy into his system and get acclimated to the high school varsity format.
"We're working on trust," Guzman said.
QUEEN ANNE'S
Head Coach: Wade Hosler.
Who's Where: Goalie: Ethan Keppler (Sr.); Backs: Christian Coppage (Sr.); Conner Cheezum (Sr.); Hayden Albright (Sr.); Brody Nordvik (Jr.); Midfield: James Rath (Jr.); Gage Jordan (Sr.); Nathan Kostka (Jr.); Mason Albright (Sr.); Boden Blodgett (So.); Josiah Hegarty (So.); Forwards: Ryan Lee (Sr.).
Outlook: "The preseason seemed awfully short this year, and our chemistry wasn't quite where I'd like it this time of year," Hosler said. "But I think it's coming, so I'm optimistic that we can do good things. We've had good moments and we've had mistakes. But I like the direction we're heading in."
Hosler has also liked his team's 3-0-1 start, which included Monday's 3-0 shutout of North Caroline.
Despite its big graduation losses, the Lions do have a solid core of returners. Outside backs Coppage and Cheezum return along with Keppler in goal. Jordan is back in the midfield while Lee returns at striker.
"We have some big pieces, but we still have some big holes to fill," said Hosler, who graduation losses included Schindler, center back William Nagle and leading scorer Nick Esper. "If we can have some guys step up I think we'll be OK."

title: Maryland fisher earns angler honors
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland fisher earns angler honors

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eric Packard of Calvert County has earned a Master Angler Milestone Award under the Maryland Department of Natural Resources' FishMaryland program. The award recognizes recreational anglers who catch 10 trophy-sized fish of different species in Maryland. Packard is the 11th master angler since the program began in 2019.In addition to being an extremely avid angler — fishing an average of 240 days per year — Packard serves as a commissioner on the Maryland Sports Fisheries Advisory Commission, representing the tidal and non-tidal recreational anglers in southern Maryland, according to a DNR release.
"A cast not taken is a fish not caught," Packard said. "So get out and take that cast, you can't catch a Maryland citation-sized fish if you don't. It all starts with a simple cast."
The FishMaryland program includes dozens of species from both salt and freshwater. Packard submitted entries for all 10 catches and received individual certificates for each catch. The department will present the Master Angler Milestone Award certificate and a gift card prize to Bass Pro Shops at its store in Hanover. Packard caught his 10th FishMaryland eligible fish, a spotted seatrout, on July 2, off of Point Lookout.
Packard's qualifying catches, in order, were:
Chain pickerel — 26 inches
Largemouth bass — 22.25 inches
Chesapeake Channa (northern snakehead) — 30 inches
Red drum — 45 inches
Crappie — 15 inches
Spanish mackerel — 22 inches
Hickory shad — 18 inches
Carp — 31 inches
Striped bass — 43 inches
Spotted seatrout — 24 inches
Packard fishes frequently in southern Maryland and in other parts of the state in fresh, brackish and salt waters. He fishes mainly by kayak and shore but also fishes on power boats with his extensive network of fishing friends.
He is a contributing writer to FishTalk Magazine, providing content about kayak fishing, shoreline fishing and weekly reports on fishing around the Chesapeake Bay region, fresh and saltwater.
During the rare times when Packard is not fishing, he paints as a self-taught artist working in oil paintings, ink or pencil drawings and pastels. Packard worked in IT for the national office of the United Association of Plumbers and Pipe Fitters before retiring.
Packard has fished since youth and recalls his first time fishing alone in Kansas, where his father was stationed with the Army.
"One day my mom said I could fish a nearby pond," Packard said. "I remember finding a topwater bait hanging in a bush. I tied it onto my Zebco 77, took a cast, and a largemouth bass blew up on the bait. I believe I ran straight home to show my mom the fish. That fish was hooked, and so was I."
FishMaryland is Maryland's recreational fishing award program and is a fun way to explore year-round recreational fishing and enjoy affordable, accessible, diverse, and high-quality fishing opportunities. More information on the Master Angler Milestone Award and the FishMaryland program is available on the program's website at dnr.maryland.gov/fisheries.

title: Nause-Waiwash aim to preserve, uncover history of Native Americans from Dorchester County
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Nause-Waiwash aim to preserve, uncover history of Native Americans from Dorchester County

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Since 1989, the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians have preserved, honored and passed down the stories of their ancestors, many of whom were Nanticoke people living along the Choptank River.Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott is the band's leader. The group preserves the tradition of the indigenous people who fled in the 1700s to the marshes after being converged on by foreign settlers.
Abbott's passion for exploring the county's native history began when she enrolled in the Nause-Waiwash around 20 years ago, though she wasn't always dead set on joining.
"There were probably two, three, maybe four generations that were brought up believing that it was disgraceful to claim your heritage, so they didn't teach it to their children," Abbott said. "And my grandmother was one of those."
Abbott's cousins convinced her to enroll around 10 years before she became the band's second chief in 2014, following the death of former Chief Sewell Winterhawk Fitzhugh.
"They brought up a very good point, and that was, 'If you don't (join), how are we going to preserve the history?'" Abbott recalled her cousins telling her. "'Because it's fading, it's dying quickly. And what are you going to tell your grandchildren?'"
The Nause-Waiwash is made up of around 300 descendants of not just the Nanticoke, but Choptank and Pocomoke people as well. Nause was a Nanticoke village outside of Vienna and Waiwash a Choptank village outside of Cambridge, Abbott said.
It's a "matrilineal society," one where the women hold the power to elect a chief and make important decisions. At meetings, the nonprofit organization plans upcoming events and collaborations with other tribes in the state, along with discussing heritage and history.
Two churches — Hughes African Methodist Episcopal Chapel near Cambridge and Wesley Chapel south of Cambridge in Andrews — are being renovated so the Nause-Waiwash can provide services and have a resource center. The organization is hosting its 32nd annual Native American Festival on Sept. 14 in Vienna.
Such outreach events are meant to educate people on the history of who occupied Dorchester land, but also how Native Americans treated the land and surrounding waters.
UNCOVERING HISTORYDespite living on the Western Shore, Erin Kennedy, a member of the Nause-Waiwash, often combs through records and land deeds in and around Taylor's Island, the community in which she grew up, hoping to piece together her mother's side of the family.
She took inspiration from her uncle, who created a family tree for her father's side of the family.
Online resources, records from the Maryland State Archives and discussions with fellow indigenous descendants on the Eastern Shore have helped Kennedy and other members of the Nause-Waiwash understand their line of ancestors.
Abbott emphasized that she's learning every day as well. She's uncertain if permanent state recognition is in the Nause-Waiwash's future given that it's not quite as large as other tribes. However, recent recognitions such as a historical roadside marker next to the Choptank River have raised the prominence of the dedicated nonprofit's work.
Nearly 10 years in, Abbott is developing a love and commitment to the work of the Nause-Waiwash.
"I have this passion for it, which I never really knew I had until I became involved," Abbott said. "And I do know that a lot of our history is gone. I want to read all these books and see if I can't find some new information out that I don't know. So I'm reading books that I'd never thought I'd ever read before."

title: Country Cooking: Christmas cookie making fun
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Christmas cookie making fun

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Stepping back in time reveals a lot of memories for me. Holiday baking was extra special, as my mother, my sister and I each liked to bake different desserts.Mom loved making pies, cakes, puddings and custards. My sister liked making candies of all kinds "and especially fudge."
I was the cookie maker. They would not have hit Betty Crocker's list, but my late brother-in-law, Sonny, loved them. He ate them perfectly baked, burned or mushy. He also said they were the best.
Brother Ollie said even the chickens wouldn't eat them when he threw them into the poultry yard.
I have improved through the years, and now each holiday I have a grandson, Colin, who joins me in the love of cookie baking. As a matter of fact, we do our first batch on Thanksgiving evening.
It is so much fun baking with the children, watching them be so excited to do this "on their own."
I am going to begin this cookie column today with my mom's favorite cookie.
GINGERSNAPS1 1/2 sticks unsalted butter, 1 1/4 cup granulated sugar, 1/4 cup lightly packed brown sugar, 1/3 cup molasses (not black), one egg, 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tsps baking soda, 1/2 tsp ground ginger, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground cloves, 2 1/4 cups all purpose flour.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line baking sheets with parchment paper. In a large bowl using an electric mixer, beat butter, 3/4 cup granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy, about two minutes. I use the paddles on the mixer for this. Add molasses and egg and beat again until well combined. Add in salt, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, cloves and flour and beat until well combined. In a shallow dish add 1/2 cup granulated sugar. Scoop the dough into 1 1/2 tablespoons balls, roll into the sugar in the dish and place on the baking sheet, leaving plenty of room for cookies to spread. Bake for 15 minutes or until cookies have spread and the surface looks cracked. Let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheets before moving to wire racks. Store cookies in an airtight container. This recipe makes 28 cookies. I use Brer Rabbit or the Grandma's brand of molasses. Enjoy.
CHRISTMAS SWEET AND SALTY TOFFEE35 saltine crackers, 1 cup butter, 1 cup packed brown sugar, 1 3/4 cups semisweet chocolate chips, 1 bag red and green holiday M&Ms, 1 jar holiday sprinkles.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line a baking sheet or jelly-roll pan with tin foil and coat with cooking spray. Line the baking sheet with Saltine crackers. Set aside. In a medium-sized saucepan, melt butter and brown sugar. Bring to a boil, stirring continuously, and let cook until bubbling, about 2 minutes. Pour mixture over crackers in an even layer and bake for 12 to 15 minutes. Top immediately with chocolate chips and let melt. Smooth chocolate out into an even layer, then top with red and green M&Ms and holiday sprinkles. Cut into squares, then cool until the chocolate has hardened.
CHOCOLATE CRINKLE COOKIES1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour, 3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp baking powder, 3/4 tsp baking soda, 1/2 cup butter (melted), 3/4 cup granulated sugar, 1/2 cup packed brown sugar, 3 large eggs, powdered sugar for rolling.
In a large bowl, combine flour, cocoa powder, salt, baking powder and baking soda. In a medium bowl, whisk together melted butter, sugars and eggs until well combined. Pour into dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Cover bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for two hours. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees and line two large baking sheets with parchment. Place powdered sugar in a small bowl. Scoop about 2 tablespoons of dough and roll into a ball. If dough is too sticky, wet your hands slightly to help roll dough. Roll dough into powdered sugar, coating well and then place on a prepared baking sheet two inches apart. After rolling all the dough in powdered sugar, roll each piece again in powdered sugar. This will help get a more dramatic crinkle when the cookies bake. Bake cookies until cookies puff and crack, about 14 minutes. The edges will just be set, but the cracks will still look slightly underdone. Let cool on a baking sheet.
CANDY CANE SNOWBALLS2 cups butter (softened), 1 cup confectioners' sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 3 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup chopped pecans, 8 ounces white candy coating (melted), 1/3 to 1/2 cup crushed peppermint candies.
Cream butter and confectioners' sugar until light and fluffy, 5-7 minutes. Beat in vanilla. Gradually beat in flour. Stir in pecans. Refrigerate, covered, until firm enough to shape, 3-4 hours. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Shape dough into one-inch balls. Place two inches apart on ungreased baking sheets. Bake until lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Remove from pans to wire racks; cool completely. Dip tops of cookies into candy coating, allowing excess to drip off; dip into crushed candies. Let stand until set.
OLD FASHIONED CHOCOLATE COOKIES1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/3 cup shortening, 1/3 cup butter (softened), 1/2 cup granulated sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1 egg (beaten), 1 tsp vanilla, 1 6-ounce package semi-sweet chocolate chips, 1/2 cup chopped nuts (optional).
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. In a medium bowl, sift together flour, salt and baking soda. Set aside, In a large bowl, cream together shortening, butter, sugars, egg and vanilla. Gradually combine half of the flour mixture into the wet mixture. Use a rubber spatula to incorporate the other half of the flour mixture if the dough gets too thick for the mixer. Stir in the chocolate chips. Roll the dough into tablespoon-sized balls. Place on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, two inches apart. Bake for 7-10 minutes. Remove from the oven when cookies are slightly golden around the edges and soft on the tops. Leave cookies on the pan for 2-3 minutes to continue cooking outside of the oven. Let cool until firm to touch. Serve immediately or store leftovers in an air-tight container.
ITALIAN THUMBPRINT COOKIES2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup salted butter (firm but not cold), 2/3 cup granulated sugar, 1 1/2 tsp vanilla extract (could be substituted), 2 large eggs (yolks and whites divided), 1 cup unsalted pistachios (finely chopped), 1/2 cup strawberry preserves, 4 ounces white chocolate or semi-sweet chocolate (melted).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In the bowl of an electric stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment and set on medium-high speed, whip together butter, granulated sugar and vanilla bean seeds until mixture is pale and fluffy, about 4 minutes. Blend in egg yolks (setting egg whites aside in a small bowl). With the mixer set on low speed, slowly pour in flour and mix until combined (mixture will seem dry at first but will start to come together). Form dough into a ball, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes. Whisk egg whites with 2 teaspoons water until frothy. Place chopped pistachios in a small bowl. Remove cookie dough from refrigerator and scoop dough up 1 tablespoon at a time and shape into balls. Drop each ball into egg white mixture and toss to evenly coat, then immediately transfer to bowl with chopped pistachios and roll to evenly coat sides and bottom with pistachios (I just left a circle on top uncoated for indenting). Transfer cookie dough balls to Silpat or parchment paper lined baking sheets (fitting 15 per sheet). Using your thumb, make an indentation in the center of each cookie and fill each indentation with a heaping 1/2 tsp of jam. Bake in a preheated oven 14-16 minutes. Allow to rest on a baking dish several minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool. Cool cookies then fill a piping bag or small Ziploc bag with melted chocolate and cut a small tip off the corner and drizzle with melted chocolate. Store cookies in an airtight container.
