title: League of Women Voters holds training for election info website
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
League of Women Voters holds training for election info website

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A group of women came together to get trained on how to run a spin-free election information portal called Vote 411. They came with laptops from as far as Frederick and St. Mary's counties to be ready for this year's primary election on May 14.This exacting and meticulous training is what the nonprofit the League of Women Voters is all about. They hold the power to vote as sacred and nonpartisan information about that vote to be integral.
"The goal is to provide training for the people that are going to be doing the voters guide and inputting information in the Vote 411 website," said the president of the Queen Anne's County League of Women Voters, Elizabeth Hammond.
"This is it for in-person training. There will be an online training on Saturday, Jan. 20. I think it is a good idea to do both of them," Hammond said.
She said the organization gets donations to do this work and create the voters guide both online and in print.
"We insert it in the Record Observer and then order about 500 extra copies and distribute them to towns and post offices and various other public places to pick up and get information to make intelligent decisions about what they want to vote for," Hammond said.
She is clear about the big picture of voting rights.
"Voting is one of the freedoms that we absolutely cherish. You want to be able to make a responsible decision and vote for the candidate that you think can do the best job. That is what we try to do with the voter's guide — to give the voters the best information possible in a nonpartisan way," Hammond said.
She said this primary election will be smaller than the general election, which will have a more involved voter's guide.
The state Board of Elections is the ultimate authority for the League of Women Voters.
"It amazing what the state Board does. What the election boards do is amazing, and they really deserve all the support we can give them and their thanks. That's why you watch the candidate listings on the state board, because that is what is going to show up, and then the proof comes when they send out the individual ballots for each county. The hard thing is you have to look through each one of those ballots. It is like 200 pages long," said Jeanne Halpin of the League of Women Voters of Maryland.
She led the training that took place at the Queen Anne's County Public Library in Centreville.
She tried to be less daunting to all the volunteers that showed up across the state.
"This is just a great learning opportunity. Don't get stressed, don't go crazy. The political parties are nominating candidates. They are asking people to run. In both the primary and the general," Halpin said.

title: Easton Town Council OKs Delmarva Pride Festival permit
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton Town Council OKs Delmarva Pride Festival permit

 December 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A permit for the 2025 Delmarva Pride Festival was unanimously approved by the Easton Town Council on Monday evening, a stark change from the council's split decision concerning the 2024 festival permit.Next year's festival, the town's fourth annual, is slated for June 14, 2025. Its expected attendance is around 4,000, according to the permit application. The Easton Police Department recommended approval.
The festival is organized by the Delmarva Pride Center and features vendors, businesses and food, with attendees lining South Harrison Street for the celebration of the LGBTQ+ community.
Council President Frank Gunsallus and Councilmembers Maureen Curry, Don Abatiello and the Rev. Elmer Davis all voted for the permit's approval. Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery was absent from Monday's meeting.
In January, Gunsallus and Montgomery voted against approving the public assembly permit for 2024's event. At the time, Montgomery brought up concerns of "overtly sexualized performances and behavior" from dancers at the festival.
At the January meeting, festival organizers maintained that the dancers were professionals and not "scantily clothed." The 2024 permit was narrowly approved 3-2, with Curry, Abbatiello and Davis in favor.
Montgomery told the Star Democrat on Tuesday that if he was present at the most recent council meeting, he would have once again voted against approving the permit.
Earlier this year, Gunsallus was heavily scrutinized by town residents for questioning whether the town should use funds to hang Pride banners and for stating the Pride flag is "antithetical to America."
But on Monday, Gunsallus initiated the motion to approve the festival permit for 2025, which this time was passed with no back-and-forth council discussion.
Tina Jones, co-founder of the Delmarva Pride Center, thanked the council for its unanimous vote during public comment Monday evening.
"I know in the past we've had some difficult conversations in this room," Jones said. "I'm glad to see that we have moved beyond those. And we look very much in favor of continuing to work very closely with this town.
"Personally for me, it's a great sign for all of our community that this has happened tonight. As Rev. Davis said at the beginning, this is a community that's made better by everybody that's here, and your vote tonight showed that."

title: Easton forfeits boys' game to Cambridge-SD
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Easton forfeits boys' game to Cambridge-SD

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 Easton High's boys' basketball team has forfeited its game Thursday at Cambridge-South Dorchester.Thursday's girls' game between the two schools will be played as scheduled at Easton High at 4 p.m., but spectators will not be allowed to attend.
The decision to forfeit the boys' game and play the girls' game without spectators is largely connected to the Oct. 27 football game between the two schools at Easton High that was stopped with just under 7 minutes remaining in the third quarter because of altercations away from the playing field.
At that game, the Easton and Cambridge-SD coaching staffs led their teams off the field while fans were instructed to leave the stadium by school administrators and local law enforcement officers. Three teenagers were arrested following the altercations.
The pattern that is emerging — basketball games scheduled between the two schools at Easton High this season will be played without fans; basketball games slated for Cambridge-SD will be forfeited by Easton High. The issue came down to playing the game with limited spectators. Easton wanted to limit or play without spectators. Cambridge-SD wanted spectators allowed.
This past Sunday, Easton High announced on its Instagram page, "Due to events that occurred during the EHS vs. CSD football game in the Fall, we have decided not to allow spectators at our upcoming girls and boys basketball game against CSD at Easton High School. As always, safety is a top priority. We apologize for any inconvenience and thank you for your support and understanding."
On Tuesday, the administrative offices of Cambridge-South Dorchester posted a statement on its Facebook page announcing Easton's decision to forfeit Thursday's boys' game at Cambridge-SD, and the Feb. 15 girls' game slated at Cambridge-SD.
"It is with great disappointment that we must convey this news: Easton High School has decided to forfeit the upcoming girls' and boys' basketball games scheduled to be held at Cambridge South Dorchester High School on Jan. 11 and Feb. 15," the statement said. "This decision was made by Easton High School and was not influenced by Cambridge-South Dorchester High in any way."
The post went on to say, "As a result of Easton High School's prearranged decision to forfeit these games, Cambridge South Dorchester High School will be credited with the wins for both of the boys' and girls' teams. We regret that parents, spectators and community members will not have the opportunity to witness these anticipated games.
"While we extend our best wishes to Easton High School, it is essential to emphasize that safety remains our top priority. We too understand the importance of maintaining a safe and secure environment for all involved.
Cambridge-SD High School was closed Wednesday due to weather conditions. Phone calls to the office of Cambridge-SD athletic director Casey O'Bier went unanswered.
On Wednesday, Talbot County Public Schools released a second statement in an email, saying that following the football game, administrators talked with coaches, athletes and parents about safety at future events.
"TCPS made the difficult decision not to allow spectators at upcoming home basketball events against CSD," the statement read.
Home games against Cambridge-SD will be livestreamed.
The statement continued that Talbot County school administrators asked that Cambridge-SD limit spectators at their home games.
"They chose not to," according to the Talbot County schools statement.
"Because the safety of our students and staff is always our highest priority, we have decided not to travel to CSD for the boys' and girls' basketball games on Jan. 11 and Feb. 15, thereby forfeiting those games," the statement read. "We value our relationship with our Dorchester County neighbors and believe this decision is in the best interests of all of the athletes involved."
The Easton and Cambridge-SD rivalry is one of the Bayside Conference's richest, especially in football and boys' basketball.
Entering Thursday's boys contest, Cambridge-SD (7-0 overall) was sitting atop the North Bayside with a 6-0 record and bidding for its first division title since 2020. Following the Vikings are second-place Queen Anne's (6-1) and Easton (5-1). Thursday's forfeit moves the Vikings to 8-0 overall and 7-0 in the division, while Easton slips to 6-4 overall, 5-2 division.
The boys' game at Easton is scheduled for Feb. 15 and will not have spectators.
Cambridge-SD's girls enter today's game at 5-2 overall, 4-2 North, trailing division leaders Queen Anne's (7-0, 6-0) and Kent Island (6-1, 6-0). Easton's girls are currently 3-6, 3-3.
Star Democrat Reporter Natalie Jones contributed to this article.

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man is facing charges including first-degree murder in connection to the fatal shooting of 26-year-old Virgil Simms last year.Jahmere Bryan, 19, is charged with first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, use of a firearm while committing a felony, and three other firearm and handgun charges.
Bryan is one of two shooters police allege are responsible for the death of Simms on Oct. 20, 2024, in the area of Pine Street. Nineteen rounds were fired and Simms sustained a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.
On Thursday, though, a jury acquitted the other main suspect, 18-year-old Jo'Mir Norman, of all charges in relation to the case. Prosecutors relied heavily on video evidence and clothing in trial, but dealt with challenges during witness testimony and the fact that the murder investigation started off with a significant mistake.
Bryan was arrested by police last November, but it came after police misidentified 15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. as one of the two suspects. Maryland State Police wrongly arrested Wongus and charged him with first-degree murder, among other offenses. Charges were dropped in late October or early November, according to an MSP spokesperson.
The misidentification of Wongus as one of the two shooters came up in Norman's trial this week. Attorneys on both sides acknowledged the error, though offered different opinions on how the evidence leading to the misidentification compared to the evidence presented against Norman.
As for Bryan, a jury trial previously slated for mid-July was postponed. A future trial date has not yet been released.
Charging documents allege Bryan fled from the shooting scene just after 7 p.m. on Oct. 20, 2024. Investigators reviewed surveillance video and allege clothing worn by Bryan earlier that day was found in a house on Camelia Street where the suspects allegedly fled to after the shooting.
According to court documents, investigators interviewed a witness who identified Bryan and provided his street name, "Krunch." The witness saw Bryan on Camelia Street before the murder, per court documents.
Bryan is being held without bond at the Dorchester County Department of Corrections.

title: Steady leadership, respect earn voters' support
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Steady leadership, respect earn voters' support

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we proceed full speed into the 2024 presidential election, the levels of bitter, vitriolic, divisive, often misleading, bombastic and demeaning rhetoric from candidates of both parties continues to escalate.This election cycle reminds me of a bitter and contentious general election for governor in Pennsylvania.
In that election, the Republican candidate was William Scranton, a former one-term Republican member of Congress. The Democratic candidate was Richardson Dilworth, the incumbent mayor of Philadelphia.
Scranton's political resume was thin. His only experience as a candidate was his successful run for Congress. Despite that, the state GOP was bullish on him after losing to Democratic candidates in two previous gubernatorial elections. They believed Scranton's success as a volunteer civic leader on economic development issues in a depressed region of a rust belt state would resonate well with voters.
Dilworth on the other hand, had a long history of political success in Philadelphia. He was elected city treasurer, district attorney and twice as mayor. His success was due in part to Philadelphia being a deep blue city with huge numbers of Democratic votes cast in local and statewide elections.
Dilworth's electoral success in Philadelphia was also based in part on a simple, but effective campaign strategy. His campaign would purchase time on a local TV station to which he would invite his opponents to a debate. He did so fully expecting his opponents would not participate. They always obliged him. As a result, he had a full hour of viewers to himself, where he reminded them not only of his accomplishments, but also repeatedly mentioned that his opponent chose not to participate in the debate.
As the November gubernatorial election heated up, Dilworth again rented TV time and invited Scranton to join him for a debate. He smugly assumed that Scranton, like all his previous opponents, would be a no show.
Dilworth assumed wrong.
Minutes before airtime Scranton unexpectedly strolled into the TV studio. A surprised and angry Dilworth had a meltdown. It started when Dilworth shouted at Scranton, "What are you doing here?"
During the debate, Dilworth peppered Scranton with insults. With thinly disguised contempt he called Scranton a phony, a coward, a Little Lord Fauntleroy, and an Ivy League Dick Nixon. Unruffled, Scranton calmly but forcefully responded with "You, sir, are a desperate man."
All of this was captured on film and was also widely reported by the print media who were there for the debate. Even those who did not see the actual television debate read all about Dilworth's meltdown.
The debate was an unexpected and game changing negative branding movement for Dilworth's grace under pressure, civility and steady leadership credentials.
By contrast, the debate was an unexpected and game changing positive branding moment for Scranton's grace under pressure, civility and leadership credentials.
In November, Scranton beat Dilworth with 55% of the total statewide votes. This occurred despite strong support for Dilworth from President Kennedy who had carried Pennsylvania in the preceding statewide presidential election.
This is a lesson for the candidates the Republican Party and the Democratic Party eventually nominate for president in 2024.
American voters have long deserved and rarely seen a presidential election where candidates are not demonizing those who disagree with them and their supporters, by questioning their motives and their intellectual capability to make informed decisions.
Regularly showing grace under pressure, civility, steady leadership and respect for all views during a long and often grueling campaign is the best way for candidates to earn voter's support and gain their trust to govern fairly and inclusively if elected.
Now is the time for presidential candidates from both parties to commit to disagree on issues without being extremely disagreeable. Voters deserve nothing less.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who serves as a trusted adviser on strategy, advocacy and media matters. He lives in Easton.

 EASTON — Hundreds of teachers and staff gathered in the Easton High School auditorium Thursday morning to celebrate the dawn of a new school year.Talbot County Public Schools hosted its annual Opening Day celebration, welcoming new teachers and presenting staff members with special awards before school begins Monday. Bands from the district's schools joined together to welcome staff, and many other students performed and introduced speakers for the gathering.
Jeremy Hillyard, the district's 2024-2025 Teacher of the Year, and Rosario Steele, the district's 2024-2025 Support Staff of the Year, were each presented with a 2025 Chevrolet Trax from Hertrich Chevy Buick GMC of Easton.
General Manager Pat Papineau thanked Hillyard, Steele and all of the district's teachers for their dedication to their professions.
"I imagine that a lot of people think that your guys' job starts a few minutes before the kids get there and ends a few minutes after the kids leave," Papineau said. "That couldn't be farther from the truth. … It's pretty much nonstop. You're continuously trying to improve yourself, you're continuously investing in yourself, you're continuously investing in your students."
Hillyard, a Spanish and English second language math teacher at Easton High, and Steele, an instructional assistant for English second language students, both delivered speeches to the crowd.
"Each of us in this room plays an important role in our students' stories," Hillyard said. "And it's our job and up to us to make that role a supporting one by always having their backs."
"This job has been the most rewarding experience in my life," Steele said. "I have witnessed those students that start as ninth graders with very little English inspire me when I see them in the community after graduation."
Many other awards were handed out during the event. AJ Rojas, the district's facilitator of interpretation and translation, was presented with the Wardell Brine Multicultural Award. Robin Werner, director of teaching and learning, was named winner of the Brewster Merrill Technology Award.
Named after a past superintendent, the J. Sam Meek Unsung Hero Award was presented to three staff members: Charlotte Compton and Heather Ewing, teachers at Easton Elementary, and George Larrimore, a bus driver since 2010.
MOVING FORWARDDistrict Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi closed Thursday morning's festivities with a speech indicating major areas for the district to focus on. Some examples were staffing, transportation, dress code and student behavior.
"I believe in bite-sized chunks and taking it slow, so that it's not a lot and it doesn't seem overwhelming," Pepukayi said.
She noted that adding mentors for incoming teachers and math coaches has been successful for the district. Pepukayi said the district will begin working on a new four-year strategic plan, as the current plan wraps up in 2025.
At the end of her speech, Pepukayi indicated the district is maintaining its three priorities of improvement heading into the 2024-2025 school year: academic equity in math, an "engaging" environment for students and staff, and recruiting and retaining a more diverse staff.
"We're going to stay the course with these three priorities as we continue to move into this next year of transforming and performing together," Pepukayi said.

title: Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay

 March 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DUNDALK — A few hours after Teresita Santana and her family drove across the Francis Scott Key Bridge, they felt their house shake."As if something had exploded," Santana said.
Santana and her family, including her children and mother, got back to their home in Dundalk late Monday night after a trip to Washington, D.C., to get their passports and see the cherry blossoms. It was only a few hours after they crossed the Key Bridge on their way home that the bridge collapsed.
A container ship slammed into the iconic bridge just before 1:30 a.m. Tuesday. Within seconds, the bridge crumpled into the chilly waters of the Patapsco River at the entrance to the Baltimore Harbor.
In the hours that followed, authorities began search and rescue efforts for survivors of the collapse. Radar indicated that vehicles had been discovered at the bottom of the river, which is about 50 feet deep.
By Tuesday evening, officials said that six construction workers who had been repairing potholes on the bridge at the time of the collapse had been presumed dead. Two construction workers were rescued in the efforts.
Tuesday morning, Santana looked out on the now collapsed bridge from a hill on Dundalk Avenue, across the street from the Logan Village Shopping Center.
"It was scary because it could have been us," Santana said.
Santana wasn't the only one looking at what's left of the I-695 bridge. People filtered in and out Tuesday morning to see it for themselves. "Shock" was a word repeated often.
"Shock and dismay," were the words Judy Corkhum used to describe the emotions of residents she had talked to.
"Nobody in a million years thought we would wake up this morning to something like that," said Corkhum, who also viewed the collapsed bridge from off Dundalk Avenue. "It brings back emotions from 9/11. ... You saw that and the first thing you think is, 'Oh my god. The people. The workers.'"
Corkhum, who recently moved to Baltimore from Dundalk, said she heard about the bridge collapse via a text from a neighbor at 4 a.m. Tuesday. She said her friend's son, a truck driver, "literally just got over the bridge before it happened."
"She said, 'I was having a heart attack this morning thinking he was out on the road last night,'" Corkhum said.
Corkhum said her friend went into surgery this morning, so she was happy to know her son was OK.
Anthony Meeks, a Dundalk native, said he heard about the collapse as soon as he woke up.
"The Key Bridge is a very iconic piece of Dundalk," he said. "It's something that everybody who's from Dundalk or this city even has at one point in their life crossed."
Meeks remembers being scared to cross the bridge when he was younger. These days, he crosses it every two weeks.
"It (will) make me go out of my way to find a different path to get to where I need to go," he said about the collapse. "It could make my trips be a lot longer."
Meeks called the incident an eye opener.
"Because it's like you don't really expect these kinds of tragedies and stuff to happen and occur in your neighborhood," he said.
Dundalk-Patapsco Neck Historical Society President Jean Walker said this is the first time Dundalk has experienced a large disaster like this.
Historical Society Vice President Joe Stadler called the event "unbelievable."
"It takes a while to fathom it," he said.
For both Walker and Stadler, the bridge has been a big part of Dundalk. They said the founder of the Historical Society, Ben Womer, was "instrumental" in getting the bridge named after Francis Scott Key, the author of the national anthem.
"It's the backdrop for everything around here," Stadler said about the bridge.
Standing on the hill, looking at the wreckage of the bridge, Corkhum said she had to make the trip from her new home in Baltimore to see what had happened with her own eyes.
"I'm so used to seeing that pretty view out there every day," she said. "It's going to be horrible seeing that (there's) no view anymore."

title: Stephen Harvey is bringing jazz to St. Michaels
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Stephen Harvey is bringing jazz to St. Michaels

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST MICHAELS — When Stephen Philip Harvey is playing the saxophone, the sounds that come from the horn of the golden instrument are lively, rhythmic and attention-grabbing.Harvey, a celebrated and well-decorated musician from the Eastern Shore, has a generational love for music.
Its a love he shares with those running the Windon Distilling Company in St. Michaels, who have invited the musician to be a part of unveiling their newest endeavor.
Having just finished its 11th year of production, the distillery is opening a new event space, Golden Hour, next to its staple tasting room. Harvey will be performing a sold-out show to mark its opening Friday night.
The distillery's founder Jaime Windon said in a press release, "this space is designed for showcasing the things we love the most: rum cocktails alongside brilliant and inspiring music, art and community. To be able to debut it while enjoying jazz along with our friends and neighbors in January is a dream."
Harvey was raised in a family passionate about music and would perform for their local church. Raised on gospel music, he soon expanded his repertoire into jazz and gained an appreciation for gathered sounds and instruments.
According to Harvey, it's not uncommon for someone in his family to break into song.
"My love for music is really a family love for music," Harvey said. "My whole family are singers and musicians… (there are times) we would be on a walk to meet up together in a space, and then someone would be like, 'oh, let's sing this hymn,' and then we break out into four part harmony. My wife was very startled by it the first time she was at a family event."
As Harvey grew up, his curiosity in music began to change away from gospel when his high school band director encouraged him to join the jazz band. From there, his relationship with music took several twists and turns.
When he got to college, his interest peaked in studying music education before choosing to focus on Western European art music, where he learned song styles of Italian, German and French musicians.
But it was American music through idioms of bebop, hard bop, vocal jazz and then big band jazz that made Harvey want to commit the rest of his life in exploring those sounds.
"It's this really interesting hobby/career where I feel like I can just do it forever and always discover new things, even looking back and going forward," Harvey said. "So discovering new things as I write and discovering new things as I listen to people who have performed and recorded in the idiom before me is so cool, especially since you come from this family that loves music so much."
Today, Harvey is a professional musician, composer and bandleader. He has released seven full albums throughout this career, with "Library Card" being his latest release.
Additionally, his compositions have been performed by an array of ensembles across the world including the National Youth Jazz Orchestra, ensembles at the Peabody Conservatory of Music and several universities across the nation.
Harvey sees his upcoming performance as part of an effort to expand jazz music's presence in the area, a mission the distillery's owners are also on board with.
Windon said she is a fan of jazz and was incredibly excited to host Harvey and his trio Sphinx as the first musical act at Windon's new event venue.
For Windon, Harvey has an electric presence.
"I have a great appreciation for jazz music of all kinds of styles, and so I liked that his music felt classic and familiar, but yet fresh," Windon said. "… There's a charisma, to me, that Stephen has that I think is also reminiscent of jazz musicians that I've always known and gravitated towards."
Harvey said he has performed in Easton and his concert will be his first time playing in St. Michaels. He shared that he's excited to establish himself on the Eastern Shore and share his love for jazz.
"My whole vibe since I've moved down here is seeing what a vacuum of jazz and Black American improvised music is on the Shore," Harvey said. "There's like none, and I would love to produce as many shows as possible, whether they are in conjunction with Lyon Rum and the Golden Hour or anywhere else. I'm just excited for any opportunity to play inside of this county."

 DENTON — Throughout the past two years, solar energy has been a major topic of discussion on the Eastern Shore.The conversation was raised again at the Caroline County Commissioners' bi-weekly meeting Tuesday, where the commissioners dissected a proposed legislative bill on solar.
The solar energy ordnance would bring the county in compliance with state law. The bill focuses on maintaining accessory solar, which is residential solar that is generating power for a property's electrical use.
After discussing several definitions they wanted to revise, the commissioners raised concerns about donating money to the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation. The commissioners have no problem with donating to agricultural land preservation, they said, but they want to make sure the money is going back to farms in Caroline County.
The county contributes $20,000 per year to the land preservation foundation. On top of that, commissioners said, when solar projects come into Caroline County on agricultural land, the solar company has to pay an agricultural transfer fee, which the county also donates to MALPF.
Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter's concern is if the state funding was cut on MALPF would the county still receive financial help to preserve agricultural land.
"If we collect money in Caroline County, I want it to be used to preserve farmland in Caroline County," Porter said.
No official decision was made on donation of the funds, and the county will continue to discuss options at future meetings, the commissioners said.
The county officials will discuss some changes to the proposed bill and move the bill to an official legislative bill with the purpose of having the first reading at the next county commissioners meeting.

Easton man pleads guilty to distributing child pornography

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty Wednesday to six counts of promoting and distributing child pornography.Darian Braun, 23, said he made the decision to plead guilty because he is guilty and it was in his best interest.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel said said that in June of 2024, the Easton Police Department got a cyber tip from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children about a person possessing child sexual abuse material. She said that through investigation, the person was identified as Braun.
Endzel described the content of the videos Braun pleaded guilty to distributing, which all included underage girls. Endzel said that when police executed a search and seizure warrant at Braun's residence, Braun told police that he knew he messed up.
After Endzel detailed the case, Braun's attorney Holland Brownley, who is with the Talbot County Public Defender's Office, said she had no additions or corrections to Endzel's summary.
Before entering into a plea agreement with the state, Braun had received 34 charges. Seventeen of those charges were for promoting and distributing child pornography, and the other 17 charges were for possessing child pornography.
As a part of the plea agreement, the state will enter nolle prosequi for the remaining 28 charges Braun did not plead guilty to, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
The six counts Braun pleaded guilty to each carry a maximum sentence of 10 years and a maximum fine of $25,000.
Braun was not sentenced during the plea hearing, and a sentence hearing date has not yet been set.
The state recommends Braun receive a sentence of 25 years with all but six of those years suspended. The state also recommends Braun serve five years of supervised probation and be added to the sex offender registry as a tier II sex offender.

title: COVID censorship?: Could Mark Zuckerberg's admission on government pandemic pressure impact the 2024 election
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
COVID censorship?: Could Mark Zuckerberg's admission on government pandemic pressure impact the 2024 election

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1131
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Could META / Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's mea culpa that the Biden-Harris administration "repeatedly pressured" the social media giant to censor dissenting voices during the COVID-19 pandemic translate into a major issue in this year's elections?In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee released Monday, Zuckerberg said the White House pressed Meta Platforms (which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp) to censor and restrict accounts and posts that went against U.S. government and administration public health policies during the coronavirus pandemic.
"In 2021, senior officials from the Biden administration, including the White House, repeatedly pressured our teams for months to censor certain COVID-19 content, including humor and satire, and expressed a lot of frustration with our teams when we didn't agree," Zuckerberg wrote.
"I believe the government pressure was wrong, and I regret we were not more outspoken about it," said Zuckerberg, promising to push back on future government pushes in the letter dated Aug. 26 and posted on the committee's Facebook page and to its account on X.
In a statement, the White House defended its COVID social media actions.
"When confronted with a deadly pandemic, this Administration encouraged responsible actions to protect public health and safety," the statement to Politico and other media outlets said. "Our position has been clear and consistent: we believe tech companies and other private actors should take into account the effects their actions have on the American people, while making independent choices about the information they present."
REKINDLING COVID FIGHTS?
The letter comes as Democrat Vice President Kamala Harris and Republican former President Donald Trump face off in the 2024 election just over a year from when the Biden-Harris administration officially ended its pandemic emergency declarations in May 2023.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, more than 27 million U.S. jobs were lost, millions more saw their hours or pay cut, as many as 40% of small businesses were closed and close to 1.2 million deaths were attributed to the virus by public health agencies.
The coronavirus was a once-in-a-lifetime, global event. The pandemic included fights over economic and social restrictions and business and school shutdowns and pushes for government and employer vaccine mandates. Government spending and central bank infusions during both the Trump and Biden-Harris administration fueled 40-year inflation highs with high prices still hitting American households.
Overall, U.S. prices are up 23% since the pandemic, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But other than persistent, post-pandemic inflation (which voters count as a top concern headed into November), COVID has not been a prime campaign issue.
That could change with Zuckerberg's letter, increasing conflicts between policing social media and free speech, and independent presidential candidates Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s endorsement of Trump.
Kennedy is a strong critic of pushes by the Biden-Harris administration and other Democrats for vaccine mandates as well as their push for social media restrictions during the pandemic.
He also wants more scrutiny of vaccines as well as processed foods.
In a social media post before his endorsement of Trump and moves to take his name off ballots in Electoral College battleground states, RFK Jr. vowed to keep COVID in the spotlight.
"The government also selected the lockdown winners and losers, transferring nearly $4 trillion of wealth from the middle class & small business to Silicon Valley and big box stores," Kennedy wrote.
Zuckerberg's letter was also not lost on Kennedy.
"Looks like Mark Zuckerberg has joined the ranks of the crazed conspiracy theorists who claim that the Biden administration pressured Facebook to censor dissent during COVID," RFK Jr. said Tuesday.
'MEMORY HOLED'But the issue has not been overtly pressed by Trump, Biden or Harris during the 2024 campaign.
Why not?
The pandemic stretched across both the Trump and Biden-Harris administrations. Coronavirus vaccines were developed and gained fast-track approvals under Trump. They were widely deployed by the Biden-Harris administration which also pushed for a number of vaccination mandates that faced court challenges.
Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, Harris' running mate after her installation at the top of the ticket after Biden quit the race in July, was an ardent advocate of COVID restrictions and shutdowns during the pandemic.
Walz backed mask mandates, instituted a COVID hotline for residents and neighbors to report those not abiding by social distancing, stay-at-home and other pandemic rules and threatened repeat violators with $1,000 fine and 90 days in jail, according to executive orders.
Eric Raile, a political science professor at Montana State University, said in an interview before Zuckerberg's letter that voters are fairly well entrenched and the fights mirror deeper American political divisions.
"There's not much left to wring out of the pandemic," he said.
The two national political camps had some alignments during the pandemic.
Massive spending measures aimed at rescuing the economy from a recession or depression were approved by both Trump and Biden. That spending, along with central bank infusions in the U.S. and across the world, help drive the post-pandemic wave.
Dr. Anthony Fauci led U.S. COVID responses for both administrations, although he fell out of favor with Trump and was fully embraced by Biden.
While Biden and Harris advocated for vaccine mandates for some workers, Trump left many restrictions and policies to individual states. He has touted developments of the COVID vaccines under his watch and made off-the-cuff and confusing comments about the use of UV light and disinfectants to combat COVID.
Other political scientists and campaign consultants see many voters wanting to move forward from all the economic, educational, social public health traumas of the pandemic.
Jeffrey Lazarus, political science professor at Georgia State University in Atlanta, contends many Americans have "memory holed" the pandemic and its myriad of stresses.
"I think people want to move on with their lives," he said.
'RETURN TO NORMALCY'Ryan Waite, a veteran consultant who has worked mostly on Republican campaigns, noted the rapid news cycles and significant campaign upheavals — including the attempted assassination of Trump and Biden being pressured to quit the race — and how that makes events such as the coronavirus pandemic seem distant.
Craig Snyder agrees that most voters want to move on from COVID and its upheavals, pointing to parallels to sentiments after the Spanish Flu pandemic in 1918.
"I think there are very few voters who are thinking about [that]. They've probably been concentrated as RFK Jr. voters," said Snyder, a Pennsylvania-based consultant who is serving as director for the anti-Trump Haley Voters for Harris groups.
Snyder said American elections are often about moving forward — especially from stressful and traumatic events. He sees contemporary similarities to the aftermath of the 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic (which coincides with World War I), which killed an estimated 675,000 in the U.S and as many as 50 million worldwide, according to the University of Pennsylvania.
Snyder pointed to Republican presidential candidate Warren G. Harding's successful campaign slogan of "Return to Normalcy" as reflective of the broader sentiments in 2024.
"For the most part, the majority of voters want to be in the rearview mirror," he said.

title: Maryland’s housing order aims to boost affordable housing, cut barriers
author: SANDRA SMITH Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s housing order aims to boost affordable housing, cut barriers

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SANDRA SMITH Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 638
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order on Sept. 3 aimed at tackling Maryland's escalating housing affordability crisis. The Housing Starts Here initiative seeks to expedite housing development, reduce production delays and make home ownership more accessible across the state.According to the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD), the state faces a deficit of around 96,000 housing units — a gap that has been widening over recent years.
The 2025 Maryland Housing Needs Assessment, an analysis of Maryland's housing gap conducted by DHCD and The National Center for Smart Growth, reveals significant disparities in housing availability across the state. Counties like Montgomery and Howard have median home prices exceeding $600,000, making homeownership unattainable for low and middle income residents.
Conversely, areas such as Allegany and Wicomico counties report median home prices below $200,000, which indicates regional inconsistencies in the Maryland housing market.
The executive order will broadly target each county in Maryland in order to create more housing development throughout the state.
"[The executive order] says that everybody has a piece of the housing crisis, and everybody deserves for their local and state governments to be working in concert to solve that crisis," DHCD Secretary Jake Day said.
In more than half of Maryland counties, renters are spending more than one-third of their annual income on housing costs, which is considered unaffordable by federal standards.
While Maryland's median income is 28% higher than the national median, the state's median home price is 35% higher, highlighting the disproportionate cost of housing.
"How we got here is really the post-2008 financial crisis. It was real-estate driven… that had to do with risks that the financial industry took at the time," Secretary Day said. "It led to a collapse in the economy, in residential home values and more. The over-correction of the market meant we stopped building houses at a pace that matched population growth."
The Housing Starts Here Executive Order directs state agencies to identify underutilized state-owned properties suitable for transit-oriented development, aiming to increase housing density in areas with existing infrastructure.
Transit-oriented development is a strategy that promotes dense, mixed-use communities around transit to help increase ridership and the use of public transportation.
"There are a lot of benefits to it… we want to develop state-owned land for transit-oriented development, since state-owned land is not currently taxable. There's no revenue generation for the states or local jurisdictions. It also provides an opportunity for Marylanders to live closer to transit and use it more," Maryland Department of Transportation's Chief of Real Estate and Transit-Oriented Development, David Zaidain, said.
According to Zaidain, transportation is the second biggest household budget item behind housing. It costs roughly $600 a month for Marylanders to own a car, which is pushing the state towards more transit usage.
Zaidain also noted the climate change benefits that come with transit-oriented development.
The executive order directs the state to speed up timelines for housing permits and establish a state housing ombudsman, or overseer, to help projects move forward.
The legislation comes on the heels of a 2024 legislative package that made housing more affordable and accessible for Marylanders struggling with construction barriers, along with creating the Office of Tenant and Landlord Affairs.
The Housing Starts Here order also directs agencies to track housing production progress annually, coordinate with local governments to address regional shortages and ensure accountability across jurisdictions.
By centralizing oversight and removing barriers, the administration aims to close the housing deficit and expand affordable options for Marylanders in the years ahead.
"When regulatory processes add cost, that cost has to be recouped — either with higher rents or a higher sales price. So, the more regulatory burden we place, the more likely it is that we're just producing expensive [places] for people to live," Secretary Day said. "By cutting time and money out of the process, by streamlining it, we can make it easier to get to the finish line."

title: Volunteers 'make a difference'
author: Tamara Forte; Special To The Bay Times Record Observer

Volunteers 'make a difference'

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 SUDLERSVILLE - Kindness, enthusiasm and a passion for helping exuded from the front doors at Sudlersville Middle School as 75 households and 130 people were served on Saturday, Nov. 4, at the 10th annual "Make a Difference Day." Tables, chairs and volunteers lined the halls, gymnasium and areas outside of the school.This non-profit and free community event began in 2014 as a way to provide county resources and services for families in need.Housing Program Administrator Kelly Huber said "not only do we rely on the committee, (but) it takes a village of volunteers to assist on the day of the event. We had over 70 volunteers from the community to help - including student volunteers from the Boys Scouts, the sea cadets, adult volunteers, and local school volunteers." Volunteers - of all ages - wore "Make a Difference Day" shirts that said: "Ask me a?" on the back. Volunteers spent the day providing information and services throughout the event.While the Division of Housing and Community Services oversees the event, a large committee plans and executes it. Composed of people from local businesses, agencies, and individuals from the community, many of the original Make A Difference Day board members remain on the committee and are active members in both the planning and in volunteering during the day.Sea cadets volunteered their time and politely welcomed each person in attendance by opening the doors and formally greeting them.Sea cadets are 10 to 17 yearolds who participate in the United States Naval Sea Cadet Corps (USNSCC), a youth leadership development program sponsored by the U.S. Navy.Once through the doors, attendees were given a navigator (who spoke their language) to guide and help them through over 50 tables, services and resources, all conveniently in one location.Each person and family could select the services they needed. Services included: legal aid, social services, meals and food access, education, transportation, housing, personal hygiene, and much more. Eddie the Barber, stylist Ashley Calderone and many Queen Anne's County cosmetology students completed 30 to 40 free haircuts on Saturday.The dental van completed over 30 free dental screenings and provided goodie bags to all.Other services included free flu shots and medical testing (blood pressure, cholesterol and glucose testing).The Lions Club helped more than 10 people with vision needs. Additional services were also offered throughout the day.Giveaways were offered to everyone and were crowd pleasers - toiletries, hats, mittens, blankets, slippers, socks, diapers and wipes, and food from the Maryland Food Bank. Many of those were made possible by donations.The entire event is funded through grants, sponsors and monetary donations from the community. And all donated items found homes that day.

author: WILL BONTRAGER

On 80th anniversary of D-Day, Post members pay homage

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER | Section: Local News

 CHESTERTOWN — Storm clouds gave way to piercing sunlight on Thursday, June 6, marking the 80th anniversary of D-Day at the John H. Newnam Armory at 509 S. Cross St., Chestertown.Members of the Frank M. Jarman American Legion Post 36 came to pay homage to those soldiers lost on the beaches of Normandy that bleak day in 1944.
Of the 2,501 US troops who died, many were from here.
At the foot of the stone monument, post members laid a wreath and flowers donated by The Mill of Kingstown, showing the Legion is just as active in the community as when they had their building at 9155 American Legion Road.
The monument reads: "In grateful tribute to the men of the medical detachment of the 115th Infantry Regiment Maryland National Guard, both living and dead this shrine is dedicated. Their valiant efforts helped preserve freedom in America, 1941-1945."
At that sacred spot, incoming Post Commander Tim Lloyd, a veteran of the Navy, provided remarks.
"We lost some good people, and their sacrifice gave us our freedom today."
Commander Paul Showalter talked about the clandestine nature of the mission the Kent County soldiers trained for at the Armory.
"Two days prior to June 6, 1944, the activity to get prepared to go to Normandy wasn't mentioned in (President) Roosevelt's fireside chats," he said.
Roosevelt only hinted at it.
In the armory, built in 1931, was where those soldiers trained. From that training area, men went to the European theater and engaged in the largest amphibious invasion in military history, a battle that changed the trajectory of World War II.

title: Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 717
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A board designed to help preserve grave sites in Dorchester County has one year to prove it is able to accomplish its mission or it will face dissolution.After holding a public hearing about repealing a chapter of the county code regarding burial sites preservation, the Dorchester County Council agreed Jan. 21 to keep the chapter — which includes the Burial Sites Preservation Board established within it — for a test period.
"A one-year test from today to see what you can accomplish and see if it is a worthy board to have within this county," Council Member Ricky Travers said before making the motion.
Throughout the public hearing and following discussion, council members brought up concerns of past problems with the board's participation and its ability to work cohesively. Council President Lenny Pfeffer said that in the one-year test period, the board would need to prove it can fill its seats and provide a quorum at its meetings.
Travers said board members would need to work together, not against each other as has been the case in the past.
"As passionate as people might be about grave sites, ... we cannot have this controversy," Travers said. "So whomever comes on that board needs to be willing and ready to work side-by-side."
County Planning and Zoning Director Susan Webb said the Maryland Historical Trust is the state's enforcing entity regarding burial sites preservation.
"And we were basically duplicating the effort," she said. "While this may be a good board for a nonprofit, being under the county's umbrella, I don't think it's working out."
Dorothy Samonisky, the chair of the Burial Sites Preservation Board, said the Maryland Historical Trust only gives guidance and does not "act as an arm of the law" like the county can.
"So right now, this burial site preservation is the only thing that gives you as county members anything to stand on if there is an incident with a grave site."
Pfeffer clarified that the board is an advisory group to the council.
Samonisky said people have been buried in Dorchester County since 1669, and many of those burial sites are on private property. She said the policy in county code gives the county the authority to "act upon destruction of those cemeteries."
Ashley Samonisky, who also spoke during public comment, said the board can guide council actions and help with outreach and education. She said there needs to be something in the code that addresses what happens if a person "maliciously destroy(s) a property or (tries) to hide the fact that it was there," in order to build a beach house, for example.
"There needs to be fines," she said. "There needs to be penalties up to and including the cost of restoring it to the pre-demolition stage. These are just a few ideas that this body can help with."
Dorothy Samonisky acknowledged that there were "internal conflicts" between several board members at one point. She said she also was out due to two major surgeries in 2024.
"We had met up through '23 and had things on the agenda and topics to discuss," she said.
Council Vice President Mike Detmer, who ultimately voted in favor of the board having a one-year test period, said he thinks the board has value, but would function better if not affiliated with the county.
"It being a law and having to be constituted a certain way and done a certain way is holding an effort to preserve burial sites back," he said, later adding, "I think it could be more flexible and more dynamic as a stand-alone."
Detmer said as long as he is on the council, if someone comes to the council with "a salient point" about something in the county, it will get attention. That doesn't require a board, he said.
Before the council unanimously agreed to give the board a test period, Travers said the board had previously gone through an "extremely adversary" time that got to the point where some board members felt unsafe coming to the meetings. He said the county practically had to act as a referee.
"And that's not what we need on our boards," he said.
Pfeffer warned the this can't happen again.
"The last board that was assembled ... had brought things to this chamber," he said. "Had brought thoughts of slander. Had brought disagreements. I will not allow that to happen during these meetings."

title: The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The beloved Blue Crab Coffee Shop in St. Michaels has reopened under new ownership, but they're not new to many on the Eastern Shore. Bagery owner Matt Andrews has expanded his reach from Easton to St. Michaels with the Blue Crab.Andrews took ownership of the establishment in May, and he says he's excited to honor the history of the space.
The Blue Crab building was a formerly Odd Fellows Lodge, built in 1867. It was originally named the Shealtiel Lodge No. 1024. Four years after the Civil War ended, the building was renamed to the Freedom's Friend Lodge No. 1024, and is the oldest Odd Fellows Lodge remaining in Maryland.
"All the plates that we use are from former Odd Fellows Lodges around the country," Andrews said.
He wants to pay homage to the building's former use by learning and preserving its history through social media videos, interviews with members of the historical society, and by getting footage of some of the artifacts.
"We're anxious to learn more and tell people about it," he said.
Along with the interesting history that comes with the establishment, Andrews is excited to expand service beyond breakfast and lunch. He said they plan on testing out dinner service soon but want to get their footing at the new location first.
Andrews says the community response has been overwhelmingly positive with strong feedback on the organic bread products made from scratch in Easton.
"All the feedback has been good about the food and the coffee and service," Andrews said.
Former Blue Crab owners Helen and Brian Herman stepped away from the restaurant in mid-April so Helen could focus on her architecture practice, Brian on his recording studio and so the two could spend more time with their three children, according to a Facebook post made by the Blue Crab in early April.
Andrews said the Herman's still own the building and he has a good working relationship with them. "We've had a good relationship with them over the years," he said. "They have been buying bagels wholesale from the Bagery since we opened in 2018."
According to Andrews, a majority of the menu uses the products they make in house at the Bagery and has an array of vegan options.
Blue Crab baristas Anna Szwaja and Alyssa Skinner said the transition in ownership has been smooth. Szwaja worked for the Blue Crab's previous owners last summer, and Skinner started at the Bagery a year and a half ago.
"We all get along really well," Szwaja said. Skinner agreed, saying she really enjoys her co-workers.
"I like getting to know customers and people that come in regularly," Szwaja said as she gestured to the knitting club in the back of the restaurant.

content:
Centreville's Landon Hawkins triumphs at Northeast Poultry Congress

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 415
 Words

 CENTREVILLE — Many participants dream of winning and advancing to Champion Row. Landon Hawkins of Centreville achieved an extraordinary feat this January by reaching Junior Champion Row with three different entries.Fifteen-year-old Landon, a ninth-grade student at Faith Christian School in Sudlersville, attended the Northeast Poultry Congress Poultry Show in West Springfield, MA, this past weekend. This prestigious event is the third-largest poultry show in the country, attracting top competitors from across the nation. Martha Stewart was in attendance, adding to the prestige of the event.
His outstanding accomplishments included winning Junior Champion Waterfowl with a white call duck drake, Junior Reserve Champion Waterfowl with a gray call duck pullet, and Junior Champion Turkey with a Royal Palm Tom.
Landon has been passionate about poultry for years. He started hatching chickens and turkeys four years ago, but his ambitions took flight when he decided to focus on building a foundation stock of high-quality bred Call Ducks.
Getting a bird ready for competition requires months of preparation and conditioning to ensure it meets the American Standard of Perfection — the official guideline for judging in poultry exhibitions and county/state fairs.
His first win was at the county fair level where he won Champion Waterfowl at the Queen Anne's County Fair in August with one of his Call Ducks. This victory was just the beginning of his journey in competitive poultry showing.
Inspired by his grandmother, who shows Sebastopol geese, in American Poultry Association (APA) sanctioned shows across the region. Landon turned his focus to competing in sanctioned shows.
With careful attention to breeding, grooming, and conditioning, Landon began winning at various American Poultry shows in Virginia and New Jersey, proving that his birds were top-quality contenders.
With this success, he set his sights on an even bigger stage—the Northeast Poultry Congress in Massachusetts, one of the most competitive shows in the region.
For Landon, showing poultry is about more than just competition. He says his favorite aspects of showing include traveling to new destinations, meeting experienced poultry breeders and mentors, and the thrill of anticipating how the judge will score his birds. Each show is an opportunity to learn, grow, and connect with others who share his passion.
Beyond the show ring, Landon and his grandmother are taking their dedication a step further. They are in the final stages of launching Hawkins Poultry, a specialized breeding program focusing on Call Ducks, Sebastopol Geese, and Royal Palm Turkeys. Their goal is "to raise and exhibit top-quality birds while promoting these breeds to other enthusiasts and exhibitors."

title: Doncic learning it takes awhile to win
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Doncic learning it takes awhile to win

 June 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 861
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Michael Jordan needed seven seasons to win his first title. LeBron James needed nine seasons and two futile trips to the NBA Finals before he became a champion. Shaquille O'Neal got swept in his first finals. And the newly crowned champion Boston Celtics lost the finals in 2022 and lost in the Eastern Conference finals last year before breaking through now.The lesson, as everyone knows: Winning the biggest prize almost always takes time. Not always. But usually.
Such is the reality for Luka Doncic. At 25, he already is one of the best players in the world, if not the very best of the bunch. But he's not a champion. Not yet.
The wait for his first championship will extend until at least 2025, which really shouldn't be all that surprising. Doncic and the Dallas Mavericks weren't a logical pick in this series against the Celtics; one was a 50-win team that caught fire at the end of the regular season, the other was a 64-win team that was better than everyone from the very beginning. The smart money said Dallas would fall in these finals, and that's what happened. It ended Monday night in Boston, the Celtics winning 106-88, an 18-point margin for their record-setting 18th title.
"They're a great team. They have been together for a long time, and they had to go through everything, so we just got to look at them, see how they play, the maturity, and they have some great players," Doncic said when it was all over Monday night. "We can learn from that. We've got to fight next season."
Let's be clear: Losing these NBA Finals should in no way be an indictment of Doncic. He could have played better, of course. Smarter at times, for certain. He spent some of the finals arguing too often with referees. He knows that. That said, letting a finals loss take anything away from the first six years of his body of NBA work would be ridiculous.
He's scored 11,470 points so far, 15th most of anyone through their first six NBA seasons. Throw in his 3,472 rebounds and 3,317 assists, and Oscar Robertson is the only other player with such stats from Year 1 through Year 6. James came close. Jordan came close. But they didn't have those numbers.
It's not like this needs explaining, but just in case: Doncic — already a five-time All-NBA first-team selection — is on an absolute Hall of Fame trajectory.
"He's played as best as he can despite the circumstances, just injuries and stuff," Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving said earlier in these finals. "He's been giving it his all."
Doncic played through knee and ankle issues in the playoffs. He had a thoracic contusion that required painkilling injections to get through the NBA Finals. He wasn't at his best, and he would have had to be otherworldly for Dallas to have had a real chance in this series.
He finished the playoffs as the leader in points, rebounds and assists anyway. Not the Mavs' leader, the NBA's leader.
"He's one of the best players in the world, and so I think the biggest thing for him is that we all would like to be healthy, but there's going to be bumps and bruises along the way," Mavericks coach Jason Kidd said. "So, for him at the age of 25 to get to the finals, to be playing his basketball at the level that he's playing, now it's just being consistent. ... When you have one of the best players in the world, you should be always fighting for a championship."
The Mavs felt that Doncic was the real MVP of the league this season, and their argument was compelling even though it didn't resonate much with voters. Kidd says Doncic's greatness gets taken for granted, which may be true. When Doncic gets it going, it's must-watch TV. He makes scoring look as easy as anyone has in this generation. He's not a high-flyer like Jordan, not someone who plays with the force, flair and power like James does. But when he's on, forget it.
He might not be "the" face of the league. But he's in the conversation, especially globally. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver watched Doncic closely on the day before the finals started and, in his own words, came away with yet another "example of how international this league is."
"Someone who grew up in Slovenia and trained in Madrid and Spain was doing interviews in three different languages," Silver said. "Again, many of you spend time with him, but he's an exemplar of the modern NBA."
The Mavs bristled at criticism Doncic took during the finals, but in some ways, that's welcome-to-the-club stuff. Jordan heard doubters. James still does. The Celtics, until Monday night, did as well. They don't doubt nobodies. Comes with the territory, and Kidd hopes Doncic converts it into fuel for his future.
"When you're on the biggest stage, someone's got to poke a hole," Kidd said. "This will only make the great ones better. When you look at … LeBron, Michael, the greats, the GOATs, they all were poked at, and they came back stronger and better. I truly believe Luka will come back stronger and better."

title: 'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race

 October 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Could anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab-American Christians) upset with U.S. support for Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas potentially tip the 2024 election away from Vice President Kamala Harris in favor of former President Donald Trump?In 2020, President Joe Biden won 69% of the Muslim vote, compared to Trump's 17%, according to Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR). Exit polls by the Associated Press in 2020 gave Biden 64% of the Muslim vote versus 35% for Trump.
Times have changed.
The Biden-Harris administration's military and diplomatic support for Israel's war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7, 2023, attacks and ongoing conflict with Hezbollah in Lebanon have eroded Arab-American and Muslim support for Harris' White House bid.
More than 43,000 people have died in Gaza since the start of the war more than a year ago, when Hamas killed 1,200 Israelis and took more than 250 hostages. More than 100 of those Israeli hostages (including a handful with dual American citizenship) are still being held by Hamas and other Islamic militants.
Israel's continued siege and bombings inside Gaza have killed more than 20,000 women and children, according to the United Nations, citing Palestinian estimates.
A worst-case scenario for Harris is that Muslim voters, Arab American Christians and other anti-war voters (including younger voters) back the Green Party's Jill Stein (who opposes the war and U.S. backing of Israel), Trump or sit out the election, which could potentially tilt the razor-thin election in battlegrounds including Michigan, Wisconsin and North Carolina.
SEISMIC SHIFT?A national poll released last month by the Arab American Institute found Arab Americans shifting away from Democrats and Harris.
The group said in the past Arab Americans voted for Democrats by a roughly 2-to-1 margin.
The October poll found Trump leading Harris among Arab Americans 42% to 41%, with 12% backing a third-party candidate such as Stein or Cornel West, who also opposes the Gaza war.
Harris is polling 18 percentage points below Biden's 2020 standing with Arab Americans, according to the poll.
"In our 30 years of polling Arab American voters, we have not witnessed anything like the role that the war on Gaza is having on voter behavior," said James Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute, in a statement, pointing out 81% of Arab Americans view the Israel-Hamas war as a top issue.
There are more than 3.7 million Arab Americans in the U.S., according to AAI.
Close to 393,000 Arab Americans live in Michigan (which Biden won by just over 154,100 votes in 2020). Another 126,500 live in Pennsylvania (which Biden won by more than 78,500 votes).
AAI estimates two-thirds or more of Arab Americans are Christians, while one-quarter are Muslim.
While Evangelical Christians are among the staunchest supporters of Israel, Orthodox, the Roman Catholic Church and more liberal Protestant denominations — which also have churches in the Holy Land — have pressed for an end to the war and criticized Israel's Gaza bombings and invasion as it seeks to eradicate Hamas.
Another poll released earlier this month by the Arab News and polling firm YouGov gives Trump a 45% to 43% lead over Harris among Arab American voters. Stein gets 4%.
'BITTER PILL'
Late August polls by the Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR) showed Harris getting 28% of the Muslim vote in six key Electoral College swing states, compared to 30% for Stein and 15% for Trump.
The CAIR poll gave Harris 12% of the Muslim vote in Michigan (a key swing state with a significant Arab-American population) versus 40% for Stein and 18% for Trump.
Robert McCaw, government affairs director for CAIR, said Harris hurt her standing with Muslim voters with recent pronouncements that she wouldn't change anything about the Biden administration policies.
"She stands by the policy of providing Israel with U.S manufactured weapons," McCaw said.
"It's a bitter pill for Muslim voters to swallow," he continued.
McCaw said if margins are tight in the presidential race or key Senate contests, anti-war voters could tip the balance. He also said like any group, Muslim voters can look to other issues, including the economy and social matters. He warns candidates not to take them for granted with Gaza in the backdrop.
"They could be in for a big surprise," he said.
'VITAL VOTES'
One leading anti-war group, Abandon Harris, has endorsed Stein.
Hudhayfah Ahmad, spokesman for the group, said the U.S. administration's "disregard for Palestinian lives has deeply damaged Harris's credibility with a large bloc of voters, including Muslims, progressives and human rights advocates."
"Their votes are vital in this election, and with each bomb dropped in Gaza, Harris's candidacy suffers more," he said.
Harris — who has been heckled by anti-war protesters at some campaign rallies and TV appearances — has tried to walk a political balance beam of supporting Israel's right to defend itself after the Hamas attacks and continued rockets from Hezbollah while calling for a ceasefire. She also snubbed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech before Congress in August, and did meet with him at the White House voicing concerns about war deaths.
Harris told CBS News Saturday the U.S. would help defend Israel if Iran strikes back after Israel Defense Forces bombed installations in Iran on Friday.
Ahmad is frustrated with the year-long cycle of top U.S. administration officials, including Harris, calling for and talking up a ceasefire and occasionally criticizing Netanyahu, only to see truce talks falter, coupled with White House and Pentagon pronouncements of "ironclad support for Israel" and continued military support.
"This cycle of empty calls for a ceasefire, followed by a new round of munitions shipments, has become insulting to Muslim voters and others who care about ending the massacres. It's a hollow strategy that tries to pacify the public, while enabling the very acts they claim to denounce. People are tired of the hypocrisy," Ahmad said.
NO FANS OF TRUMPHarris does enjoy backing from Emgage Action, a Muslim group advocacy group that backed Biden in 2020.
Emgage CEO Wa'el Alzayat said "Gaza has been completely destroyed, tens of thousands of civilians have been killed, including many children, and a population of two million has been destitute."
But Alzayat said voting for a third-party candidate will help Trump win the White House.
"Muslims do not need to be reminded of who Donald Trump is," Alzayat said, pointing to the travel bans he proposed from several Muslim countries, moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem and backing Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.
Alzayat said Trump also "blessed Netanyahu's expansionism by recognizing Israeli occupation of East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights" and has promised support for Netanyahu on the campaign trail. He sees more hope in Harris, despite her standing by Biden's war stance.
Ahmad is also no fan of Trump.
"Trump's record on Palestine is disastrous — he's championed Israeli expansion and disregarded Palestinian rights altogether. Muslim voters have every reason to distrust him on this issue," he said.
A national poll by The Economist and YouGov shows 36% of Americans sympathize with Israel in the war, 17% back the Palestinians, 25% have equal allegiances and 22% aren't sure. More than two-thirds of conservatives and 45% of wealthy voters back Israel, according to the survey.
The same poll shows 32% of Americans believe Israel is committing genocide in in Gaza, while 35% say they aren't and 32% aren't sure.
'PEACE, NOT WAR'Trump has promised strong support for Israel and is backed by pro-Israeli mega-donor Miriam Adelson and other pro-Israel advocates including billionaire hedge fund manager Bill Ackman. Eighty two percent of white Evangelical Christians — who are among the strongest backers of Israel — support Trump.
But he has also vowed to end the Holy Land war, as well as the war between Russia and Ukraine.
Trump had a group of Muslim leaders and imams — including Dearborn Heights, Michigan Mayor Bill Bazzi — on stage with him during a rally in Michigan on Saturday, welcoming their support.
"We, as Muslims, stand with President Trump because he promises peace, not war," said Imam Belal Alzuhairi. "We are supporting Donald Trump because he promised to end war in the Middle East and Ukraine. The bloodshed has to stop all over the world, and I think this man can make that happen. I personally believe that God saved his life twice for a reason."
Trump has also promised global protections for Christians, promising support for Coptic Christians in the Middle East and pointing to the sectarian dispute between Orthodox Armenians and Muslim Azerbaijanis.
The U.S. provides $3.8 billion in military aid to Israel annually. The Biden-Harris administration backed a $14 billion war aid package and approved a $20 billion long-term weapons sale to Israel earlier this year, and has sent troops, weapons, fighter jets and naval assets during the war with Hamas and Hezbollah and skirmishes with Iran.
Those efforts enjoy bipartisan support. Still, Republicans, including U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, as well as Trump, argue Biden and Harris have not been supportive enough of Israel.
Trump is also courting Jewish voters, another traditional Democratic voting bloc, and has touted his communications with Netanyahu. Jewish voters backed Biden over Trump by a 68% to 30% margin in 2020, according to the Jewish Virtual Library.
A poll this month by academic research group CHIP50 found some slippage, with Harris holding a 54% to 36% lead over Trump among Jewish voters. A new poll by Channel 12 TV in Israel shows 66% of Israelis back Trump in the U.S. election versus 17% for Harris. More than 90% of Netanyahu backers prefer Trump over Harris, according to the Israeli poll.
This comes as Harris and Democrats press the case that Trump is a fascist who admires Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
"I'm not a Nazi. I'm the opposite of a Nazi," Trump told a campaign rally Monday in Atlanta.
