title: Strand Beach Project To Be Completed By Summer
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com
content:
Strand Beach Project To Be Completed By Summer

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - With the first phase of construction complete, Oxford's Shoreline Improvement project along the Strand is expected to be complete by summer.Oxford Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said the first part of the project, to build the shoreline infrastructure, "touched on nearly all parts of the project."
This part, which was completed before Thanksgiving, included building a berm between the road and the water, placing hooks along the east and west areas of the Strand to help bring sand in and creating small islands in the water to reduce the waves that come onto the beach.
Lewis said these island structures were built using a combination of rock, wood chips and other components.
"(The structures) will sit over the winter months, which allows them to stabilize," Lewis said. "It allows them to go through weather, high tides, we just had a fairly substantial storm, that sort of stuff."
Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner said the construction brought in extra traffic, particularly with all of the materials that were brought in using larger vehicles like dump trucks.
In order to allow space for workers to do their job and to prevent damage to civilian vehicles, Kellner said that the police department, with the help of Public Works, closed the beach parking lot.
There were some concerns from residents about the large construction vehicles speeding in the area, Kellner said.
"In response to that, we did a few things," he said.
"One was, obviously, we ran radar to enforce the speed limits. And we also deployed our speed sign to remind the vehicles of their speed in hopes of calming any potential speed issues."
Kellner said that in running radar and collecting data from the speed sign, the police department really sees an issue with speeding.
He said that large and loud vehicles driving down a small, narrow street can sometimes give off the perception that the driver is speeding.
"Our findings were that most of those larger vehicles were following the rules of the road," he said.
In the spring, the second part of the project is set to begin.
"We're estimating April," Lewis said. "I mean a lot of this is dependent on weather temperatures, asphalt, plants, a lot of factors."
Lewis said the second part will include adding plants to the new structures, adding signage, elevating land on the far east end and making improvements to the parking lot.
"The whole concept is to build a higher area all along the Strand to protect it from the stormwaters off the river," Lewis said.
The parking lot will be built with storm management areas underneath it so that storm water can enter it and be filtered before going back out. The parking lot will be paved with asphalt, with a cobble layer underneath it.
"There's a lot of - not just tidal water coming from the river - but also stormwater settling along that road in the parking lot," Lewis said.
"So bringing all of that elevation up to prevent that and allowing the water to go under the road and then back out into the creek will basically build resilience for that whole area."
Lewis said that as the sea level rises and the intensity of storms increase, infrastructure along the Strand becomes more vulnerable.
"Keep in mind, this is the only road we really have that runs along the water," she said. "This area here, it's worthy of this type of resilience protection because a breach in any place, especially up near the parking lot, would be so difficult to repair."
Lewis called it a project for the future.
"With the impacts of sea level rise and stormwater and tidal water management that we're seeing currently," she said, "it's necessary to look at how to build in these areas with natural infrastructure that will help to protect it in the future."
David Ghysels, who walks along the Strand every day, said he thinks the project will be nice when it is complete, particularly if it helps with flooding.
Lewis said she has received positive and negative comments from residents on the project.
"I think the closer you are to the project physically, the more involved you may have been over the last five years," she said. "So I think that one of the impacts will be people who don't go there regularly or aren't involved in the government regularly all of a sudden want to know what happened. So it's really just a continued educational process."
Mac Sommerlatte, who lives next to the beach, said he thinks the project should, when finished, positively impact the town by minimizing shoreline erosion and mitigating the impact of sea level rise. He said the project is a complicated one.
"I think one of the problems is that there are several projects here," he said.
"It's not just one. And people don't seem to have the complete information on all of them. And they may disagree with parts of it."

 TRAPPE — On Tuesday evening, the Trappe Planning Commission met and approved a minor amendment and Phase 1D subdivision revision plat for the Lakeside development. By approving this, they have cleared the way for the Trappe Town Council to vote on this phase of the Lakeside development.The commissioners approved Phase 1D of the subdivision revision, with the notation that the areas identified as public open space on the plat would be clearly labeled as such.
Trappe Attorney Lyndsey Ryan stated that open space is defined as active and passive open space for public use and enjoyment.
Robert Rauch, president of Rauch Inc., the engineering, architecture, and environmental firm constructing the Lakeside development, told the commission that there may be some confusion about the distinction between public open space and private space.
Rauch wanted to ensure that the areas labeled as public open spaces were properly understood to be used by the public.
The open space would not be within stormwater management. Rauch explained that the areas in the exhibit will be green open areas for "throwing frisbees." The exhibit has two parks: Lakeside Public Park and Wooden Public Park. There is public access to the sidewalks between the two areas by trails.
Open space areas would be under the homeowner's association's mandate and management, regardless of whether they are designated as public or private. Rauch clarified that for any areas designated as public open space, the HOA would have the obligation to provide a permanent and perpetual public easement for access and use.
The development agreement states that the public shall have a permanent and perpetual easement to use and enjoy the open space, which may not be limited by the petitioner or any HOA.
The commission voted to approve the revisions of the subdivision to make sure that all designed public spaces were clearly labeled.
Cannabis
Ordinance 1-2024, an ordinance for the town of Trappe to establish reasonable zoning regulations for cannabis businesses, was also approved by the Planning Commission and will be recommended to the Town Council for approval.
Margaret English, a resident of Trappe, was a vocal advocate against approving the zoning regulations for cannabis businesses.
"I don't think you should recommend it," English said. "I don't want drugs in my town, and I ain't moving."
Commissioner Edgar Harrison noted regardless of whether or not he agreed with her; he didn't think the state would permit the town to outlaw the introduction of cannabis businesses into town. After the meeting, he sat down with English and listened to her concerns regarding cannabis.

 CHESTERTOWN — The National Music Festival, a community-driven event in Chestertown that supports young professional musicians through mentorship, lodging, meals and scholarships, will hold a special fundraising concert Sunday, Oct. 5, at 4 p.m.The concert, hosted by Emmanuel Episcopal Church, will celebrate the church's contributions to the Festival each June. Two acclaimed Festival alumni — cellist David Agia and pianist Leili Asanbekova — will return to perform at Emmanuel Episcopal Church, 101 N. Cross St. Tickets will be available at the door for $20, with proceeds supporting the free lunches the church provides to Festival musicians.
Emmanuel Church's role
Emmanuel Episcopal Church plays a pivotal role in the annual Festival, offering spaces for rehearsals and performances and providing weekday lunches to musicians, mentors and staff.
Festival Executive Director Caitlin Patton praised the support, saying: "It's the generosity of the Chestertown community — particularly our host families and Emmanuel Church — that makes our Festival possible and our community special. This fundraising concert will recognize, at least in a small way, all the essential volunteer effort and generous support that Emmanuel Church provides."
Featured musicians
Cellist David Agia has performed as a chamber musician, recitalist and orchestral player at venues including Carnegie Hall, Alte Oper Frankfurt, Palacio de Festivales, Symphony Space in New York and Historische Stadthalle Wuppertal. He has appeared in numerous festivals and master classes. Agia is an adjunct professor of cello at Rowan University.
Pianist Leili Asanbekova began studying music at age 6. She has performed at concerts, government events and festivals, and won several local and international competitions. She has collaborated with conductors including Marek Moś, Vladimir Spivakov and Yuri Simonov. She is pursuing her Doctor of Music degree at the University of Maryland.
Concert program
The concert will feature three works for cello and piano by Italian and Spanish composers.
Alfredo Casella and Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco were members of Italy's "Generazione dell'80," tasked with creating a "new Italian sound." Both had complicated relationships with the fascist Italian government. Castelnuovo-Tedesco, who was Jewish, emigrated to the United States in 1939, finishing his career in Hollywood.
Early 20th-century Spanish composer and cellist Gaspar Cassadò's music reflects his Catalan roots. A student of Pablo Casals, he dedicated his cello and piano piece Requiebros to his teacher.
About the Festival
The National Music Festival brings together world-class mentors and young professional apprentices for two weeks each June. The 14th season will run May 31–June 13, 2026.
Apprentices receive full scholarships and housing, mostly with local host families. They rehearse and perform alongside mentors in orchestral, chamber and solo recitals, presenting more than 30 concerts and dozens of open rehearsals.
More information on the Festival, tickets and donations is available at https://nationalmusic.us

title: Appreciating oysters
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Appreciating oysters

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Having grown up on the Eastern Shore, the oyster has been a much-appreciated seafood in my life.My mother made some of the greatest tasting oyster fritters on the Mason Dixon line. There are no watermen in my family, but we lived close enough to the water to respect the life of the waterman and the delicious delicacies that were a result of their hard work.
In our local area here, the most popular oyster varieties include Malpeques, Well Fleet, Blue Points, Delaware Bay, Chesapeake Bay, Chincoteagues, Apalachicola Bay and Gulf Coast.
East Coast oysters range from slightly salty to sharp salt flavor (Chesapeake, Delaware and Gulf Coast oysters have a light salt taste; all others have a sharper salty taste).
The Chesapeake Bay has been home to oystering since the early 19th century. Chesapeake Bay skipjacks are the last commercial sailing vessels in the United States.
The dredge boats once numbered in the thousands. Today only about a dozen or so remain.
Skip jacks are limited to 150 bushels of oysters daily. The dredging season runs from November through March 1. The recent ice has made it impossible for the boats to get out to perform their work — cutting into the ice and cutting into the pockets of our waterman and their families. Check your local newspapers and the Facebook posts of local fire departments, churches and organizations with upcoming oyster dinners and roast coming up for their fundraising events.
I know that many seafood markets are featuring fresh oysters in the shell or by the pint and quarts or opened for you. I like to open my own — eating them on the half shell or cooking them fresh.
Try going down to the docks and getting them from the waterman themselves. Support a trade that is slowly leaving our Eastern Shore. Thank a waterman who goes out in all kinds of weather laboring in a trade they must love that is full of obstacles. The weather has cleared, and the watermen are returning to the trade they love. I am on the way to the docks for oysters to prepare some of my favorite seafood dishes.
EASTERN SHORE OYSTER FRITTERS
Drain 1 quart of oysters, reserving the juice, and set aside. Beat 2 eggs, add the reserved juice to the egg and add Worcestershire sauce to taste. Add 1 1/2 cups flour with 1 1/2 tsps baking powder and mix well. Add the oysters and lightly mix. Fry in hot oil, browning on both sides. Drain on a paper towel and serve warm. When dropping the fritters in the oil, make sure you have at least 3 oysters to a fritter.
TRADITIONAL MARYLAND OYSTER STEW
In a large saucepan, cook one-pint fresh shucked oysters, with juice, over low heat until edges begin to curl. Add 1 quart of milk, 1/4 cup butter, salt and pepper to taste. You can sprinkle some Old Bay seasoning on top if desired slowly, but do not boil. Serve hot with oyster crackers if desired.
SCALLOPED OYSTERS
In a greased two-quart casserole, place alternate layers of oysters and fresh cracker crumbs, doting each layer with butter. For this process you will need one quart of oysters with liquid, 2 to 3 cups fresh crushed crackers and 1/2 cup butter or 1 stick margarine. You can also sprinkle each layer with salt and pepper to taste. End with a layer of crumbs, and pour one to two cups of milk over the top. Dot the top with remaining butter or margarine and bake at 350 degrees until browned, about 40 to 50 minutes. Makes 6 generous servings.
OYSTER POT PIE
In a large saucepan place 5 or 6 diced potatoes, cleaned and peeled, with 5 or 6 carrots, 2 to 3 cleaned and diced onions, 1/2 pound of chopped ham, and 4 strips of uncooked bacon. Cook until done and add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with 1/2 tsp parsley flakes and 1/2 tsp oregano. Mix 1 pint crushed tomatoes and the liquor of one pint of oysters. Add this to the already cooked ingredients. Bring to a boil; thicken with some cornstarch. When thick, add one pint of oysters. Cook until the oysters have curled edges. Pour into a baking dish lined with your favorite crust and place a crust over the top. Slightly prick the top crust with a fork, bake at 400 degrees until brown. This is so delicious for supper on a wintry day.
BACON OYSTER LETTUCE TOMATO
1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 1 tbsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp onion powder, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper, 2 dozen oysters (freshly shucked), 12 slices thick-cut bacon, vegetable oil (for frying; about 5 cups), 8 slices brioche or white sandwich bread toasted, mayonnaise, bibb lettuce, and sliced tomatoes. Whisk flour, cornmeal, garlic powder, onion powder, and cayenne in a medium bowl; season with salt and pepper. Working in batches, toss oysters in flour mixture, transfer to a plate. Working in batches, cook bacon in a large skillet, preferably cast iron, over medium heat until crisp, 10–12 minutes per batch; drain on paper towels. Pour oil into a skillet with bacon fat to a depth of one inch and heat over medium-high heat until oil bubbles immediately when a pinch of cornmeal mixture is added. Working in batches, fry oysters, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crisp, about four minutes. Drain on paper towels, season with salt and pepper. Build sandwiches with mayonnaise, lettuce, tomatoes, bacon and fried oysters and serve.
OYSTER CORNBREAD STUFFING
8 tbsps unsalted butter (divided), 4 stalks celery (finely chopped), 1/2 yellow onion (finely chopped), 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp rubbed sage, 1 tsp dried rosemary, 1 tsp dried thyme, 1/2 tsp coarse ground black pepper, 6 cups cornbread cubes, 18 ounces oysters (chopped, liquor reserved), 2 cups chicken broth, 2 large eggs. Preheat oven to 350 degrees and spray a 9x13 baking dish with vegetable oil spray. Add 4 tbsps unsalted butter to a large skillet on medium heat. Add in the celery and onions, cook for 6-8 minutes until translucent. Add in the salt, sage, rosemary, thyme, and black pepper and stir. To a large bowl add the cornbread cubes, vegetable mixture, and oysters and toss. In a second bowl whisk together the reserved oyster liquor, chicken broth, eggs, and melted butter. Pour the mixture over the bowl and toss gently to moisten the cornbread cubes. Pour the mixture into your baking dish and bake, uncovered, for 30-35 minutes until golden brown.
SINGLE FRIED OYSTERS
1 pint freshly shucked raw oysters, 2 cups buttermilk, 1¼ cup fine yellow cornmeal, ¾ cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp Creole seasoning, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 quart peanut oil. While the oil heats, pour the oysters into a colander or strainer and let them drain. Then, rinse with fresh water to wash off any debris or shell fragments. Pour the buttermilk into a medium-sized bowl and dunk the drained oysters. Let them marinate for 15 to 20 minutes. Place the cornmeal, flour, creole seasoning and salt in a shallow bowl or pie plate and whisk to combine. Remove the oysters from the buttermilk one at a time and dredge them in the cornmeal mixture. Toss gently and make sure they are well coated, then shake any excess bread off. Place the coated oysters on a metal cooling rack until all of them have been coated. Letting them sit for a few minutes helps to fuse the breading and buttermilk and keeps the breading from falling off when they are fried. Place a large stockpot, Dutch oven, or cast iron skillet with high sides over medium-high heat and add one to two inches of oil. When the oil reaches 370 degrees, carefully add the oysters, one at a time to fry. Depending on the size of your pan, it works best to fry in batches and only cook six to eight at a time. You do not want to crowd them. (Maintain a consistent heat of 370 degrees by increasing or decreasing the heat under the pan.)Let the oysters fry for about two to three minutes, stirring occasionally or until the breading is light golden brown and the meat is opaque with the edges slightly curled. Use a wire kitchen spider or slotted spoon to remove them from the oil. Place on a paper towel or wire cooling rack to drain. Repeat until all of the oysters are fried and serve immediately. Optional, garnish with fresh lemon or lime slices and serve with your choice of sauce and sides.

title: St. Michaels Commissioners bid farewell to duPont, approve ordinances
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels Commissioners bid farewell to duPont, approve ordinances

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 At the Commissioners of St. Michaels meeting Wednesday evening, leaders discussed Commissioner Thomas "Tad" duPont's resignation. The board also approved an ordinance establishing zoning regulations for cannabis businesses and approved the proposed contract with International Computer Services Incorporated for IT work.DUPONT RESIGNATIONCommission President David Breimhurst announced the resignation of Commissioner Thomas "Tad" duPont. Breimhurst stated that duPont's resignation was due to health reasons.
DuPont submitted a letter of resignation on Feb. 6 that Breimhurst read to those at Wednesday's meeting. In the letter, duPont recounted the "challenging" three years and nine months the board had while he was in office. Among the challenges duPont listed were navigating the pandemic, creating budgets and many other efforts.
"It has been a pleasure to serve, and (I) wish all continued success," stated duPont's letter.
DuPont was most recently elected to serve as a town commissioner in July 2020. He first served as a commissioner from 2010 until resigning in August 2013 over concerns with an ethics ordinance, according to prior Star Democrat reporting.
The vacancy on the town commission came three months shy of the town's upcoming election. Three seats, including duPont's, will be up for grabs on May 6.
But because duPont's resignation came within 90 days of the next regular election, the vacancy will remain unfilled until the election, according to the town's charter.
When Breimhurst finished reading the letter, he added a personal note on how grateful he was to serve alongside duPont.
"I thank Tad for his dedication and devotion to the town of St. Michaels. His love for the town is never ending," Breimhurst said.
CANNABIS BUSINESSES ZONINGThe Commissioners unanimously approved an ordinance changing zoning regulations for cannabis businesses that would permit cannabis dispensaries and processing facilities as a special exception in St. Michaels' general commercial zoning districts.
These changes would allow the zoning board to review each application based on factors such as noise, parking and compatibility with the neighborhood.
A nine-month cannabis moratorium, which temporarily blocked applications, site plans, permits, construction, processing and approval for businesses looking to manufacture or sell recreational or medicinal cannabis in St. Michaels will run its course at the end of the month.
ICSI CONTRACTThe Commissioners voted to renew St. Michaels' contract with International Computer Services Incorporated to assist with the town's IT services. ICSI is the town's current IT consultant and is under contract for another year and a half.
Town Manager Rob Straubel recommended the approval of the ICSI proposal because it will avoid issues with having multiple service providers and separate maintenance contracts.
OTHER TOWN BUSINESSMike Bibb, a member of the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, presented an annual review of actions taken by the Accountability Board, established in January 2023.
This board comprises two parts — the Policy and Procedure Committee and the Accountability and Charging Committee.
The Accountability and Charging Committee reviewed 50 complaints filed, and Bidd stated that no cases were made against law enforcement from St. Michael's.
The challenges faced by the Police Accountability Board included police recruiting and retention and new juvenile justice laws that make it more difficult to charge juveniles for crimes, Bidd said. He advocated for improved police training and changing laws regarding the statute of limitations for police misconduct charges.
The commissioners then discussed reviewing the town's ethics code.
Straubel recommended developing a board to review the code. The board will comprise five people: one to be a commissioner and four to be community members. The commission will post an announcement to the general public in ConstantContact for volunteers.

title: VFW plans parade to welcome Vietnam veterans home 50 years after end of war
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
VFW plans parade to welcome Vietnam veterans home 50 years after end of war

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When Kenley Timms returned home from the Vietnam War, he did not receive a warm welcome."I was never spit on, never thrown trash at, but when I landed at National Airport in Washington, I walked into the airport, and there was a lady and her child, probably 5, 7 years old, and I spoke to the child, and that woman picked that child up like I was the devil," Timms said.
Other returning soldiers faced even more hostile receptions upon returning to a country where political tides had turned and the Vietnam War, unbeknownst to those deployed, had become deeply unpopular.
"And at the time, I didn't know about it because when I was in Vietnam, I didn't know what was happening back in the United States," Timms said.
Now, 50 years after the war ended, Timms, the commander of VFW Post 5118, and a collection of other veterans at the post in Easton are seeking to give their fellow service members the welcome home they never got.
On March 30, the VFW post plans to hold a wreath laying ceremony before a parade through downtown Easton and a short program in honor of Vietnam veterans.
"I'm hoping that we'll have a couple thousand people standing in the streets, waving to us," Timms said. "You'll see a lot of veterans walking or riding, ones that are able to walk, tears rolling down their face."
The parade route, which has already been approved by the Town of Easton, will begin at the intersection of Dover and Washington streets, then make its way down Washington Street and Glebe Road to the VFW. Event organizers plan to distribute American flags for spectators to wave.
But beyond event attendance, the Vietnam veterans behind the event are hoping to gather parade participants and gain assistance with transportation for veterans who are unable to walk the parade route.
"We need transportation, but we don't want a bus. We want something where people can see them, the public can wave to them," Timms said.
"What we're looking for is people to participate," added Wayne Hall, president of the VFW's Vietnam Veterans Chapter. "If anybody has any military vehicles, the collectors, we'd be glad to have them."
Those who wish to be involved in the event can contact 410-310-5748.

 The 44th edition of the Ryder Cup returns as players tee off in Rome beginning Sept. 30 and finishing on Oct. 1, at the Marco Simone Golf and Country Club. USA Network and NBC will feature live coverage.As the 2023 Ryder Cup gets underway, Team Europe aims to return to its winning ways after what was a dominant victory for Team U.S. in 2021 (19-9). While the Americans on paper look to have more talent, the Europeans have gone 7-3 in the past 10 Ryder Cups prior to the less-than-par performance at Whistling Straits.But Team Europe, now led by fourtime Ryder Cup winner Luke Donald, is going into this tournament having put together a team with a good balance of youth, talent and experience.With the likes of Rory McIlroy, Jon Rham, U.S. Open champion Matt Fitzpatrick, Shane Lowry and the world No. 4-ranked Viktor Hovland of Norway, who is participating in his second Ryder Cup tournament.Having burst onto the scene making his Ryder Cup debut in 2021, Hovland has been excellent all season, having earned three top-five finishes, including defending his title at the Hero World Challenge. His proven ability to perform in big moments and against the world's top golfers is proven in his performances.The Norwegian has placed in the Top 20 at The Masters, U.S.Open and The Open, and was a runner-up at the PGA Championship.

title: Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School were arrested on the second day of school after multiple fights broke out, Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said.The school resource deputy alerted the Sheriff's Office that a student was assaulting the school safety monitor. Before it was over, Phillips said several deputies and school staff were assaulted, and one staff member was taken to the hospital. Phillips did not disclose the extent of their injuries, but he said that everyone was going to be OK.
The school safety monitor received multiple blows to the head and was held down on the floor, and three deputies were spat on by students, Phillips said.
"That's a biological thing, you just don't know what you're dealing with, now they have to get tests done," Phillips said.
Phillips said the incident was prompted by something that happened outside of school. He did not provide further details on what incited the fighting.
The response from law enforcement was substantial, including 10 Cambridge police officers, seven sheriff's deputies and five state troopers.
"A majority of law enforcement in our small geographical area was at C-SD," Phillips said.
Public details are limited due to the involvement of juveniles, but a 15-year-old was arrested and charged with five counts of second-degree assault, resisting arrest, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school activities, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office press release.
The second student arrested was 14 years old. The student was charged with one count of second-degree assault, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a reasonable and lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school operations, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the press release.
"The crowd was actually larger than that (the two arrests). A lot of onlookers with their cameras and stuff," Phillips said.
The two juveniles were taken to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, then released to their guardians with referrals made to the Department of Juvenile Services, according to the press release.

 Sugar, spice and everything spooky: Season 2 of "Halloween Cookie Challenge" airs Mondays through October on Food Network."Celebrity pastry chef Duff Goldman and social media sensation Rosanna Pansino celebrate the wildest and most colorful holiday of the year!," Food Network describes."They'll bring together the best cookie makers in the country to compete in two challenges and create the creepiest, spookiest and tastiest Halloween cookies ever made! title: Seahawks deny Vikings' bid for history
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Seahawks deny Vikings' bid for history

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SALISBURY — Davin Chandler may not have known Cambridge-South Dorchester High had never won back-to-back Bayside Conference championships in boys basketball.What Stephen Decatur's talented senior guard did know was he was going to do all he could to prevent the Vikings from beating his team for a second straight year
He pretty much did just that Tuesday night.
Attacking the rim from seemingly all angles and adding a few pull-up jumpers, Chandler scored a game-high 30 points while leading the Seahawks to a 60-48 victory over unbeaten Cambridge-SD in the conference championship at the Wicomico Youth & Civic Center.
"Sometimes we take things for granted. But we just witnessed a Division I player," Cambridge-SD head coach Shawn Tucker said of Chandler, who is headed to Vanderbilt University on a football scholarship. "He's going to school for football, but we just witnessed what a Division I player looks like. He did everything he needed to do for his team."
And he wasted little time doing it, driving hard to the hoop for the game's first points, then making a three-point play that tied the game at 5-5 with 2 minutes, 31 seconds left in the first quarter. Chandler slashed in for yet another drive to give Decatur (21-1) a 9-5 lead, stirring Decatur's fan base into thinking a potential quick getaway was in the making.
But Cambridge-SD (20-1) stayed close from beyond the 3-point arc.
Thomas Wilson's 3-pointer brought the Vikings within 9-8. Decatur moved to a 13-8 lead, but Kaleal Johnson's trey made it a two-point game. The Seahawks extended their second-quarter lead to 19-11 on buckets by Chandler, Judah Carmack (nine points) and Solomon David. Koby Ennals (11 points) hit one of his game-high three 3-pointers, drawing the Vikings within 19-14 with a little over 5 minutes left in the half.
The Seahawks upped their lead to six, but a field goal and 3 from Sterling Perkins Jr. (team-high 14 points) pulled Cambridge-SD within 20-19 with 2:38 remaining in the first half.
The Vikings though wouldn't get any closer, as Decatur used an 8-0 run to close the first half for a 28-19 edge, then widened its cushion to 32-19 less than 2 minutes into the third quarter.
"I feel like we forced some shots and then we settled, and then we hit the panic button," Tucker said. "We just weren't disciplined early enough to withstand what Stephen Decatur was doing. Hats off to them. They brought the energy."
Cambridge-SD, which hit 10 3-pointers compared to none for Decatur, kept its deficit between 10 and 12 points throughout the third quarter. But Chandler scored 10 of the Seahawks' final 13 points in the third quarter, mostly on drives, to give Decatur a 47-32 lead heading into the fourth quarter.
"He's just a winner," Decatur head coach B.J. Johnson said of Chandler. "There's a reason why he's going to Vanderbilt to play football. He's a coach's dream. And he would not let these guys lose. He's a great teammate. These kids rallied around him, bought into him being the leader, and I'm just so happy for him and all my players."
Chandler added six points during Decatur's 10-2 run over the first 4 minutes of the fourth, giving the South champions their biggest lead at 57-35.
"Big-time players step up in big-time moments," Tucker said of Chandler.
Cambridge-SD narrowed its deficit with a 10-3 game-ending run, but couldn't get any closer than 11.
"We just had one of those games," Tucker said. "Unfortunately, it was on the big stage. But fortunately it wasn't in the state playoffs."
The top-seed in Class 1A East Region II, Cambridge-SD will have a first-round bye and await the winner of Friday's Pocomoke-Crisfield game.
"This is a great opportunity to regroup, refocus and get prepared for the playoffs and make a deep run," Tucker said. "And guess what? It's one game. It doesn't define the rest of our season. So we have to continue to move forward and be positive. You have nothing to hang your head about. I know our guys. They're going to bounce back and they're going to make a run."
Notes: It was Decatur's first conference title since 2017. ... The Seahawks will be the No. 1 seed in Class 3A East Region I.

title: Easton police join athletes in carrying the torch for Special Olympics
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton police join athletes in carrying the torch for Special Olympics

 June 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Special Olympics Maryland athletes joined with police officers on Tuesday to carry the torch through Easton.Beginning on Dover Street, a group of around 100 athletes, families, law enforcement officers and community members participated in Talbot County's leg of the Law Enforcement Torch Run, an annual tradition to raise money for the Special Olympics. They brought along the Special Olympics torch, called the Flame of Hope, as they traversed the downtown streets of Easton.
Officers from the Easton Police Department and Talbot County Sheriff's Office, as well as local officials such as Easton Mayor Megan Cook and Talbot County Council member Dave Stepp, participated in the event. Some local organizations stood outside to cheer on the athletes, including employees from the Town of Easton offices and Rauch Inc.
Walking down Harrison Street, athlete Hannah McNiece beamed with joy alongside Easton officer Cordero Proctor, as the two each placed a hand on the torch and led the entourage of athletes to the finish line at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Some officers and athletes took a running route through town and caught up with the walkers toward the finish.
Jill Garvey, management assistant for the Easton Police Department, helps organize the torch run. She said it means a lot when the athletes interact with law enforcement and build relationships with the officers.
Other counties across the state participate in the torch tradition. Also on Tuesday, Queen Anne's County police officers joined with Kent Island High School students for the Law Enforcement Torch Run.
"This event is about more than a run, it's about promoting inclusion, dignity, and respect for every athlete," said Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann in a press release. "We're honored to be part of this tradition and proud to stand alongside our partners and students in support of such a meaningful cause."
The Summer Games for Special Olympics Maryland athletes is set to take place this weekend at Towson University from Friday to Sunday.

title: National Night Out connects cops with community
author: Tom McCall
content:
National Night Out connects cops with community

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A crowd in Moton Park joined communities all over the country in celebrating the 40th annual National Night Out Tuesday.National Night Out connects different branches of law enforcement with the community. The goal is to prevent crime and have people know the officers and emergency services personnel who serve their area.
Megan Coxon, a sergeant with the Easton Police Department, has been a primary force in organizing the event.
"We are here for First Night Out, which is a nationwide event. It happens the first Tuesday in August. I probably know half the folks here just because we interact on a daily anyway," Coxon said. "It is like a mini reunion. We get to hang out for a night, and of course you get to meet new people. If I don't know you, I will come talk to you and if I have seen you before, we will reconnect."
She said she got a lot of help from Jill Garvey, an EPD management assistant, and Lorraine Gould, director of Easton Parks and Recreation.
Coxon pointed out the law enforcement representatives in attendance.
"We have at least ten from EPD. We have sheriff's office, fire marshall's office, Natural Resources Police, Talbot Sheriff's office and MSP. There are about 40 people," she said.
Over a smoking hot grill with about 50 burgers were members of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
"We are cooking some good burgers. We got some good hot dogs. We got a decent crowd of people, it is its a good time," Aiden Lowery, a firefighter and EMT said.
Mayor Megan Cook was also present, immersed in community.
"Talking to people? That is the best part of my job," Cook said. "The sense of community is what is important tonight. I think to see the police department as partners and to get them visible in the community so our neighbors know that they are a resource and they are there to help."
John Grothe of the state's fire marshal office had a full kevlar and ballistic shield bomb squad suit and special helmet on display. He is a bomb tech and said the suit weighs 100 pounds.
"In the event that there is a device or suspicious package, we try to stay as remote as possible. We try to utilize our bomb robot, but every once in a while, we have to put on the suit and go downrange in person. Night Out is a great opportunity to meet people and have them come up and touch the equipment. We get to explain what we do. It puts a face to the agency," Grothe said.
There were over 100 community members wandering around, getting food, visiting with friends and getting information from the community service booths.
Jessica Carter, who was sharing an shaved ice with her daughter, said the National Night Out event gives her family an opportunity to see what resources are available to them.
"We come every year. The resources. Giving back to the community. Some people may not know what resources are available to them. So it is good. I like the health department and Chesapeake Voyagers," Carter said.
Garvey said she has been working on this event for over a month. She had two massive sheet cakes from Cordova Bakery in her air conditioned vehicle.
"It falls into place. I have been planning these for 18 years. It is a free fun family event. The pool is open. Come out and enjoy. There is free food. It is a good community event," she said.

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland fell 6.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.04 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 0.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 16.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago."Millions took to the road for Thanksgiving, and while some regions, like the Great Lakes, saw gas prices rise just in time for travel, most of the nation saw prices hold mostly stable or decline slightly as the national average remains near the lowest level we've seen since 2021," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
The national average price of diesel has risen 1.1 cents in the last week and stands at $3.514 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.65 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.14 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 0.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.00 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 23.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.

title: Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat

 July 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 753
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every Sunday when I was a child, we eagerly awaited the delivery of the Sunday newspaper. It always included a feature with riveting pictures from previous editions.They were not just a collage of all the pictures from previous editions.
They were selected by the newspaper's editors thinking not so much on how timely they were at the present, but how timeless they might be going forward.
If that program were still in place today, two pictures that most certainly would be selected would be from the 2024 presidential election campaign.
One is of former President and current presidential candidate Donald Trump after an attempted assassination at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.
In that surreal picture, Trump is being taken with a bloody hand on a wounded ear, blood on his face and his other hand raised as a defiant fist from the event stage by Secret Service agents.
Another picture would be from the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.
In that picture, Trump is standing alone on a stage next to the helmet and bunker coat of Corey Comperatore, who was a volunteer firefighter and Trump supporter who attended the Pennsylvania rally.
Corey died shielding his family from the fusillade that almost killed Trump and seriously wounded two other rally attendees.
Prominently displayed next to Corey's bunker coat and helmet is an American flag.
Trump appears to be gazing with deep contemplation of and reverence for the memorial for Comperatore.
In deeply divided America, both pictures are generating widely different reactions.
Some Trump detractors claim the assassination was preplanned to generate support for the Trump campaign. They have implied Trump exiting the stage largely under his own power was done to show a stark contrast to a former opponent who often stumbled and needed assistance while walking.
Some Trump detractors claim the picture of Trump looking at the Comperatore's memorial was staged for nothing more than scoring political points. They question if Trump's hand on the shoulder of the turnout coat was orchestrated and insincere.
Sadly, a significant number of seriously deranged Trump adversaries have posted messages on social media with messages like "sorry the shooter missed" and "hope he [Trump] is killed the next time."
I found the vileness and hate in those messages so disturbing I couldn't read all of them.
Not all those adversaries are radical fringe malcontents.
They include a wide range of elected officials, celebrities and political commentators who have regularly characterized and continue to characterize Donald Trump as a Nazi, a neo-Nazi, a fascist, a dictator wanna be and an existential threat to America.
Some Trump supporters believe the attempted assassination was a deep state conspiracy.
They maintain the spectacular failure of security at the event was by design.
They also believe constant inflammatory comments from Trump's many adversaries created an environment where the question on an assassination attempt was not if, but when.
I am not going to engage a debate on the credibility on either side on these deeply held beliefs.
I am more concerned such debate affirms that an alarming and steady decline of civil dialogue in our society is the greatest existential threat to democracy in America.
In today's intensely polarized political environment, it is considered normal and acceptable to disagree by being viciously disagreeable, to listen only to those who share and affirm that their views are the right views. Worst of all, we expect and accept the practice of demonizing anyone, and everyone who doesn't agree with us on every issue all the time.
We desperately need a renewed national commitment to critical thinking, listening to others, avoiding group think, respect for differing opinions and acceptance of a system of government where the majority rules, even when that can and does result in public policy decisions that do not have universal agreement.
Much easier said than done.
The underlying reality of where we are as a society is best captured by the cogent observation of veteran political communications consultant, Frank Luntz: "It's not what you say or write, it's what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
In other words — my mind is made up. Don't try to persuade me otherwise with facts.
When dealing the deep divisions caused by the issue of slavery and the American Civil War Abraham Lincoln said, "A house divided cannot stand."
America has been and is a house divided.
If we do not change course soon, we will not stand.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it
author: RIVERA SUN
content:
Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RIVERA SUN | Section: Columns 
 
 688
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm tired of the violence. Aren't you?Some days, it seems relentless. A mass shooting at a school. Another youth killed by gun violence. A family on the street after fleeing an abusive partner. A genocide halfway around the world. Brutal wars displacing millions.
When will the violence stop?
The answer is: When we take action to stop it, together.
It's not impossible. Communities across the country and around the world are showing us how. Violence may be everywhere, but so are the people trying to stop it. And many of them have powerful antidotes to the violence we face.
During the Campaign Nonviolence Action Days, Sept 21-Oct 2, tens of thousands of people will show everyone that another world is possible.
What does a nonviolent world look like? It's not all roses. Conflict happens — but we have better ways to respond without resorting to violence. Many of these strategies will be on display during the upcoming Action Days: Neighborhood safety patrols to prevent gun violence. Unarmed peace teams de-escalating tension in hot conflict zones worldwide. Anti-bullying programs aimed at preventing the next school shooter. Centers that help mothers and families get back on their feet after leaving abusive situations. Protests pushing banks to divest from weapons.
More than 4,438 actions and events are planned across the United States and around the world to "build a culture of peace and active nonviolence, free from war, poverty, racism, and environmental destruction."
An 11-year-old movement, Campaign Nonviolence aims to end violence in its many forms. This includes direct or physical violence (fights, bullying, war, gun violence) and it also includes systemic violence (houselessness, hunger, mass incarceration and the climate crisis). Going even further, the effort seeks to transform cultural violence as well, the beliefs, attitudes and values that lead to harm and destruction, such as militarism, racism, sexism, xenophobia and homophobia.
Instead, Campaign Nonviolence rallies hundreds of groups and organizations who use nonviolent action and promote nonviolent solutions. Sandy Hook Promise trains thousands of schoolchildren in how to counter social isolation — a factor in mass shootings — with Start With Hello Week. The Nobel Prize-winning International Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons coordinates hundreds of actions to move money out of nukes. The Global Silent Minute synchronizes thousands of people for a moment of prayerful silence for peace on the International Day of Peace, Sept 21. Nonviolent Peaceforce and Cure Violence use de-escalation techniques in conflict zones worldwide to prevent attacks.
Local community groups take powerful action in their neighborhoods. Nonviolent Opelika, Alabama, (part of the nationwide Nonviolent Cities Project) offers trainings and talks on their neighborhood patrols to prevent gun violence. Groups in Honolulu reaffirm their Zone of Peace and Nonviolence in a low-income public housing complex. An elementary school in Little Rock, Arkansas, holds a peace march with all the children. In Detroit, Meta Peace Team trains an entire high school in de-escalation skills.
There are street theater protests at military bases and teach-ins on nonviolent history, such as M.K. Gandhi or Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers. There are peace art contests and concerts in public parks. There are marches for ceasefires in Gaza and Ukraine. There are actions to stop environmental destruction and the climate crisis.
Campaign Nonviolence is gearing up for its largest-ever Action Days stretching between the International Day of Peace Sept 21 to the International Day of Nonviolence on Oct 2. In 2023, more than 5,000 actions were held. With weeks to go, there are already 4,438 actions planned for 2024, and hundreds more expected to be added. The campaign calls for a range of nonviolent actions to be used during the 12 days, including labor strike solidarity, divestment from fossil fuels and weapons, racial healing circles, nonviolence teach-ins, peace demonstrations, and violence de-escalation trainings.
When the violence of our world weighs on your heart, connect to the people working to change it. They bring practical solutions and real-life experience. They persist in showing that something else is possible. They invite you to be part of the solution.
Rivera Sun has written numerous books. She is the editor of Nonviolence News, program coordinator for Campaign Nonviolence, and a nationwide trainer in strategy for nonviolent campaigns.

title: Israeli Jews safety depends on Palestinians' safety
author: SARENA NEYMAN
content:
Israeli Jews safety depends on Palestinians' safety

 September 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SARENA NEYMAN | Section: Columns 
 
 818
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we enter the 10 days between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur — a time meant for reflecting on where we've strayed from compassion — I keep returning to the dehumanization of Palestinians I've witnessed among the observant Jewish community I grew up in.Over the years, I have spoken out against Israel's assault on Gaza and have been accused of spewing "ignorant, pathetic Al Jazeera-fueled antisemitic rhetoric." "You will not be admired for your performative moral integrity," they admonish. My critics are often otherwise compassionate people, yet their support for the Israeli army remains unwavering.
My devotion to Israel was once as absolute as theirs. My parents — both Holocaust survivors — loved Israel second only to their children. They sent me to Zionist schools and summer camps; I grew up immersed in Hebrew music and literature. To me, Israel was not just a country; it was our shield against another Holocaust.
Only later did I learn about the forced expulsions of Palestinians and how the Israeli army — which I had been taught was the most moral in the world — had armed death squads in Africa and Latin America. My Israeli cousin trained troops for Idi Amin, whose regime slaughtered half a million Ugandans. When I asked my mother how Israel could have done this, she said everyone hated us, so we took our support where we could get it.
Her words rattled me. How could this survivor of five concentration camps, who rebuilt her life as a beloved pediatrician, embrace a moral exceptionalism that excused Israel for abetting genocide?
Over time I came to see her response as born of unspeakable trauma. The Nazis had torn her baby sister from her arms. She had been beaten and starved and witnessed death on a daily basis. Centuries of persecution embeds a fierce tribalism: Protect your own at all costs. But as Rabbi Daniel Bogard points out, "Trauma does not give us moral clarity. It just makes us traumatized." And trauma, left unhealed, breeds more trauma.
Hamas's attack on Oct. 7 reawakened Jews' deepest wound — our ancestral fear of extermination. The Israeli government seized on this to justify a campaign of annihilation: deliberately starving and attacking civilians, restricting humanitarian aid, bombing hospitals and schools.
Even as Israel escalates its Gaza assault, defenders minimize these horrors. Despite Israeli media restrictions and unprecedented journalist deaths, the emerging evidence looks nothing like self-defense. But when dozens of human rights groups call it genocide, the messengers are discredited to deny the message. "How naive you are," comes the refrain. "Don't you understand these groups hates us?"
The ease with which my own people excuse these atrocities is chilling.
"I'm watching something that is so evidently horrific and inhumane," Jon Stewart shared on The Daily Show. Yet when he condemns these actions, he is warned that speaking out threatens Israel's survival, even though it is Israel's actions, not Jewish dissent, that endanger the country most.
And he's right. Studies show Israeli violence fuels antisemitism, which then "justifies" more militarization, creating an endless, deadly spiral that both brutalizes Palestinians and endangers Jews everywhere. Furthermore, adds Jewish Currents publisher Daniel May, the argument that Jews are "at risk no matter where they live and no matter what they do or say," distracts us from addressing the conditions that actually drive anti-Israel violence.
Among my detractors, acknowledging this context is taboo. Mention decades of occupation, and you're accused of excusing the horrific kidnappings and murders of Oct. 7.
I believe Israel has a right to exist, but survival built on another people's suffering isn't survival — it's moral collapse that sows the seeds of our own undoing. I understand that tribalism served an evolutionary purpose, forging loyalty in times of threat. But when it hardens into a moral blind spot, it justifies cruelty and brands truth-telling as betrayal.
As Israel edges toward near-total obliteration of Gaza, we must confront the trauma-fueled myth of victimhood. Backed by billions in U.S. aid, Israel is no longer David. It has become Goliath. But Goliath's strength is also his weakness; brute force creates more enemies than it destroys.
Yet the community in which I grew up still clings to the fantasy that Israel can eradicate Hamas through its military might. In fact, the opposite is true. As journalist Peter Beinart warns, our destinies are intertwined: "If you want Israeli Jews to be safe, Palestinians also have to be safe. And Palestinians cannot be safe unless they are free."
This means abandoning the dehumanizing narrative that Palestinians are terrorist monsters who use children as human shields. Because only by cultivating genuine empathy — by recognizing Palestinians as people just like us, who want safety and dignity for their families — can we break this cycle of trauma. The choice before us is stark: Continue down this path of moral blindness that endangers both peoples, or find the courage to imagine a different story — one where Jewish safety doesn't require Palestinian extinction.

 Broadcasting out of Kent County High School in Worton, 90.5 WKHS radio celebrated TuneFest, the station's 50th anniversary, on Saturday, May 9. next door at Red Acres Hydroponics farm.Station manager and Career and Technical Education Instructor Chris Singleton received gratitude as well as a golden microphone trophy as he recalled his start in 2008.
Singleton had a lot of people to thank, and made sure he got as many KCHS staff, programmers, students, and others as he could.
Going down the line, Singleton mentioned how each was instrumental in the journey to make WKHS the influence it is today — one of the most powerful high school stations in the country.
At 17,500 watts with flat terrain all around, their signal can be heard up to 60 miles in any direction.
Plaques were presented to outgoing Superintendent Karen Couch and former Station Managers Steve Kramarck, Rob Futterman, Karyn O'Brien, Ted Dively, June Fox, Keith Hill, Walt Barcus and the "godfather," inaugural WKHS station manager Jim Hammond.
Hammond reflected. "The very first song we played, March 28, 1974, was "Rocket Man." Part of that was when I was on the air, you never used your real name. I was 'Captain Space' because I played progressive rock."
While they talked, food vendors served and in between the rainfall people jetted out to grab a carbonated beverage and some food then hurried back for the live music.
"It wouldn't be a radio celebration without music, right. So we've assembled a great variety," Singleton told the crowd.
LOCAL TALENT
Sombarkin' played blues and some toe-tapping gospel. Justin Singleton and the Shorebillies performed soulful country-style songs with original lyrics. Philip Dutton and the Alligators rocked out Louisiana-style, and the Blake Thompson Band performed later that day with some classic rock/blues/folk music.
On the smaller stage, Maryland Delegate Jay Jacobs presented Singleton a citation of recognition.
The station also received a certificate of recognition in March from the Kent County Commissioners.
While the crowd mingled, Singleton's junior students, the class of 2025, took the sound coming from the stage and broadcasted it out for those who couldn't make it that day.
The "on-air" on the barn wall above the bands wasn't just for decoration.
Singleton was appreciative of the community support.
"It's pretty amazing. Everybody coming together from all walks of life today, celebrating for a common cause. We're the only high school radio station in Maryland and still going strong."
You can discover Singleton and his crew's work on the radio dial at 90.5.

author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: Business

 Words

 Inflation was up 3.2% in February compared to a year ago with higher prices for housing, car insurance, dining and items such as beer, baby formula, sew machines and fabric.Prices for consumer goods, items such as insurance and staples including food and housing are up 20% from before the COVID pandemic and its shutdowns and massive spending and monetary measures.
U.S. prices are up 18.6% since January 2021 when President Joe Biden took office.
The Consumer Price Index for February shows higher prices across the U.S. as voters continue to have consternation over their personal finances and the economy.
Housing helped drive the overall 3.2% CPI inflation rate with a 5.7% increase in costs from Feb. 2023.
Rents are up 5.8% as affordable housing continues to be a problem for many households across the country.
Higher prices are also showing up in spending areas across the economy creating reelection challenges for Biden in his rematch with former president Donald Trump.
Car insurance rates are up a whopping 20.6% compared a year ago, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Prices for food at restaurants are up 4.5% with the industry facing continued labor shortages, higher prices for food, alcoholic beverages and equipment and increased financing costs and debt loads stemming from Federal Reserve interest rate hikes to tackle inflation.
Baby formula and baby food have jumped 8.8%.
Tuition for day care and preschools are 5.5% more expansive than 12 months ago.
Sewing machines are fabric prices have increased 11% since last February. Those increase have been seen with patterns, equipment and fabric and comes as JoAnn's Fabric, a major retailer in the space, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Tax service providers have hiked their prices by 9.8% over the past year.
Cameras and photo equipment are 9% more expensive
Beer prices are up 4.1%.The beer market has seen some upheavals with the higher prices impacting consumer decisions and the growth in popularity of brands such as Yuengling and Modelo.
Bud Light is still the top U.S. beer brand but was its popularity negatively impacted after a social media ad featuring transgender influencer Dylan Mulvaney and an Anheuser-Busch marketing executive deriding the brand's customer base as 'too fratty.'
Higher grocery prices have eased some from their inflation wave highs but are still up 2.2% from a year ago. Smartphone prices are down 10.5% from a year ago, according to BLS.
Public opinion polls show voters rank inflation and the economy among their top concerns. That comes despite Biden, Democrats and media acolytes touting some strong macro-economic figures.
U.S. prices rose 7.7% during Trump's term in office (2017-2021), according to BLS.

title: Oxford tables plastic bag ban ordinance
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford tables plastic bag ban ordinance

 August 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Following a nearly 30-minute public hearing, the Commissioners of Oxford tabled an ordinance that would ban retail establishments in town from giving out single-use, disposable plastic bags.At a town meeting on Aug. 27, Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said the ban would apply to retail establishments including grocery stores, convenience stores, shops, department stores and service stations. The ordinance would not apply to restaurants and food service establishments.
Ryan said while the ordinance would apply to the Oxford Market, it would not apply to the deli within the market.
"So the sandwiches, subs, things like that that would be wrapped in plastic would continue to be in plastic," she said.
During the public hearing, some local business owners and employees expressed their concerns with the proposed ordinance. Graham Norbury, the general manager at Safe Harbor Oxford, said that while this may be a national issue, he doesn't observe plastic bags being littered often in Oxford.
"Why is restricting a retailer's right to choose the best delivery mechanism for their products, why is that something that the commissioners feel necessary?" he asked.
Oxford Vintage & Trade owner Barbara Ranson said in her six years of being in business in Oxford, she has always used paper bags. She said she doesn't understand why the commissioners are looking at this legislation when "it may or may not target three very small businesses."
"So it seems to me (like) legislation looking for a problem, and I don't understand why we would spend one minute on this," she said, receiving some applause from residents in the audience.
Ranson also brought up a part of the ordinance that would require retail establishments to charge a 10 cent fee — which the retail establishment would keep — for each paper bag it hands out to customers. She said that having to charge and keep track of that would take up time and labor and would just be another thing that the town needs to enforce.
"And who's going to do that?" she asked. "Because we already have ordinances that are not enforced because we don't have anybody to do them."
Resident David Donovan, who is in support of the ordinance, acknowledged that it won't solve the global problem.
"But if every one of us in every little town stands up and does their share, you do solve a problem," he said.
Resident Rose Donovan said she considers this to be a "common sense ordinance." She said this is a way to stop using plastic bags "where we can."
Commissioner Katrina Greer said she feels passionately about banning plastic, but Oxford is facing a lot of other important issues right now.
"So I would like to find a way forward with this. But perhaps just not now," she said, adding that there is more commissioners should consider regarding the ordinance.
Before the commissioners voted unanimously to table the ordinance, Ryan brought up the idea of giving retail establishments an incentive to not use plastic bags, rather than banning them. She said the commissioners could consider a tax incentive, among other possible incentives.
Commission President Norm Bell said they should bring all of these ideas to the table before they make a decision.

title: History is filled with many 'what if' questions
author: DAVID REEL
content:
History is filled with many 'what if' questions

 July 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who study history regularly ask the question — what if? What if certain watershed events in American history had never occurred or had occurred much differently?One such watershed event was the war in Vietnam.
Historians to this day ask what if decisions made on escalating or de-escalating that war had been made by President John Kennedy and not by President Lyndon Johnson.
Military historian Fred Kaplan makes a compelling case that if Kennedy had not been assassinated in November 1963, the outcome and duration of that war would have been much different.
Kaplan makes his case based on Kennedy's actions and decisions during the biggest crisis of his presidency — the Cuban Missile Crisis.
Prior to that crisis, Kennedy's leadership capabilities were challenged regularly by his opponents. They were especially scornful of his disastrous Bay of Pig's invasion of Cuba in April 1961 and his disastrous summit meeting with Russian Premier Nikita Khrushchev in June 1961. Following that summit Kennedy privately acknowledged "he just beat the hell out of me."
Perhaps those two events emboldened Khrushchev to place Soviet medium- and long-range nuclear missiles in Cuba in October 1962.
That decision resulted a 13-day period where World War III between America and the Soviet Union was more likely than ever before or since.
The fact that it did not is a testament to Kennedy's masterful leadership skills.
When Kennedy was made aware of that grave threat to from nuclear missiles less than 90 miles from America, he assembled a group of civilian and military advisors to evaluate and oversee an appropriate American response.
Those advisers included the eight members of the military's Joint Chiefs of Staff, National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy, Defense Secretary Robert McNamara, Secretary of State Dean Rusk, Undersecretary of State George Ball and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.
With one exception (George Ball), Kennedy's advisers strongly supported direct military action including bombing the missile sites and invading Cuba.
After 13 days of a tense standoff between the two superpowers, Khrushchev secretly and unexpectedly offered a deal to end the crisis. The deal terms were Russia would remove their nuclear missiles in Cuba that were pointed at American targets if America would remove American nuclear missiles in Turkey pointed at targets in the Soviet Union
Kennedy's advisers with one exception (Ball) vehemently opposed the deal. They continued to support plans drawn up by the military and Defense Secretary McNamara that called for 500 conventional bombing sorties of the Soviet missile sites and air bases daily for seven days, followed by an invasion of Cuba.
Following receipt of the Khrushchev offer McGeorge Bundy bluntly told Kennedy — "I think we should tell you … the universal assessment of everyone in the government who's connected with the alliance problem (NATO) is if we appear to be trading the defense of Turkey for the threat in Cuba, we will face a radical decline." Secretary McNamara ended his review of suggested next steps with "before we attack Cuba."
After listening to his adviser's opinions Kennedy, told them "I'm just thinking about what we're going to have to do in a day or so. … Five hundred sorties … and possibly an invasion, all because we wouldn't take missiles out of Turkey. And we all know how quickly everybody's courage goes when the blood starts to flow, and that's what's going to happen in NATO … when we start these things and the Soviets grab Berlin, and everybody's going to say, 'Well, this Khrushchev offer was a pretty good proposition."
Kennedy knew that the American missiles in Turkey were rapidly becoming obsolete and had no long-term military value to America.
He told his advisers calmly but resolutely he was sending his brother Bobby (who bitterly opposed the deal) to tell the Soviet ambassador to the United States that America was accepting the Khrushchev proposal.
It was a moment reminiscent of a Cabinet Meeting in the White House 100 years earlier when President Lincoln polled his cabinet members on his proposed new battle strategy for the Civil war. Every member of Lincoln's Cabinet voted no. Lincoln said "I vote aye. The ayes win."
Kennedy obviously knew that as commander in chief he could overrule his advisers when he chose to do so.
Following Kennedys assassination, Lyndon Johnson was either unwilling or unable to overrule his advisers on their repeated calls to escalate the war in Vietnam. Ironically, many of those advisers (except again George Ball) repeatedly advised Johnson for escalation in Vietnam were the same advisers overruled by Kennedy during the Cuban missile crisis.
Kaplan's answer to the "what if" question on the course of Vietnam war is LBJ plunged deeply into the war and JFK would not have.
Based on Kaplan's analysis of what if JFK had lived, America would have avoided the great tragedy of a futile and immensely divisive war that resulted in more than 58,000 American deaths and countless veterans returning home with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
I agree.
David Reel is a public relations and public affairs consultant who lives in Easton.

 CHESTERTOWN — The Kent County commissioners talked about not "releasing the hounds," but gave consideration to licensing their kennel, at their regularly scheduled meeting on June 24.Due to recent legislative changes, the commissioners now sit as the Fox Hunting Club Dog Kennel Licensing board.
Their first applicant was The Wicomico Hunt Club, a club in existence since the 1920s, seeking to preserve a rich history of safely hunting red foxes on horseback with hounds along fields, forest and wetlands beside rivers and tributaries of the Bay.
Approval of the application would enable the club to build the kennel for the hounds on the 20 acre Worton farm that until recently, was prohibited from housing more than five dogs since it is located in a Resource Conservation District.
Director of Planning, Housing and Zoning Bill Mackey explained that last year the club sought to change that law with an application for a text amendment.
Attorney Genevieve Macfarlane acting as counsel to the club, said the text amendment sought to create a definition for kennels specific to organized fox hunting clubs, and to amend the Zoning Ordinance to permit such kennels within the RCD zone.
However, while in that process, during a meeting with the Planning Commission, some public outcry arose concerning potential noise and safety issues over the hounds. The planning staff then recommended the commissioners hold certain licensing requirements to protect both the club and the public.
This past year, the hunt club has worked with the County to address those concerns and a text amendment was approved to allow hounds in the RCD zone on the condition a Fox Hunting Kennel Licensing Board and licensing scheme be put in place.
The county commissioners act as the oversight board and are responsible for implementing a regulatory framework specific to the licensing of such facilities.
"We've been called worse than that," Commission President Ron Fithian quipped when they were deemed the Fox Hunting Club Dog Kennel Licensing Board.
At the June 24 meeting, Deputy Director of Planning, Housing and Zoning Carla Gerber submitted the club's application for a kennel license as well as permission to build a temporary kennel to house 30 fox hunting hounds at Worton.
Gerber said the application met all the requirements as outlined in the new chapter 64 under Animals, article 62.
At these proceedings, Club Huntsman Eden Kloetzli was accompanied by supporters of the club, Attorney Genevieve Macfarlane lending counsel, Master of Fox Hounds Ed Fry, and member Dan O'Toole. Together they responded to concerns about potential noise and safety issues.
O' Toole, huntsman with Mount Carmel Hounds, stated he has been housing hounds on his Baltimore County property for 65 years. Although the area is far less rural than Kent, he has not had any issues so far. It relies on good communication with neighbors.
O' Toole has been helping design the club's kennel and suggested using mass-loaded vinyl on the fencing for effective sound proofing.
Kloetzli added that elevation changes on the property, the surrounding woods, the acoustic panelling on the fence and the natural isolation of the area, will help cut down on noise. They plan on growing a sound barrier with cedar trees as well.
Kloetzli assured them that the previous property owners of the farm had a working septic system used for cattle which would suit their purposes. Waste gets pumped out and disposed of properly and there will be no smell since they sanitize everyday.
Previously the hounds were housed at Tolchester and although challenging, Kloetzli learned from that experience, O'Toole pointed out.
Kloetzli said if the hounds are limited to what they see, they will be happy and not prone to bark as much.
Since many of these regulations are similar to the requirements they adhere to in Baltimore County, O'Toole applauded the County's process.
The club is the only recognized one on the Eastern Shore, Fry said, one of 142 clubs around the country. They adhere to Master Fox Hounds Association where they follow a strict code of how operations are run, the sanitary condition of the kennels and updated vaccinations.
The hounds all have their shots and are microchipped and soon will be wearing identifiable collars, Kloetzli pointed out.
Commission President Ron Fithian stated being a board member for dog kennel licensing is a new experience for them but by being so, if any complaints arise, they now have a system to address it.
With no voiced opposition to building the kennels during the hearing, Commissioner John Price moved to close it out. The application will be considered for a vote on July 8.
The club is cherished by many on the Eastern Shore and today, is the only remaining hunt sanctioned by the Masters of Foxhounds Association on the Delmarva Peninsula.
