title: QA’s, Easton hoping for a Shore thing
author: Bill Haufe
content:
QA’s, Easton hoping for a Shore thing

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 841
 Words 

 Read News Document

 They battled each other in one of the season's more memorable duels, playing 80 scoreless minutes before settling things in 1v1s.That was Oct. 1, when Queen Anne's County High's field hockey team outlasted Easton in a shootout, part of a 14-game Lions' unbeaten streak.
The Warriors have not lost since that clash, reeling off eight straight victories.
Wednesday, 36 days later after that marathon, Queen Anne's and Easton prepare to play in the Class 2A state semifinals at Glen Burnie High School, not against each other, but hoping to possibly create the first all-Eastern Shore state final since 1997.
"How great would it be?" Queen Anne's longtime head coach Shana Corder asked rhetorically. "I am rooting for Easton and Queen Anne's to win this one. I think that would be an awesome setup."
Warrior head coach Kim Neff seconded that notion.
"That would be so wild," Neff said of an all-Shore final that hasn't happened since Pocomoke defeated Kent County in the 1997 Class 1A championship. "That would be so cool."
Of course, Corder and Neff each know that dream match doesn't happen unless their respective teams get past a pair of unbeatens tonight.
Third-seeded Queen Anne's (13-1-1) goes first, when it plays three-time defending state champion and No. 2 seed Glenelg (15-0) at 5:30 p.m. Fourth-seeded Easton (12-3) follows in a meeting with No. 1 seed Manchester Valley (15-0) at 7:30 p.m.
"OK. So we're not undefeated," Corder said. "We're the underdog."
The Lions may have thought they would be wearing that underdog tag through at least part of this season after graduating a number of standouts off last year's 15-1 team that posted 14 shutouts and reached the state semifinals. Corder honestly thought this would be a rebuild season, since the entire defense from a year ago — with the exception of goalie Cassidy Alexander — was gone.
But after a season-opening loss at Pocomoke, Corder changed her position.
"I think they felt, 'Oh, we're not going to be as good,'" Corder said. "'We are not as good as this team.' But I was like, 'We are as good. You can't set yourself up to think you're a failure.' I think losing that game was the best blessing we've gotten all year.
"I saw their faces and they weren't used to losing, all my returners," Corder continued. "And I felt like they didn't like to lose. So I thought that gave them the drive to want to win. I felt that was our turning point."
Since then the Lions, behind their one-two goalie punch of Caroline Kimball and Alexander, and a rebuilt defense, have gone unbeaten, which included winning their second straight Bayside Conference and regional championships — a first in program history — and recording 11 shutouts.
"I feel every team we play has given us their best game because we did so well (last year)," Corder said. "They understand pressure. They've been here before. All the returners know what this feels like. Hopefully they already felt the pressure. We've had 1v1 games, overtime, blah, blah, blah. I'm just hoping they are able to rise to the occasion Wednesday."
Though Easton didn't have a 2023 season that compared to Queen Anne's, Neff was filled with optimism at the outset of this season.
"I knew we were capable of getting this far," Neff said. "A lot of these girls I've coached since they were in kindergarten, and I know their potential. It was the most athletic group that I have seen (during preseason tryouts). I think them playing some travel ball together and being on rec teams together, they know each other well, which helps."
But Easton's record was sitting at 4-3 after the 1v1 loss to Queen Anne's. The Warriors moved to 5-3 with a shutout of Kent County.
Then came a 3-2 overtime victory over Pocomoke.
"We have a long history with Pocomoke," Neff said. "And Pocomoke tends to get the victories. So I think that game, and going into overtime, and doing what they did really solidified them. Like I knew and I had the confidence in them. But I think it solidified the confidence in them, like, 'We can do this.'"
Since that victory, Easton has defeated perennial Bayside heavyweight Kent Island 1-0 in overtime. The Warriors defeated Parkside 2-1 in overtime in a 2A East Region II semifinal, then beat Stephen Decatur 2-1 with 11 seconds remaining in regulation in the region final. Easton continued its trend for the dramatic last Thursday, defeating Hereford in a 1v1 in a state quarterfinal, placing the Warriors in the state semifinals for the first time since 2021.
"I told them, 'You've earned your spot there,'" Neff said. "'We're all good teams. We made it to the top four. We're not looking at records because every day's a clean slate for every team. We haven't seen them (Manchester Valley). They haven't seen us. And so we're going in and we're playing our game. They're ready."
Notes: Wednesday's winners will meet for the state final on Saturday at Stevenson University at 11 a.m.. … Third-seeded Pocomoke plays No. 2 seed Fallston Wednesday in a 1A state semifinal at Crofton High.

title: Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery decked out with flag display to honor soldiers
author: Konner Metz
content:
Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery decked out with flag display to honor soldiers

 May 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HURLOCK — Around 100 volunteers placed thousands of flags on graves at the Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery Saturday morning just outside Hurlock.When the gates opened at 8 a.m., volunteers made quick work of the flag display, cemetery Superintendent Dean Arcoraci said. American flags whipped in the wind along with many Military Order of the Purple Heart flags honoring those killed or wounded in action.
"There's a lot of tradition here," Arcoraci said of the annual flag display.
The Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery is one of five official veterans cemeteries in the state and the only one on the Eastern Shore. Arcoraci noted it was the first ever Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families cemetery, opening in 1976.
Civil War veteran John Henry Blades was the first person to be buried at the cemetery. Today, there are around 8,000 burials and there's room for thousands more, Arcoraci said. He said the state also recently relaxed its residency requirements, allowing some families from nearby Delaware to place veterans at the Hurlock cemetery.
The cemetery features a unique design, with the burial sites forming curves facing the American flag in the middle of the cemetery.
Once the flags were placed, Mary Alice Jones and her son Bill Jones took some time to visit the graves of relatives, including Korean War U.S. Army veteran Joseph Horenstein.
Mary Alice Jones said it's important to remember and honor veterans no matter the time of year.
While Memorial Day was widely celebrated Monday, the Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery commemorates Memorial Day later this week with an annual program.
At 1:30 p.m. Friday, the cemetery will host a Memorial Day program open to the public. It will include remarks from American Legion members and guest speaker Ross Cohen, acting secretary of the Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families.
Memorial Day was originally observed on May 30 in the years after the Civil War. That tradition continued through much of the 20th century before a federal act moved it to the last Monday in May.
Arcoraci said the cemetery and its committee continues the May 30 program because of tradition. "I'm expecting quite a crowd," he added.
The Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery partners with a number of local veteran groups and organizations, including local American Legions.
"This cemetery's about community involvement," he said.
The Eastern Shore Veterans Cemetery is located at 6827 E New Market Ellwood Road, Hurlock, MD, 21643.

title: Ghrist sponsors DAF storage bill
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Ghrist sponsors DAF storage bill

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State Del. Jeff Ghrist introduced legislation Feb. 9 aimed at giving local jurisdictions the authority to regulate the storage of dissolved air flotation by-products, otherwise known as DAF residuals."I want to make sure that the local governing bodies can do that on their own without any ambiguity, because small counties like Caroline … can't afford to be sued," Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said in a Feb. 21 interview.
House Bill 1404 was co-sponsored by Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) and Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) as well as two Cecil County legislators and three from the western shore. It is cross-filed with Senate Bill 1149, sponsored by Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Ghrist's bill addresses an issue the Caroline County Commissioners have been dealing with in their legislation process since mid-December. He said he discussed the DAF storage issue with the commissioners, the Eastern Shore delegation and the Maryland Farm Bureau.
Neither the state's Department of the Environment nor the Department of Agriculture have jurisdiction over regulating or controlling the storage of DAF residuals, "and so we have at least one person taking advantage of that loophole in the law," he said.
"Whether or not (Love's bill) removes any ambiguity (regarding) how much control the county commissioners have in storage, that remains to be seen," Ghrist said. "But I just want to make sure that after this legislation is passed that one, it goes far enough to ensure that we're not going to have DAF being stored anywhere near our towns, and two, if it doesn't go far enough, I want to make sure that the local governing bodies can (restrict it) on their own, without any ambiguity."
Ghrist said he wanted to make sure that the case would have no standing in court if "anybody decided to sue the county."
The bill is "just a placeholder," Ghrist said. If a separate bill, HB991 sponsored by Del. Sara Love (D-Montgomery) addresses the DAF storage issue and is passed, Ghrist said he may consider withdrawing his.
If enacted, HB991 would establish an industrial sludge utilization permit administered and enforced by the Department of the Environment.
Ghrist's bill will be considered 1 p.m. March 8 by the Environment and Transportation Committee.
Love's bill will go to the same committee 1 p.m. March 5.

title: When life gives you tomatoes
content:
When life gives you tomatoes

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A11 | Section: News

 Too many tomatoes are never a problem. Perhaps the only challenge is maintaining self-control when passing the colorful piles of peak-season tomatoes at the market.Admittedly, they are hard to resist. Cherries, heirlooms and Early Girls in vibrant shades of the sun and summer challenge restraint. It's easy to be greedy and fill the basket with an array of these beauties without a plan for how to use them. While I am not here to judge or to advise you on any indulgence issues, I do have a recipe to help you use your exuberant surplus.This recipe is a wonderful summer salad with ingredients that scream "garden-fresh." You might be tempted to call it a pasta salad, but as you can see, the emphasis is on the vegetables rather than a carbladen bowl of pasta interspersed with a few green leaves. Dainty orzo steps into the pasta role. Its petite rice shape won't overwhelm the bowl, allowing the tomatoes and greens to shine as they should. Fresh, creamy mozzarella and zippy Parmigiano-Reggiano round out the flavors, with a balsamic drizzle that binds the salad with a sweet and puckery kick.Serve the salad slightly warm or at room temperature.You can cook the orzo in advance and refrigerate until assembling the salad.TOMATO, ARUGULA AND ORZO SALADActive time: 20 minutes Total time: 20 minutes, plus cooling time for the orzo Yield: Serves 4 Dressing:2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar 1 garlic clove, minced 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil Salad:1 1/3 cups orzo 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 3 ounces baby arugula, about 4 packed cups 6 ounces fresh mozzarella, cut or torn into bite-size pieces 8 to 10 ounces cherry tomatoes, halved 1/4 cup pitted Kalamata olives, halved 1/4 cup fresh basil leaves, plus more for garnish 2 tablespoons finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese Freshly ground black pepper Whisk the vinegar, garlic, salt and pepper in a small bowl. Add the oil and whisk to emulsify.Bring a large saucepan of salted water to a boil. Add the orzo and cook until al dente, about 7 minutes.Drain. Transfer the orzo to a large, shallow serving bowl and stir in the oil and salt.Cool to lukewarm or room temperature. (Alternatively, refrigerate the pasta until use. Let stand at room temperature for 15 to 20 minutes before assembling the salad.)Spread the arugula over the pasta, then add the mozzarella, tomatoes, olives and basil. Drizzle half of the dressing over the salad and gently mix to combine. Garnish with additional basil, the Parmigiano-Reggiano and a generous grind of black pepper. Drizzle with additional dressing to taste. Serve immediately.Lynda Balslev is an award-winning writer, cookbook author, and recipe developer based in northern California.Visit TasteFood at Taste-Foodblog.com.© 2023 LYN DA BALSLEV DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION

Gunsallus leading in race for town council president

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones And Tom Mccall; njones@chespub.com and tmccall@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News

 EASTON - After a steady stream of voting Tuesday, Frank Gunsallus was leading in the race for the Easton Town Council's next president.According to election supervisor Carlene Phoenix, Gunsallus had earned 835 votes at the close of polls Tuesday evening.Former Easton Mayor Robert Willey received 696 votes, and former Ward 1 Councilman Al Silverstein received 348 votes. Kevin Bateman received 30 votes.Phoenix said 140 absentee ballots remain to be counted Wednesday afternoon. Gunsallus holds a 139-vote lead over Willey.A steady flow of voters poured into Easton's firehouse Tuesday as residents cast their ballots for the next president of the Town Council. Just over 1,900 ballots were cast during in-person voting.Early in the morning, candidates for Easton Town Council president stood beneath tents as a stream of voters passed them by. There wasn't a hard sell, it was more of a morning greeting as the light slanted onto the firehouse. Voters went in and did their civic duty. There weren't big lines at 9 a.m.Turnout at the polls was busy and steady as election day progressed, Phoenix said.But in this contentious election cycle, agitation simmered just beneath the surface between some of the candidates.Al Silverstein sat alone while the other three - Frank Gunsallus, Kevin Bateman, and former Mayor Robert Willey - spoke amiably. There was even a minor turf war when Gunsallus placed a sign too close to Silverstein's camp. Within seconds it got moved back and replanted.Willey, a former town council president and mayor himself, has been running for office in Easton since 1992. He brought doughnuts.As a longtime local politician, Willey knew there would be a lot to do early on election morning. He knew the day would be long as well, especially in waiting on a vote tally."But this election has gotten to be a little more demanding than some in the past," he said. "I hope (when) it is over with everybody (can) still talk to each other when they leave." "This is my 10th election," he said. "This has become the most pointed, the most mean-spirited. I would not want to go through this again." Willey said win or lose, this was his last run.Leaning on a tent pole was Bateman."It is a relief to have election day here, especially after the last two weeks. All the hate mailers and hate speech have gone forth," he said."I want to see that Easton is governed equally for all of Easton - not just certain communities, but that all communities are included." Gunsallus said he was feeling good about the election, mentioning that he heard positive feedback from the community."I am thankful to everyone who has shown support and for all the amazing people I have met along the way," he said. "Irregardless of what happens, I am happy to have had this experience." Silverstein stood up to greet each voter as they passed. Some stopped to voice their support.A former councilman serving Easton's Ward 1, Silverstein said it's exciting to be outside the polls on election day and to thank the electorate for coming out."I would encourage anybody who wants to change their community for the better to throw their hat in the ring," he said. "I congratulate all my opponents for getting out there and getting their positions known. I think it is the greatest part of the American system." One community member, Shari Wilcoxon, was fired up enough to hold a Gunsallus sign in front of her car."What happens in the Town of Easton matters greatly to Talbot County," she said. "I think it is time for some new leadership." Carol Voyles of Easton was happy to vote and do her civic duty."It troubles me that our communities are so divided," she said. "When it is over, we are going to celebrate."

Public hearing closes for development proposal at former Safeway

 EASTON — A public hearing for a proposed 33-unit housing development at the site of the former Safeway closed during Monday's Town Council meeting. Despite mixed public reactions at past town meetings, no members of the public spoke Monday evening.The proposal comes from Lane Engineering on behalf of NAI Saturn Eastern and Safeway, along with Miller Development Corporation, the potential developers of the project. It includes 24 partially-connected townhomes and nine standalone units. The property, which has been vacant since 2017, sits at 139 N Washington St.
Council members mentioned discussions with developers about a per-unit contribution to the town's affordable housing efforts. Ward 1 Council Member Maureen Curry said it's her "understanding that the developer has agreed" to those contributions.
"We discussed the possibility of a $10,000 per-unit support of the affordable housing fund," Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello said, "with $5,000 coming at the building permit stage and $5,000 at the moment of getting the permit of occupancy."
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh said she will work with Ryan Showalter, an attorney representing Miller Development Corporation, in the lead up to the next town meeting Aug. 19 so that a potential vote on the proposal comes to the council.
FIRE DEPARTMENTSonny Jones, chief of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, presented a report to the Town Council on Monday detailing the station's activity through the month of July.
As of July 31, the department has responded to 540 fire or rescue incidents this year, 255 of which came in the months of May, June and July, Jones said.
"I really want to point out that this is an all-volunteer organization, and as of July 31, our members have spent 8,515.07 hours in service to the community," Jones told the council. "And I'm very, very proud of all the men and women who do that."
Jones pointed out that Mondays around 3 p.m. tend to be the department's busiest time. He also said there's been a decrease in the number of false alarms.
"(Ward 2 Council Member Don) Abbatiello has assisted us with that in taking great strides to try to reduce the amount of false alarms," Jones said. "We have done some outreach to businesses which were problematic, and encouraged them to have a system to maintain."
Jones also said the fire department has raised $3.2 million to date for a training facility project that has been in the works. He said a construction contract was awarded to Willow Construction.
The new training facility, which will be located at 9095 Mistletoe Drive in Easton, will be a hub for all volunteer firefighters across the Mid-Shore region who are looking for specialized education.
"This is an exciting project for us," Jones said. "It's the first of its kind in the area … And we're going to see some significant start in September for the building of that."

title: Country Cooking: Shrimp, an Eastern Shore tradition
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Shrimp, an Eastern Shore tradition

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Growing up on the farm, surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean and Chesapeake Bay as well as the many rivers, we ate many types of seafood, but shrimp was not my favorite dish.Shrimp has a long history in the Delmarva region, particularly in the Chesapeake Bay and its estuaries. While not typically fished with a large-scale commercial harvest due to gear restrictions like the beam trawl ban, shrimp populations have been present and studied for decades. Recent observations suggest increasing shrimp populations in the area, possibly due to factors like warming waters.
Shrimp have always been found around the Chesapeake Bay, which is replete with the marshy, muddy habitat they love. Shrimp like to bury in sediment and can be found in both the Bay and its river estuaries, from shallow to deep water. Around the last week of October each year, a sudden drop in temperature drives the shrimp to funnel out of the Bay and into the southern Atlantic, where the water is a little warmer.
The shrimping industry is most popular in the Gulf states of Louisiana, Alabama, Florida and Texas. In the last five years, shrimp sales volume increased from 275 million pounds to 415 million. The percentage of households buying fish has also increased from 44.2% to 48.6%. This growth is seen in all areas of the country.
Shrimp is an excellent, affordable meal option for families. Shrimp can be enjoyed as an appetizer, snack, main course or side dish. Shrimp is a great addition to many popular favorites as it's easy to toss some shrimp into a creamy pasta or grill up some prawns to top your preferred cut of steak.
In later years, I discovered shrimp and became a "shrimp lover." My parents really didn't care for shrimp, so therefore when I became a cook in my own kitchen, I ventured into exploring many different foods. The same happens generation after generation, introductions to different foods.
JUMBO STEAMED SHRIMP
1/2 cup vinegar, 1 tbsp Old Bay seasoning, 3/4 cup water, 1 tsp salt, 1 1/2 lbs jumbo shrimp.
In a medium sized saucepan combine vinegar, Old Bay, water and salt. Bring these ingredients to a boil. Add shrimp. Stir gently to coat the shrimp in the liquid. Cover and steam for 5 to 6 minutes or until tender. Drain and serve.
SHRIMP AND RICE
1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup chopped onion, 1/4 cup chopped green pepper, 3 tbsps flour, small can tomato sauce, 1 cup water, 1/2 tsp hot sauce, 1 1.2 lbs pre-cooked shrimp, rice.
Melt butter, add onion and green pepper, mix well with the butter. Mix in flour, stirring until bubbly. Add tomato sauce, water and hot sauce. Cook slowly for about 10 minutes. Add shrimp and cook slowly for another 10-15 minutes. Serve over cooked rice.
SHRIMP SCAMPI
1 1/2 cups olive oil, 1/4 cup lemon juice, 4 crushed garlic cloves, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper, 4 lbs raw shrimp (shelled and deveined).
In a large skillet, place olive oil, lemon juice, garlic cloves, salt, and pepper. Heat thoroughly and add shrimp. Stir well and cook until the shrimp are pink. Serve with rice.
SHRIMP STIR FRY
2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 lb shrimp (peeled and deveined), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 small head of broccoli (cut into small florets), 1 red bell pepper (seeds and ribs removed, thinly sliced), 8 oz sugar snap peas, 3 garlic cloves (minced), 1 tbsp finely chopped peeled ginger, 1/2 cup reduced-sodium soy sauce, juice of 1 lime, 2 tbsps light brown sugar, 1 tbsp cornstarch, pinch of crushed red pepper flakes.
In a large wok or skillet over medium heat, heat olive oil. Add shrimp; season with salt and black pepper. Cook, turning halfway through, until pink, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer shrimp to a plate. In the same skillet over medium heat, heat sesame oil. Add broccoli, bell pepper, and peas and cook, stirring and adding a splash of water if browning too quickly, until softened, about 7 minutes. Add garlic and ginger and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute more.In a small bowl, whisk soy sauce, lime juice, brown sugar, cornstarch, and red pepper flakes. Add to the skillet and toss to coat. Add shrimp and cook, tossing frequently, until heated through, about 2 minutes.
OLD BAY SHRIMP BURRITOS
For Old Bay aioli: 1/3 cup mayonnaise, 1 1/2 tsp Sriracha, 3/4 tsp fresh lime juice, 1/2 tsp Old Bay seasoning (plus more for serving), Kosher salt. For shrimp filling: 1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, 1/2 yellow onion (finely chopped), 1 small green bell pepper (diced), 2 cloves garlic (thinly sliced), 1 lb small shrimp (peeled and deveined, tails removed), 1/4 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp paprika, Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper. For assembling burrito: 4 large flour tortillas (warmed), 1 cup cooked long-grain white rice, 1 cup cooked black beans (rinsed and drained), 3/4 cup shredded Mexican cheese, 1 cup shredded lettuce, 1 cup pico de gallo (drained), 1 avocado (thinly sliced), 2 tbsps chopped chives (plus more for serving).
Make aioli: Whisk together mayo, Sriracha, lime juice, Old Bay, and 1 teaspoon water. Season with salt, if desired. Make shrimp filling: In a large skillet over medium-high heat, add oil, onion, bell pepper, and garlic. Cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly golden, about 2 minutes. Stir in shrimp, cumin, and paprika. Season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until opaque and just cooked through, about 4 minutes. Assemble burritos: Lay a tortilla on a serving plate. Add 1/4 cup each of the rice and beans. Top with ¼ each of the shrimp filling, cheese, lettuce, pico de gallo, and avocado slices. Sprinkle with chives and drizzle with aioli. Roll the burrito tightly and repeat with remaining tortillas and ingredients. Slice each burrito in half and serve with more aioli, Old Bay and chives.
SWEET CORN, SHRIMP & RICE SKILLET
1/2 cup basmati rice, 1 bunch scallions (divided), 1 medium red bell pepper (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (5 roughly chopped, 1 minced), 4 tbsps white miso, 1-inch piece ginger (thinly sliced), 1 1/4 tsp turmeric powder (divided), 1 tsp Kosher salt (plus more for seasoning), 1 tsp granulated sugar (optional), 1/4 tsp ground cayenne pepper (optional), 4 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil (divided), 1/2 lb medium shrimp (peeled and cleaned), freshly ground black pepper, 3/4 cup water, 1 cup frozen corn (rinsed in warm water and drained), lime wedges for serving.
Rinse rice well, until water runs clear, then transfer to a medium bowl and cover with water. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Cook 5 roughly chopped garlic cloves and ginger in a pan for around 1 minute. Remove roots and ends from 4 green onions and roughly chop into pieces. Add chopped scallions to blender or food processor, along with the bell pepper, garlic cloves, miso, ginger, 1 teaspoon turmeric, salt, and sugar and cayenne if using. Blend until all ingredients are finely chopped and thoroughly mixed, then slowly drizzle in 3 tablespoons olive oil while running the food processor or blender. Blend until mixture is smooth. Pat shrimp dry and transfer to a medium bowl. Add remaining turmeric and minced garlic clove, and season with salt and pepper. Heat remaining tablespoon of oil in a 12-inch oven safe skillet over medium heat. Add shrimp and cook until opaque, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove cooked shrimp into a bowl just big enough to fit and cover with a plate to keep warm. Return the skillet to heat and add prepared puree. Cook on medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until the liquid has cooked out and paste has darkened, 8 to 10 minutes. (You'll know it's done when the oil starts to separate from the paste! Reduce heat to medium and whisk in water until smooth. Strain rice, and add rice and corn. Drain any cooking juices from the shrimp into the skillet, using the plate to keep the shrimp from falling in. (Be sure to keep shrimp covered. Stir to incorporate everything, then bring mixture up to a simmer. Place in a preheated oven and cover tightly with a lid or sheet pan. Bake until all liquid is absorbed and rice is tender, about 23 to 25 minutes. Meanwhile, thinly slice remaining green onions for garnish. Fluff rice with a fork, then scoop into serving dishes. Top with cooked shrimp and green onions and serve with lime wedges on the side.
SHEET PAN SHRIMP
1 lb. baby red potatoes (quartered), 1 1/2 lb raw medium shrimp (peeled and deveined), 2 ears of corn (cut crosswise into 4 pieces each), 2 links smoked andouille sausage (thinly sliced), 2 lemons (sliced), 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp Old Bay seasoning, 2 tbsps melted butter, 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 2 tbsps freshly chopped parsley for garnish.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook potatoes until just tender, about 10 minutes. Drain. In a large bowl, combine cooked potatoes, shrimp, corn, sausage, lemons, garlic powder, Old Bay, melted butter, and oil and season with salt and pepper. Toss until combined, then divide between two large baking sheets. Bake until shrimp is cooked through and corn is tender, 13 to 15 minutes.

title: Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Town employees discussed an apparent "sabotage" of Greensboro's water system and heard feedback from residents during a Thursday evening Town Council meeting.On July 29, the town announced that the its water and wastewater contract operator, Susquehanna Operational Services, conducted tests throughout town, finding higher than normal chlorine levels. It came after a bevy of complaints from concerned residents, who said the water had a chlorine-like taste and smell the weekend prior.
The town concluded that "one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with" in the tower wells. In a press release, it was deemed "deliberate sabotage," and the town stated the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would conduct an investigation.
Brandon Cunningham, the town's public works supervisor, provided an update Thursday on security measures put in place in days since. Cunningham said "the locks have all been changed to all the well houses."
Keys were given to members of Susquehanna Operational Services, and himself and the town manager in case of emergency, he said.
He also said he's been in contact with SafeHouse, a security system company, to potentially procure security cameras and keypads. Cunningham said SafeHouse security measures, including adding cameras, would cost $15,865.54.
Councilmember Joe Noon said he'd "like a couple more bids" for the cameras and security additions. Carly Landolfi, assistant to the town attorney, told councilmembers they could vote on a "contingent" motion to purchase the SafeHouse services, depending on whether she finds the town must legally seek out other bids or not.
Mayor David Spencer said he's visited the wells and vouched for security services to be adopted as soon as possible.
"I really don't want to push this off," Spencer said. Councilmember Pete Breila made a motion to pass the "contingent" motion, which was seconded by Councilmember Bob Harrison.
PUBLIC COMMENTMultiple residents expressed concerns about the water quality and the town's response to councilmembers Thursday.
"The word sabotage, that's a pretty extensive word," resident Chris Mason said. "It means a lot, and it puts fear in the community."
Mason continued, questioning why the investigation is being conducted by Caroline County Sheriff's Office and not the Greensboro Police Department. He added that he wished the town had passed out water to residents during the days in which the chlorine-like taste and smell was apparent.
"Who has access to sabotage?" resident Melissa Knight asked. "Where'd that information come from? We're not getting any forthcoming information."
Knight said that "the entire bedroom (smelled) like chlorine" after flushing the toilet in her house last weekend. She also asked about the process of testing the chlorine levels.
George Smith, president of Susquehanna Operational Services, said his team tested multiple locations when notified by the town of the complaints. Smith and a Susquehanna employee confirmed there were readings of 2.2, 0.6 and 0.54 milligrams per liter. The Environmental Protection Agency's standard is that anything above the 4.0 milligram per liter mark is not healthy to drink and could pose long-term health effects such as eye irritation and stomach problems.
Smith declined to comment on the investigation since it's active. Spencer also declined.
"There's a lot that we'd all like to say," Spencer said. "But since there is an investigation ongoing, when that is concluded, then we will try to give you as much information as we possibly can."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office declined to comment on the investigation for this article.

title: Delaware school boards increasingly see controversy
author: Julia Merola Spotlight Delaware
content:
Delaware school boards increasingly see controversy

 August 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Julia Merola Spotlight Delaware | Section: News 
 
 2359
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "You're out of order" was one of the most popular phrases of the night at Tuesday's Christina School District's Board of Education meeting. The sentiment was directed toward board members and attendees alike.Although the nearly four-and-a-half-hour meeting was certainly shorter than last month's nearly eight-hour-long meeting, tension between the board and community members was felt immediately.
Within the first 35 minutes of the meeting, Board President Donald Patton explained the rules of public comments and called attendees "guests" while doing so.
"Let me take a few minutes to remind our guests that you are our guests," he said. "We have a session coming up called Opportunity for Public Comment if you've registered, and I will read the guidelines for correct participation. But as a guest, you cannot be disrespectful to the process."
The audience and community members didn't take being labeled as guests lightly.
"It was stated in the past that we are guests. We are not guests. This is a public body, this is a public meeting. You are elected officials. These are not guests. These are the bosses," said Rep. Madinah Wilson-Anton (D-Newark) as the audience applauded her. "We have a First Amendment right to speak in public meetings, speak our minds. You can put policies in place that say you can't say certain things, but you can't police how we speak because you don't like it."
Within the last year, boards of education from Delmar to Brandywine have been subject to controversy, particularly around their most important duty: hiring, working with and overseeing a district's superintendent.
None have been more volatile than Christina, which voted last month to remove its superintendent after a meeting stretched more than seven hours into the middle of the night. Controversy in the Newark-area district has become so frequent that state legislators mandated that a Delaware Department of Justice attorney attend all meetings for the next year.
Schools' governing authorityIssues occurring within boards are unusual, said Verjeana McCotter-Jacobs, the executive director and CEO of the National School Boards Association. It's more typical to see tension when a board deals with issues like budgets, boundary changes or closing schools.
"With 90,000 school board members on 15,000 school boards across the country, by far, most are doing good work, and they're focused overall, on the vision for the school district," McCotter-Jacobs said.
A local school board essentially is the governing authority for a school district, said Paolo DeMaria, the president and CEO of the National Association of State Boards of Education. School boards can fulfill tasks like hiring a superintendent and approving budgets and curriculum priorities.
Board members aren't paid, but some receive reimbursements for incurred expenses.
McCotter-Jacobs also compared board members to members of Congress, as they typically don't have term limits. Board members are typically elected for four-year periods and can run for reelection as many times as they'd like, but some do have term limits.
State school boards are similar to overseers for local school boards, in the sense that they have regulations that local school boards have to follow, McCotter-Jacobs said. The state school board isn't involved in how a local board carries out its regulations unless they receive a complaint or an appeal that they'll review.
How do Delaware's local school boards work?While independent, each Delaware school board has many of the same basic characteristics: members don't receive a stipend or salary, they have no term limits and the state school board sets regulations that might influence how the local school board decision-making.
School board members must be Delaware residents and U.S. citizens, be 18 or older and must live in the nominating district, said David Tull, the executive director of the Delaware School Boards Association. An individual cannot be a paid employee of the district and must never have been convicted of embezzlement.
After being elected to a school board, members have two state training sessions that they're required to complete within their first year. One session is for financial training and the other is due process training, which is for dealing with special education, Tull said.
The Delaware School Boards Association also offers its own boot camp for board members every July, covering a variety of topics like financial training, due process training, board member responsibilities and the need to follow Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) rules, among other topics.
Other organizations like First State Educate, a nonprofit that aims to engage families and communities on education issues, share information about student outcomes and encourage school board candidates, also work to provide different resources and training sessions for board members.
"We're trying to train the public and the community and potential school board members, and then we're trying to train the board members themselves," said Julia Keleher, the executive director of First State Educate. "Ultimately, if both people have the same knowledge and information, they're going to be able to operate much more effectively."
The organization recently announced its Center for School Board Excellence in Governance, to provide school board members with resources to "lead with confidence and integrity." Their first set of courses will focus on parliamentary procedures, ethical decision-making and financial management.
First State Educate is also pushing out information to help people understand what boards of education are supposed to do, and will recruit people for board elections starting in January, Keleher said.
The organization also has a school board consultant in New Castle County and is aiming to hire additional people to develop the same role downstate.
"We want to develop those roles and put that resource there so that those communities also have exactly what we built in New Castle County," Keleher said.
DelawareCAN, an advocacy group that works on public education improvement and equity, partners with First State Educate to run trainings and to help get qualified people interested in running for school boards, said Executive Director Britney Mumford.
Christina board tensions cause divideThe Christina School District's Board of Education has seen a tumultuous few weeks, with some public commenters labeling the board as "an embarrassment." Tuesday's meeting did little to ease lingering tension.
The board's discussion information items in its Aug. 13 agenda included a "referral to the Public Integrity Commission for an opinion on whether targeting of the superintendent by the board violates public trust and reflects unfavorably on the district," a second referral to the Public Integrity Commission for an opinion on whether engaged in self-dealing with the district "through alternative entities," and a third referral on whether a board member's prolonged absence from the district undermines the public's trust.
Other points included nullifying the July 2024 board officer votes and holding a new vote on board officers, reinstating Superintendent Dan Shelton — who was placed on administrative leave during the July 9 meeting — as "the latest investigation uncovered no wrongdoing," and recommendations for an interim superintendent, among other items.
However, a simple majority of board members voted to strike discussion on all items except naming an interim superintendent.
It later selected former Christina and Red Clay Consolidated School District Superintendent Robert Andrzejewski to head the district this coming school year — despite questions over whether he even knew he was being nominated.
Five members of the state legislature who represent the Christina district — Reps. Madinah Wilson-Anton (D-Newark), Paul Baumbach (D-Newark), Cyndie Romer (D-Newark), Sophie Philips (D-Bear) and Eric Morrison (D-Glasgow) — also filed a FOIA violation against the board with the Department of Justice.
"As legislators, we generally try to stand back and let [the board] do their stuff, but when things have a problem, we start looking into it," Baumbach said. "The closer you look into it, you realize how bad that the district board is being led."
FOIA violations
In June, the DOJ found the board violated FOIA laws by holding an unannounced executive session for an improper purpose and failing to provide adequate notice in its March and May meeting agendas for votes regarding the contract rescission and vote of no-confidence in Shelton.
If a meeting is not noticed properly, meaning there will be items considered that were not on the agenda, then the public wouldn't know whether they need to attend the meeting or for how long they'd need to attend, said Mark Fenster, a law professor at the University of Florida who studies government transparency.
Fenster added that sometimes an agency might use vague wording in a public agenda because they may not know exactly what they're doing with the issue or what to anticipate, but know they will cover it.
"Members of the public are not being paid for going to these meetings, having other things to do and busy lives," Fenster said. "If this is a trap or a trick that the agency is playing, this seems both kind of duplicitous and shady, as well as potentially illegal, because it's not really following along."
The DOJ is required to send a report to the General Assembly after its year-long observation. The report will include any FOIA matters observed and recommendations it has for necessary changes to ensure the "proper operation" of the board.
Patton declined Spotlight Delaware's request for comment on the controversy, citing the "potential for litigation."
Patton made it a point to apologize to the public during the Aug. 13 meeting for "a number of things," admitting the board should be functioning differently. Patton also said he's been working with a parliamentarian to help provide a stricter structure on Robert's Rules of Order to help streamline the meetings.
Patton also acknowledged the FOIA violation complaints and said the board will be having a lawyer speak to them about the open records laws and violations.
"You have to remember when boards are put in place, folks aren't trained on these specific things," Patton said.
Although Christina has been a longtime member of the Delaware School Boards Association, they decided to drop out this past year, said Tull, the DSBA executive director, who added that Christina's newest board member paid to attend DSBA's boot camp though.
Although there's been a bit more public awareness in Christina, Mumford, of DelawareCAN, hasn't seen the average parent in the district become more interested in the board.
"There has been some of it, but it's really been to the extent of, 'Why are they acting crazy and not actually focusing on policies that affect my students?'" she explained.
Mumford added that the public's perception of the board "acting crazy" might cause families to see board members as something separate from the community.
"When things like this happen, people get the perception that, 'Oh, these are just another group of power-hungry policymakers that don't care about my family and my students,'" she said.
Brandywine also faces FOIA accusations
The Brandywine School District's board faced its own FOIA allegation this spring, following the district's former superintendent's retirement. One month after former Brandywine Superintendent Lincoln Hohler announced his retirement, then-Board President John Skrobot announced that then-Deputy Superintendent Lisa Lawson would be replacing Hohler.
Skrobot then asked board members Jason Heller and Kim Stock to volunteer for a small working group to deliver contract proposals to the full board.
The request caused a debate over whether the board was violating FOIA guidelines as the working group discussion wasn't on the agenda. During the meeting, board member the Rev. Shawn Jegede called on the public to file FOIA violations against the board if they felt the board went against open record laws.
"I have tried over and over again to encourage this board to no longer continue these violations of FOIA so that we can focus our attention on educating our students and supporting our staff and not wasting our time on lawsuits," Jegede said during the meeting.
The board moved to executive session to consult legal counsel and when they returned, Skrobot made the volunteer request again and clarified that the working group discussions would happen in a public meeting.
Current Board President Ralph Ackerman said there was no open records violation. Their attorney instructed that the subcommittee could be made of three board members or less.
"It's when you reach four and you have a quorum that that becomes unacceptable, so I think it was misunderstood by the person who had chatted with the attorney as to what was acceptable and what was not," Ackerman said. "It is certainly acceptable for the president to ask a couple of board members if they would volunteer to help negotiate a contract, which I believe, is exactly what Mr. Skrobot did at the time."
Brandywine's board of education doesn't have an attorney at every meeting, it instead uses a "strictly representative model," Ackerman said. He also noted that almost all of the board members have gone to the DSBA's boot camp in recent years.
Capital super leaves after 'hostility'
When former Superintendent Vilicia Cade announced her departure from the Capital School District on June 11, she thanked the Board of Education for the opportunity to serve the district and highlighted some of her achievements.
On June 12, the district published a joint letter between Cade and Board President Felecia Duggins, showing gratitude from both parties. Duggins thanked Cade for her service to the school and Cade expressed that "under the esteemed Board of Education the district will remain the heartbeat of the first state."
However, in her resignation letter to staff, Cade cited a hostile work environment and interference in her ability to carry out her role.
"I have consistently asked for us to work on fostering trust, mutual respect and jointly explore ways to work more intently toward improving communication between the board and superintendent," Cade wrote. "Subsequently, my request was met with aggressive hostility on the part of some board members, including acts of intimidation and intentional misuse of authority."
Both Cade and Duggins did not respond to Spotlight Delaware's request for comment.
The public's perception of their school board could make it more difficult to find candidates in the future, Mumford added.
"The folks that run for school board are not generally people that see that as a political steppingstone. In my opinion, they are people that really want to invest their time in the district, that really care about student outcomes, and when things become so polarized, it becomes difficult for them," Mumford said. "Situations like this make it tougher to find good candidates moving forward because they don't see the school board as creating positive outcomes, as looking to really make a true impact. They just see it as this polarizing political entity."

title: A clown named Crickett 'stands out' at Port Deposit festival
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
A clown named Crickett 'stands out' at Port Deposit festival

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1049
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PORT DEPOSIT — Hundreds of people attended the fourth annual Pirate Takeover in Port Deposit last weekend, but one person stood out in the crowd — quite literally.Head and shoulders above all the rest was "Crickett," a professional clown who ambled throughout the Marina Park grounds on stilts that were hidden by his tuxedo-style pants and boosted his natural six-foot height to somewhere around eight feet.
"Crickett," whose real name is James McGrath, turned heads — upward, as well as sideways — wherever he roamed Saturday during the seven-hour event.
Many people stopped in their tracks and tilted their heads skyward to confirm that there was, indeed, a face attached to the top of that human mountain in their midst. Clearly amazed, giggling kids ran up to Crickett to get a closer look. Several of the youngsters went airborne, giving it their best Jordan jump, as they high-fived with this spectacle that bent forward accommodatingly.
"Some people actually get startled when they see me," McGrath said. "You get the usual jokes from people, too, like, 'How's the weather up there?' and, 'Hey, Shorty,'" stuff like that.
Of course, folks ask him how tall he is on those stilts. And they ask if he has ever fallen.
The answer to that last question: Only once in approximately 20 years of practicing and performing on stilts. And after that tumble, Crickett got back on his feet — unscathed — because learning how to fall safely on stilts is as important as learning how to walk on stilts.
The trick is to never extend your arms to break your fall because, instead, you will break your wrists, humerus and other nearby bones, he emphasized. Tucking your extremities, balling up your body and rolling when you hit the ground are the ingredients for a safe fall.
As it turns out, Crickett takes his clowning very seriously. A 44-year-old Washington, D.C. resident, McGrath performs as Crickett in the region about 100 times a year under his enterprises of Shows by Crickett, Block Party Bubbles and Clown Cabaret.
"I performed at the Pirate Takeover event in Port Deposit for the past few years, and it is easily one of my favorite gigs," McGrath commented.
Those 100 or so annual gigs are the sole source of income for McGrath, who married for the first time in 2024 after spending many years on the road as a professional clown, including a long stint with the renowned Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus.
That clowning job with The Greatest Show on Earth took him to every state in the continental United States, save for Wyoming, the Dakotas and perhaps one or two others. McGrath performed as "Crickett" with Ringling Brothers in some major arenas, including the legendary Madison Square Garden.
"Back stage, there was a bunch of pictures of Billy Joel because he had performed there so many times. I think he holds the record," McGrath said of that famous New York City venue.
So how did McGrath morph into a professional clown?
Born in Massachusetts and raised in Virginia, McGrath went to the circus with his family as a kid and was drawn to all of its attractions, particularly juggling. While attending Christopher Newport University in Newport News, Va., where he graduated in 2005 with a psychology degree, McGrath learned to juggle.
"I always liked juggling as a hobby. I got a book, something like, 'The Complete Klutz Guide to Juggling' and taught myself how to juggle," he recalled.
Perhaps the main lesson that McGrath learned while majoring in psychology was this: Live an adventurous life and see new places while you are still young and able.
After attending a clowning camp in New York City, a few years post graduation, McGrath joined the Big Apple Circus as a concessions worker — just to get his big, goofy clown foot in the door.
As did many of the 150 other circus employees, McGrath lived in a renovated room in the back of a trailer while the show traveled to places in Georgia, Vermont, New Hampshire, Virginia and New York.
"I was a cotton candy twister," he said, before explaining, "I was just hoping to meet some people, make the right connections."
That pay-your-dues gig made a huge difference, too, because McGrath then got a performance job with Ringling Brothers. He performed under the Big Top as Crickett with the Blue Unit of that outfit from 2006 through 2011, juggling and executing all manners of jokes, including sight gags.
"I was very lucky. I just happened to be submitting a resume at the time when one of the clowns jumped ship — so I was available and got the job," McGrath remembered.
It was common for Ringling Brothers to stay in the cities and towns on the tour and perform nine to 15 shows per week, before moving on to the next stop. It was a demanding way of life that was tempered by the fun and adventure it provided.
"We traveled by train and pretty much lived on that train. We each had a 6'-by-6' room. We were paid a salary that was just enough to live on, just enough to meet expenses. We got one month off every two years," McGrath reviewed.
It was a passion project. "I'd work with the other clowns and we'd come up with our own gags. We'd also work with writers and a team of prop builders," McGrath said.
There was no need, however, for McGrath's talent on two-foot stilts at the Ringling Brothers level. "They had Caribbean stilt-walkers who walked smoothly on 6-foot stilts," McGrath noted.
The secret to walking on stilts, according to McGrath: "You have to get over your reptilian mindset and feel comfortable walking higher above ground than normal. And you have to know how to fall safely. It took me about 20 hours total of walking on stilts before it felt natural to me."
He added, "Most gigs are one to two hours long. Some, though, are four to five hours long and you feel pretty achy after walking on stilts all that time."
After he left Ringling Brothers and transitioned into a more domesticated life that still allowed him to clown and perform regionally, McGrath incorporated more stilts-walking into his act. He has been performing solo as Crickett, mostly on weekends, for approximately the past 15 years.
"It is an abnormal job, but I have a pretty normal life," he summarized.

 In this new year of 2025, I am praying for an awakening. It is very interesting to consider what people seem most passionate about.Everyone seems to be passionate about something.
As Christians, we are passionate about many things — God, family, rights, the list can go on and on. But how many of us Christians (followers of Christ) are passionate about Jesus' last words before ascending to Heaven?
Mark 16:15 — And He said to them, "Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature."
There are so many Christians today passionate about politics, conspiracies, health, theology, but not many are passionate about Christ's last words.
We need to on guard so that we do not become better at winning arguments, than at winning souls. God have mercy on us and forgive us of this great neglect. Give us ears to hear and hearts to receive and obey your word to us.
2 Timothy 4:2. — Preach the Gospel in season, and out of season; reprove, rebuke, exhort with all long suffering and doctrine. Help us Lord to remember that the last words of our Lord Jesus Christ are called the Great Commission, and not the Great Option.
Lord strengthen us to do your will. In Jesus' name, Amen.

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Denton food pantry provides food for more than 1,000 families

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Aaron's Place, a food pantry and soup kitchen just northeast of downtown Denton, provided crucial meals, food and drinks to more than 1,000 families last week.On Thursday, volunteers stacked open trunks full of fresh fruit, vegetables, perishables, canned sodas, Thanksgiving desserts and, of course, turkeys. They began distributing the groceries just after 11 a.m., though cars were lined up hours in advance.
Aaron's Place Executive Director Cheryl Beulah said volunteers handed out food until around 7 p.m. Around 1,115 families were served, according to Beulah.
From seeing residents come into the food pantry every week, Beulah says "food insecurity is real." Mary Lou Russ, an administrative assistant at the food pantry, said the amount of need is "overwhelming."
During the pandemic, Beulah says they served around 2,500 people for the Thanksgiving giveaway, an all-time high. The work done by Aaron's Place, which is partnered with the statewide nonprofit Maryland Food Bank, hasn't slowed down at all since 2020.
According to Maryland Hunger Solutions, more than 6,000 Caroline County residents participated in the federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in fiscal year 2022. 2020 census data shows 13.2% of Caroline County residents were below the poverty line, above the then-state average of 9%.
And according to a new survey of holiday meal costs by the American Farm Bureau Federation, the price of a Thanksgiving dinner has risen 29% from 2020. Beulah sees those rising food prices, and says it's a "challenging" time.
She said many of the residents in need, particularly during Thanksgiving and the holidays, are families and people from Caroline County. She also sees growing concern with hunger for the senior community.
Beulah said while discussions pertaining to food insecurity are important, action matters. In part, that's what drives her to lead the Denton food pantry and soup kitchen.
"That conversation's not putting food on that person's table," Beulah said. " … Your neighbors could be starving."
Aaron's Place's food pantry is open Tuesdays from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., Wednesdays from 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., and the third Thursday at 11 a.m. in January, March, May, July, September and November. The soup kitchen opens on Tuesdays at Noon.

author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Greensboro suspends Zoom meetings after 'vulgar' meeting interruption Monday

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 322

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Town of Greensboro's special meeting stream on Monday was cut short.The Zoom meeting was a victim of a "disturbing experience," which led the town to continue the meeting without the live stream.
"We were just having a normal meeting, and next thing we know, there's an interruption with vulgar racial language and pornographic video," Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said. "It was stopped within a minute or less than that."
After the meeting, the town put out a statement via Facebook stating all future Zoom meetings for the town would be suspended.
"Last night, during the Council meeting, an individual or individuals hijacked the Zoom feed. There is an active investigation to identify the individual(s) responsible for what appeared to be an intentional transmission of obscene materials over the internet," Town of Greensboro said in a statement.
"Council will take all necessary steps to prevent such incidents from happening in the future, including the suspension of all Zoom meetings," Town of Greensboro said in a statement."
The town later clarified that Zoom meetings would be suspended while the incident is investigated by the FBI, not indefinitely.
"The suspension is like a school suspension, Kelledes said. "It's not a permanent thing. It will be evaluated as the investigation goes forward and council is able to talk and decide what they want to do."
Greensboro will still be uploading the meeting minutes for residents to check and see what was discussed, the town said.
"They can always get a copy of the of the meeting minutes. There's certainly, there are plenty of people that attend that put the content out on social media," Kelledes said.
The town of Greensboro's plan is to have another form of video up after the investigation has been conducted and they receive recommendations on what software is good to use to conduct meetings without interruption.
"We're just trying to get through the investigation and see what the FBI tells us and what they recommend," Kelledes said.

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 7.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.59 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 5.3 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 18.2 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has fallen 1.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.73 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $3.05 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.29 per gallon, a difference of $1.24 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 1 cent per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.41 per gallon today. The national average is down 18.0 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 13.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
June 17, 2023: $3.41 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.55 per gallon)June 17, 2022: $4.97 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.99 per gallon)June 17, 2021: $2.98 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.07 per gallon)June 17, 2020: $2.12 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.11 per gallon)June 17, 2019: $2.61 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.67 per gallon)June 17, 2018: $2.85 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.89 per gallon)June 17, 2017: $2.27 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)June 17, 2016: $2.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.35 per gallon)June 17, 2015: $2.77 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.80 per gallon)June 17, 2014: $3.65per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.67 per gallon)

"Since the national average price of gasoline fell to its lowest June level since 2021 last week, we've seen the drop in prices take a break, with some states seeing a small rise over the last week. Thankfully, I expect this to be more like a short timeout, with an eventual return to falling gasoline prices in most states," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "The decline in diesel prices continues, with the national average price of diesel now at its lowest level since January 2022. Both gasoline and diesel prices remain below their year-ago level, which is music to the ears of the Federal Reserve, as fuel prices are a significant component of the Consumer Price Index. Also factoring in gasoline demand that has been running a bit weaker than expected, market fundamentals look pretty good right now if you're a motorist."

 The Toys For Tots Foundation — which includes the Cecil County chapter of the United States Marine Corps Reserves group — joined forces with a children's book author, who is originally from the Eastern Shore, to provide free books to children at the Elkton unit of the Cecil County Boys and Girls Club.Kim C. Lee brought signed copies of her book, "The Night Owl Goes to Space" for each child in the after school program at the Elkton Community Center. With the assistance of Allison Brown, Toys For Tots Foundation Youth Ambassador, Lee read her book to the kids.
"This is my second Night Owl book," Lee said, adding her son Jourdan is her inspiration to the stories.
"My son does not like to go to sleep at night," she said of Jourdan Russell, now 11. Even though it was written for him at a younger age, Lee said Jourdan still claims the title. "I am the Night Owl,' she said Jourdan would say.
As the story developed, the youngsters peppered Lee with comments and questions, showing they knew about the planets, their names and unique qualities. To her right, Brown kept up, turning the pages so each of the colorful pages could be seen.
Brown, who is from Centreville and now lives in Baltimore, has been a Toys For Tots Youth Ambassador for three years. She got involved through her American Heritage Girls troop. The lessons she's learned so far have been invaluable.
"I've really learned how to do social media ... how to push a post to get the community involved," Brown said. She's also learned about all the services in her own community and can talk to other teens about how they can get involved or get help.
Valerie Anderson, representing the regional foundation, said Brown — like the 44 other youth ambassadors across the country — is "a stand out person."
"She's been to our Outdoor Odyssey Leadership Camp in Pennsylvania, she goes to monthly meetings and activities and helps us raise brand awareness," Anderson said.
Lee gave each child her book and Brown handed each a Toys For Tots backpack that included such items as bookmarks, rulers, slap bracelets and stress balls.

QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A collaborative initiative to strengthen minority owned business presented its first inaugural class to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Sept. 10.Funded through the Rural Maryland Economic Development Fund, which is supported by the Maryland Department of Commerce and Upper Shore Regional Council and administered through Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator (META) pilot program provided tailored mentoring, networking opportunities, and strategic resources to help small minority-business owners overcome challenges and achieve sustainable growth.
Presenting certificates of achievements to participants, Rebecca Murphy, founding consultant of Upper Shore Community Development Founder and Chief Strategist noted META was created with the belief that diversity and entrepreneurship strengthens communities and economy.
"It is with great pride and joy that we congratulate the graduates of the inaugural class of the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator program today at this commissioners meeting. We celebrate not only their accomplishments but also the bright futures that each of them is carving out in our community," she said.
"META is a six month intensive business development and coaching program aimed at providing a cohort of small minority businesses with the resources they need to scale," said Sam Shoge, cofounder and partner of Rivers and Roads Consulting, who served as program facilitator and coach.
The program intends to close the knowledge resource and funding gap between minority-owned and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
Data is applied across all minority businesses including women-owned and veteran-owned, he said, and the importance of the program is noted in the disparities between minority and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
The average revenue of black sole proprietorships versus non-minority sole proprietorships is $22,000 versus $50,000 respectively, according to Shoge.
On average non-minority owned businesses are six times larger than black-owned businesses, he said.
A total of 15 applications from women and minority owned businesses were received in 2023 and five Queen Anne's County businesses were selected to participate in the inaugural program, he said.
Participants included Moniesha Baynard, owner of Three Guys and a Girl Personal Chef and Catering; Diane Moorman-White, owner of DMW Soul Fitness; Timeka Wheeler, owner of Long Live Assisted Living; Deayna Ewell, owner of Onyx Beauty Supply Salon Barbershop; and Ebony Johnson, owner of Tips and Toes Nail Studio.
The six-month program at the Kent Island Library began its first seminar in February 2024 and concluded in August.
META entailed monthly business development seminars including a variety of topics such as market strategy, business planning, sales and customer service, bookkeeping best practices, licensing and regulation as well as personal coaching, Shoge said.
A key aspect of the program was how entrepreneurs can partner and collaborate and support fellow community small businesses, he said.
"Our secretary of commerce Secretary (Micheal) Gill always said that economic development is a team sport and that is very much reflected in this program here," Shoge said.
Officials were very happy with the outcome and success of the program, with many participants reporting increased revenues, Shoge said.
Transitioning from a 36-year veterinary career, participant Moorman-White, credited the program with giving her the push and the confidence to prove to herself she could turn her "side-gig" into a full time career.
"Probably the biggest thing the META program has done for me was it changed my mindset. I am now recognizing the power I possess to achieve my goals both big and small," she said.

title: Federalsburg officials address town's mounting issues at public forum
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg officials address town's mounting issues at public forum

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Federalsburg Town Council hosted hundreds of residents for a public forum at Federalsburg Elementary School Monday evening.Town officials wanted to set the record straight about town rumors, addressing issues like misappropriation of town funds, employee resignations, $5 million of debt, wastewater treatment issues and police department cost.
A 50-minute explanation by the council members explained the root of these issues and the options and plans to solve them.
Debt and staff accountability
Council members revealed the town's $5 million of debt dates back to 1995.
"We did not get into a over $5 million debt overnight, but here we are and we're trying to clean it up piece by piece," council member Brandy James said. "When I came on council, the math just didn't add up. So, looking into things, some of this debt goes back to 1995.
"The town has had a very historic past of one not paying bills on time, two robbing Peter to pay Paul, and three in order to get anything done instead of doing the right thing and figuring out how to better utilize the funds that were coming in, they would just take out loans or they would take out grants. Some grants were grants that the town wasn't even qualified for, but that's what they would do."
James said the town must pay back grants to grant providers because the grant providers have discovered that the town wasn't eligible to receive the grants. She said the town has lost grants because of not having audits done since fiscal year 2023.
Federalsburg officials plan to establish a plan to pay off debt within 12 months using money from the town's general fund. The town has frozen spending and committed to a hiring freeze, except for a part-time code enforcement officer.
After the hiring freeze, James said that the town will shift its employment focus to hiring staff who are qualified for their positions, no longer hiring employees based off relationships.
Wastewater and water issues
Council member Darlene Hammond led the discussion on the fire department water usage. She said the town will not charge the fire department for water used to fight fires, but the fire house will be metered for non-emergency uses, which it previously has not been.
The town will install meters on hydrants to help track and detect leaks and start billing churches and other town serving companies for water and sewer usage.
Town officials acknowledged past issues with inconsistent billing and old meters. They plan to take steps to clear billing statements and update account balances. They will explore tools for online payments and text alerts when bills are due.
The town's wastewater treatment plant was also discussed at the meeting. The facility was built to support a housing development in the town that was never constructed, making it outsized to the town's needs.
Mayor Kim Abner said the facility is built to handle 750,000 gallons a day, more than double the current usage of 350,000 gallons per day.
The town has many issues with taking care of the facility due to cost and improper usage.
"It costs a lot of money to fix the water main. It costs a lot of money to maintain the wastewater treatment plant," Abner said. "There are state mandates that we have to deal with. We also need a new sludge press because the sludge press presses the water out, and if you don't press all the water out, you're paying more at the landfill. So, the wastewater treatment plant's a lot. It's a big investment. It's a lot of money, but we have to do it for safe drinking water and safe toilets."
Police Department
Council member Ian Ferguson talked about the cost of the town's police department.
If the town were to sign a memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide policing services, it would save the town between $300,000 and $500,000, he said.
The town currently pays $1.146 million for the Federalsburg Police Department.
Sheriff Donald Baker told residents that the his would hire Federalsburg's police officers if it were to assume policing duties for the town.
According to the Town Council, the current police station could be used as a substation for the Sheriff's Office if the town signs a memorandum of understanding.
The town plans to continue to have quarterly public meetings to keep the town informed on all issues and improvements.

title: Art exhibit in Easton uses small items to explore larger themes such as war, homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
Art exhibit in Easton uses small items to explore larger themes such as war, homelessness

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new art exhibit in Easton uses small-scale items like twigs to tell large-scale stories involving war, poverty and conflict.Inside the Academy Art Museum, "To the Edge of Your World" by Dutch-Irish artist Anita Groener welcomes viewers into a peaceful setting of grid-like drawings and bird-chirping sounds.
Two main displays — Cradle and Shrapnel — are sculpture works by Groener. They include materials like twigs gathered from walks with her dog that she started collecting more than 10 years ago.
Groener hopes the sculptures help people understand some of "their own baggage" and history.
"Everything's very small, which creates a psychological distance," said Groener, who lives in Dublin, while inside the Easton exhibit space last month. "And that's important because we witness all these world events."
For her, the exhibit is largely motivated by time she spent in the southern United States visiting civil rights monuments, as well as Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
Its meaning continues to evolve today, Groener said.
"Like we in Ireland watch what's going on in America," she said. "But it's such a distance, and I'm not taking part in that. Yet it affects us all. Everything that happens in the world, in our lives, affects us and is connected."
The Ireland-based artist doesn't want people to walk in thinking the art will yield certain takeaways. Rather, Groener hopes her art is open to interpretation.
"I like ambiguous readings, because as an artist, you can't be prescriptive," she said.
Groener's exhibit is the Academy Art Museum's first ever international exhibit. Charlotte Potter Kasic, the museum's executive director, said it took "many hoops to jump through" to make happen, but she's happy it panned out.
The opening weekend for the exhibit and a sister documentary film last month drew more than 250 people, Kasic said. They watched "Shelter," a 30-minute short film addressing homelessness on the Mid-Shore. Groener, the Talbot Interfaith Shelter and filmmaker Matt Kresling collaborated on the project.
At the front of Groener's exhibit is the main shelter structure, which is shown at the end of the film. She took around 10,000 pictures of the structure to make the stop-motion scene possible.
Groener said the scene is a "coming together of people" and all about community. Kasic said the audience on opening weekend was captivated by the film.
"No one moved," Kasic said. "They were all very engaged."
The film is slated to show at the Chesapeake Film Festival on Oct. 10 at the Ebenezer Theater in Easton. Groener's exhibit is open at the Academy Art Museum through Oct. 27.

title: Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition
