 STEVENSVILLE - When Queen Anne's County history teachers Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders first began recruiting students for National History Day years ago, there wasn't a lot of convincing students to participate."We knew we had to up our game," said Anders. "Now the Upper Shore region is second in the state for participation." National History Day is an event that encourages students to develop research, analysis, presentation, and social skills while working on a historical project. Open to students across the Shore, including Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, working individually or in groups, Junior Division (grades six-eight) and Senior Division (grades nine-12) students select a topic related to an annual theme. Information on the competitive event is distributed to students by their history teachers.The 2024 NHD theme is "Turning Points in History." There are five different types of projects that students complete: documentaries, exhibits, performances, and websites that can be done as a group or individually or papers that may only be done individually.Research is key, so the two teachers partnered with the public libraries in the participating Upper Shore counties of Queen Anne's, Kent, Talbot, and Cecil."Schools have limited research options," said Hayman, "so we turned to the county libraries who have more resources." During the fall season, as students begin picking a theme and looking for information, the teachers make themselves available at libraries across the region on specific dates so that librarians and History Day staff can provide assistance with finding research options, accessing online databases, or browsing materials.Hayman said the students learn valuable skills "like how to analyze information, to make sure sources are reliable, and to form their own opinion." Last weekend, Hayman and Anders visited Queen Anne's Library on Kent Island. Next up is the Talbot County Free Library in Easton on Oct. 21 from 9 a.m. 1 p.m.; Queen Anne's County Library in Centreville from 9 a.m. 1 p.m. on Nov. 4; and the Learning Resource Center at Chesapeake College on Nov. 12 from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.The actual contest is March 23, 2024, at Chesapeake College. Judges from the Upper-Shore community include teachers, professors, and museum staff. Students who place are then able to participate in the state finals on May 4 at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.The hard work of Hayman and Anders has paid off. "We saw that at the beginning the winners were always from the western shore," said Anders."Now we send more students to the state event than everyone but Baltimore County." Hayman said the program helps make history more real and interesting to students."You don't usually have students thrilled to be in history class," said Hayman. "Students who participate sometimes find their true passion."

 Name: Lynnette (Lynn) KeefeEmail: lkeaston@yahoo.com
Age: 54

Occupation: Online shopper at Harris Teeter
Previous political experience: I am not a politician, I am a regular resident of Easton. I got interested in politics when I was involved with Medical Freedom for Talbot County.
1. Why are you running for the Ward 2 seat on the Easton Town Council?
Running for Ward 2 is an honor. I am running because we need a voice for the day-to-day people who live in Easton. The hardworking backbone of our society. Your neighbors, servers, police, grocery store workers, those struggling on social security, etc. I see and hear the struggles.
2. What issues will you prioritize if elected?
I will prioritize the accountability of the Town Council, transparency and accountability with "your" money, smart growth for our special town.
We need to keep our next generation. People with and without children are from moving away from the Shore because they can't afford to live here and raise a family.
3. What changes would you make to the town's budget, and what budget items should not be cut?
The town budget is not transparent enough. We need to see more details instead of just line items with no explanations. It's hard to see exactly where our money is going.
4. While the town has grown, affordable housing remains a challenge for residents. How should the town build more housing, in particular affordable housing?
It is funny the Census has Easton population growth of only 101 more people since 2020. We all can see there has been much more growth. Either that or are we just congested because of workers commuting who live in more affordable towns.We need starter home neighborhoods for the first responders, teachers and people not making six figures. We can think outside the box — barndominiums, tiny homes or prefab housing neighborhoods, which are much less expensive to build.
5. What are your plans for public safety in Easton? What can be improved?
Safety is key for everyone in Easton. We need to treat our neighbors with kindness. Introduce yourself and watch out for each other. We have exceptional first responders, including police, EMS and volunteer firefighters, working a tough job just out of their heart for the people of their community. They are doing a great job even though they are running with short manpower.
With the area growing, we need to make sure we keep them equipped with proper needs.
6. In addition to serving the Town of Easton as a whole, what are your plans to improve your ward specifically?
I love the Ward 2 area where I live and volunteer. The Rails to Trails is a huge part of linking neighborhoods to the downtown area. Keeping that a positive and safe trail is always a concern for everyone.

title: Ruth Emma Santucci (Dietrich)
content:
Ruth Emma Santucci (Dietrich)

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - On Saturday, June 24th, 2023, in Easton, Maryland, our beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, Ruth Emma Dietrich Santucci, gently passed away at the age of 94 years old after years of declining health. Her passing was peaceful as she was comforted and held by her youngest daughter, Anne.Ruth was born on August 21st, 1928, to Annie Elmira Eckert and Nevin Emanuel Dietrich in Fleetwood, Pennsylvania. Ruth loved and cherished her sister, Agnes Breidegam and her three brothers, Ivan, Ray, and Lloyd Dietrich, who preceded her in death.After graduating from high school, Ruth attended Mansfield State Teacher's College, in Pennsylvania. A devoted student, Ruth, earned a BA in Education, with French as her minor.She completed a graduate degree at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.She was a believer in attaining education and she so enjoyed learning, especially foreign languages.She was fluent in German and French.Ruth was a teacher for several years in New Bloomfield, Pennsylvania.Ruth married the late Hubert Chester Santucci on August 22,1953, in Hershey, Pennsylvania.Upon their move to Easton, Maryland, Ruth continued teaching for several more years at St. Michaels High School. Following the births of her daughters, she focused on raising her children and supporting her husband, Hubert, as he continued his employment as principal of Easton High School, and later as Supervisor of Instruction at the Talbot County School Board.Ruth was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She always said she would "fight tigers for her daughters". She was a nurturer, a protector, and provided calm council for her family. As her husband's health declined, she was his strength. A quiet sentinel at his casket, gently placing his sleep toboggan on his head, so he wouldn't feel cold. A calm enduring presence following his death to give comfort to all the family who were grieving.Ruth was of the Depression Era. She never asked for much and was content with what she did have. She always put others feelings ahead of her own and it was most important for her to conduct herself in a ladylike manner. She never wanted to cause distress or inconvenience for anyone. A resilient lady, calm in a crisis, always lending emotional support to others.A member of St. Peter and Paul Catholic Church, Ruth had a strong faith. She did not fear death. She was confident she would be surrounded by her loved ones when she passed.Ruth is survived by her daughters, Lisa Santucci Dunphy, Amy Santucci Parrish, and Anne Kay Santucci; granddaughter, Kathryn Taylor Raver and her husband, Adam; grandson, William Chester Parrish, and his wife, Arianne; her great-grandchildren James Hubert Raver and Peyton Louis Raver; her sons-in-law, John Dunphy and Randy Parrish. Ruth will be cremated and her remains will be buried with her cherished husband, Hubert Chester Santucci, at the Eastern Shore Veteran's Cemetery.As Ruth had a love of learning and teaching, in lieu of flowers, she would have appreciated a donation to the Talbot County Free Library of Easton, Maryland.

title: Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While the Chesapeake Film Festival's focus this year largely dealt with environment and women's empowerment, the "rhythm, motion and meaning" section shown at the Academy Art Museum on Saturday afternoon veered into something different.There were two screenings: a documentary feature called "Lives Beyond Motion," directed by Keith Glassman, and a documentary short called "100 Foot Photo," directed by Matt Kresling.
The festival's Executive Director Cid Collins Walker said she chose to show these films together to balance the festival's commitment to films about women's empowerment with stories about men.
Walker said this was the best attended year in the festival's 18-year history.
"Every year, we see an increase in the amount of support we receive for all the programming," Walker said.
Committing life to art
After the showings Saturday, there was a Q&A with the director and producer of "Lives Beyond Motion."
The film explored Glassman's existential question of why he and other men committed their lives to dance.
The film began as a low-budget, long-term project around 2008 with major progress starting in 2015 after bringing producer The Angel on board. Glassman interviewed around 20 dancers who, without knowing it, shared common loves, struggles and difficulties.
Glassman's own career as a dancer ended 30 years ago after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. This prompted his quest to understand why dancers commit their lives to the artform for such a long time.
"I decided their answers should be heard by a wider audience, which was the impetus for the interviews," Glassman said. "Their specific answers about their experiences adjusted my perspective beyond my own, bringing in topics relevant to the whole dance community over the years, like the HIV epidemic."
"Lives Beyond Motion" is Glassman's first documentary, and he said he's been submitting it to every film festival possible.
Audience members went around the room describing what about the film resonated with them most. Multiple people spoke of the authenticity and vulnerability of the interviewees, which they said made this film personal and emotional.
An Eastern Shore connection
Matt Kreslings short film follows the journey of 20th century American artist Robert Rauschenberg's trip to China in the 1980s, his creative relationship with long-time Eastern Shore resident Donald Saff and, ultimately, his creation of a long, scroll-like photograph he named "Chinese Summerfall."
The 10-minute film explored the painstaking process of printmaking at a time when artists were physically cutting negative images and didn't know if they were done properly until the images were processed.
"I want my work to make you care because I care," Rauschenberg said in the film.
The Academy Art Museum will celebrate Rauschenberg's 100th birthday with the exhibit "Rauschenberg 100: New Connections" opening Dec. 11 and running through May 3, 2026.
The exhibit will include "Chinese Summerfall," which is rarely exhibited due to its size and fragility, according to the Academy Art Museums website. It will also feature showings of Kresling's short film, "100 Foot Photo."
"Receiving the support that we do from the community, from our sponsors, our partners, our patrons, makes such a huge difference for us," Walker said. "We simply couldn't do it without you."

title: Rivera yet to name starting QB against Dallas
author: Stephen Whyno
content:
Rivera yet to name starting QB against Dallas

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Stephen Whyno | Page: 18 | Section: Sports

 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ron Rivera refused Tuesday to reveal who will start at quarterback for the Washington Commanders in their season finale this weekend against the Dallas Cowboys.It could be an 18th consecutive start for Sam Howell, the first of the season for Jacoby Brissett or even Jake Fromm's first NFL game action in nearly two years.
"We don't have to let anybody know until tomorrow, so we're just going to wait," Rivera said on a video call with reporters. "We don't want to give them any head start on anything."
No matter who starts, the Commanders need to do a better job helping that QB. Howell has been sacked a league-high 61 times, the product of a lack of offensive balance with the team largely abandoning the run for a pass-heavy approach.
Brissett was 18 of 23 for 224 yards and three touchdowns in two recent games in relief of Howell.
Rivera last week benched Howell for Brissett, who then popped up on the injury report Friday with a hamstring injury that kept him out against San Francisco.
Not learning until two hours before kickoff that he'd be starting, Howell threw two more interceptions against the 49ers in a 27-10 loss, Washington's seventh in a row, to give him a leagueworst 19 this season.
Asked about the switch back to Howell after practicing with Brissett during the week, veteran tight end Logan Thomas said: "Both of them are obviously different. But we're all professionals. We know how to work with either guy."
It's unclear if Brissett, on a oneyear contract and set to be a free agent again this offseason, is healthy enough to practice this week or play Sunday against Dallas.
"He's just been working with the trainers and everybody, and we'll see how he is," Rivera said.
WHAT'S WORKING
Arizona's stunning comeback win at Philadelphia not only allowed the Niners to celebrate clinching the NFC's top seed, it boosted the Commanders' draft status. They could pick as high as second, pending the result of their game and New England's at home against the New York Jets.
That would give whoever's next in charge the chance to take one of the top quarterback prospects available, Ohio State receiver Marvin Harrison Jr. or a standout offensive tackle.
WHAT NEEDS HELP
The offense isn't the only problem, and there are plenty of holes to fill on defense, too. Cornerback Kendall Fuller, safety Kam Curl and linebacker Cody Barton are all pending free agents, and Washington will need new edge rushers after trading Chase Young and Montez Sweat prior to the deadline.
STOCK UP
One of the few bright spots this season has been second-year running back Brian Robinson Jr., who averaged 4.9 yards a carry against San Francisco. Robinson has eight total touchdowns this season with 358 yards receiving to go with 708 on the ground as he has shown he can catch as well as run in the pros.

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County animals continue to be in "good paws" as officials presented updates to ensure the safety and wellbeing of those in their care to the Queen Anne's Board of County Commissioners Feb 27.The Queen Anne's County Animal Control Commission (ACC) introduced updates to the Animal Control Comprehensive plan, Chapter 9.
While there have certainly been changes over the years, the Animal Control ordinance has never seen a line by line holistic review of documents such as this before, said Jennifer Nowak, commission chair.
"It needed a major upgrade," she said.
Revisions were especially needed to make the ordinance more applicable for animal control cases, Nowak noted. The extensive revision includes housekeeping items and definition changes to make the documentation flow better.
Updates to the animal control ordinance include three full document reviews, hundreds of hours of work and strong collaboration from officials including Animal Control, emergency services and animal services, according to Nowak.
A public hearing regarding the ordinance is expected at the commissioner's March 26 meeting.
In other business, Queen Anne's County Animal Services (QACAS) presented 2023 overviews and 2024 projections to the county commissioners.
Animal Services Chief of Services Kelly Hamilton presented a year in review and projections for the shelter moving forward.
The shelter continues to lead the way in providing care care for forlorn animals of the Eastern Shore with an impact stronger than ever, she said, it was a very successful year of diligent volunteers, engaging events, and successful community support and 2024 only looks to continue.
The organization considers itself a quintessential No-Kill Shelter of the state of Maryland and the Eastern Shore, Hamilton said, with the Live Release Rate determined by the number of animals leaving the shelter via adoption, returned to the owner or transferred to another shelter.
The national standard to be considered a No Kill Shelter is 90% and with a 94.6% rate, QACAS is proud to be one of 12 such shelters in Maryland, she said.
A total of 1,324 animals entered the county's shelter in 2023, whether as strays, seized or transferred in, a 29% increase from 2022, according to Hamilton.
Through QACAS, 679 animals found their "furr-ever" families in 2023, she announced.
Nearly 900 surgeries were performed onsite ranging from routine neuters, to life saving procedures.
The shelter has ramped up its social media presence including facial recognition software to instrumentally connect owners and pets and help 166 animals find their way back home in 2023.
"It's amazing, the technology is there," Hamilton said.
Hamilton credited volunteers and foster families as the "true heroes" for their tireless dedication to the animals.
"It really takes our team to invest all this time and energy in these animals to get them ready for that adoption floor," she said.
Foster families are imperative to provide valuable insight into an animal's behavior outside of the shelter to provide "purr-fect" placement for prospective adopters.
Programs include doggy day trips in hopes of enticing new foster families with a day of play away from the kennels, which can often snowball into full blown adoptions.
IQACAS participated in a National Clear the Shelter Event to roaring success, seeing nearly 100 animals find homes in a very short amount of time, she said.
Other community events include Puppy Yoga, donation drives, and partnering with the Parks and Recreation Department for the first annual "Pawing in Love" Fun Run.
Moving forward, the shelter expects to see an increase in community involvement including school education programs and "bigger and better" fundraisers, Hamilton said.
The facility has undergone remodeling to include updated in house dental machines and a new lobby layout. The shelter is now home to new cat condos, improved yard spaces, and even surround sound speakers at the dog kennels to provide calming ambiance.
With its newly improved yard space, they plan to offer additional enrichment programs for dog training including daily doggie play groups.
A complimentary behaviorist class is available for all newly adopted dogs. This program will serve residents who may be considering surrendering animals to the shelter for behavioral concerns or are in need of training tips, according to Hamilton.
QACAS looks to continue leading the pack as a local No Kill Shelter with updated technology and infrastructure improvements to provide community critters the best care "pawsible."
More information about the QACAS, including upcoming events can be found at www.qac.org/1425/Animal-Services.

title: Country Cooking: Sweet Potato Day on the farm
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Sweet Potato Day on the farm

 October 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1484
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was usually a cool, crisp morning as the rule of the farmers was "dig the sweet potatoes after the first frost."Days before, the baskets would be pulled out and the space in the shed prepared for storage. Mom would make a large pot of vegetable beef soup and have freshly made biscuits ready.
The tractor had the flat trailer attached, and the boys climbed on board. Off to the field they would go. No music to listen to or cell phones to talk on — just country folks doing the seasonal Saturday morning "thang."
As the tractor returned to the shed the filled baskets were lifted off next to piles of empty baskets, the sorting began — the sweet potatoes were placed in the empty baskets by their size.
The large ones for steaming for pies and bread, the medium ones for baking and the small ones for a quick pan of biscuits and to give to families smaller than ours who only wanted "enough for a taste."
When the work was done, and the delicious smells of freshly made soup filled the air, we all stepped into the kitchen where the big table was set with bowls, soup spoons and dishes of homemade butter. The hungry crowd quickly filled the seats.
Grace was said, biscuits taken out of the oven, bowls of soup passed around — Mom standing, watching with a smile on her face.
However, my sister and I would stand with scowls on our faces at the number of dishes to be washed, dried and put away. Saturdays on the farm, folks.
As we get closer to Thanksgiving, I will include Mom's sweet potato pie recipe.
For this first one today, we are taking a trip to Memphis. One of Elvis's favorite dishes is what's called Red hot Southern sweet potatoes.
RED HOT SOUTHERN SWEET POTATOES
3 ½ pounds sweet potatoes (peeled and cubed), ¼ cup butter or margarine (melted), ½ cup packed brown sugar, 1 ¼ cups cinnamon red hot candies, ¾ cup water, 1 package miniature marshmallows.
Place the sweet potatoes into a large saucepan with enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, and cook over medium heat until tender, about 25 minutes. Drain water, and place potatoes in a large casserole dish. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a medium bowl, stir together the butter, brown sugar, red hot candies and water. Pour over the sweet potatoes in the dish. Bake for 1 hour in the preheated oven, until sweet potatoes are soft, and the candies are melted. After this, you may top with marshmallows and return the dish to the oven for 10 minutes to toast them.
TOASTED SWEET POTATOES
2 pounds sweet potatoes (about 4 medium), 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Dice the sweet potatoes into 3/4-inch cubes, leaving the skin on. In a large bowl, mix together the sweet potatoes with the olive oil, garlic powder, and salt. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place the sweet potatoes on top in an even layer. Bake for about 25 minutes, until the cubes are tender and browned on the bottom. Serve warm. Store leftovers refrigerated. Make ahead instructions: Make up to three days in advance and reheat in a 350-degree oven.
SWEET POTATO SALAD
3 large sweet potatoes (peeled and cubed), 1 small red onion (thinly sliced into half moons), 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/2 cup crumbled feta, 1/4 cup freshly chopped parsley. FOR THE DRESSING: 2 tbsps apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp Dijon mustard, 1 tbsp honey, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp ground paprika, 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees. On a large rimmed baking sheet, toss sweet potatoes and red onion in oil then season with salt and pepper. Distribute them evenly on a sheet in a single layer. Bake until tender, about 20 minutes. Let cool for 10 minutes then transfer to a large bowl. Meanwhile, make dressing: In a small bowl or in a medium liquid measuring cup, whisk together vinegar, mustard, honey and spices. Gradually pour in oil, whisking constantly until emulsified. Season with salt and pepper. Toss sweet potatoes with dressing, cranberries, feta and parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.
INSTANT POT SWEET POTATO CASSEROLE
3 pounds sweet potatoes (peeled, cut into three-inch cubes), 1/4 cup dark brown sugar, 3 tbsps maple syrup, 1/4 cup unsalted butter, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp vanilla, 2 1/2 cups pecans (chopped), 2 cups mini marshmallows.
Place the cubed sweet potatoes into the cooking vessel and pour in enough water to cover the potatoes. Select Manuel/Mode at 400 degrees, and set the time to 30 minutes. Bring to a boil. Using the handle grips remove the pot from the heat, drain the excess water and place it on the countertop protector. Add the sugar, salt, vanilla extract and butter. Using a masher, mix until smooth. Using a spatula spread the mashed potato, making sure you have an even layer, top with a layer of pecan and on top a layer of mini marshmallows. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. When the preheating time is done, place the cooking vessel into the oven and bake uncovered for 30-35 minutes or until the marshmallows are golden brown. Remove the cooking vessel using the handle grips and place it on the countertop protector. Serve and enjoy.
CRISPY SWEET POTATO FRIES
1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 3 large sweet potatoes.
In a bowl combine salt, cayenne pepper, garlic powder and cinnamon. Set this dry mixture aside to use at the end. Wash sweet potatoes and halve each potato lengthwise. Slice into 1/4 inch sticks. In a large pot, heat canola oil. In batches, cook fries in oil for 5 minutes or until crisp. Drain on paper towels. Sprinkle with the cinnamon, cayenne mixture. My grandson Mason loves to dip his in maple syrup.
SWEET POTATO BISCUITS
Cook sweet potatoes, cool, peel and mash well. To 1 cup of the potatoes, add 2 1/2 cups biscuit mix, 1/3 cup softened butter and 1/2 cup milk. Mix until a soft dough is obtained. Turn dough out on a lightly floured surface and shape into a ball; knead three or four times — do not over-knead. Press out to a flatten circle and cut into two-inch rounds. Arrange biscuits with edges touching on an ungreased baking sheet. Bake in a pre-heated 450-degree oven for 10 — 12 minutes or until golden.
SWEET POTATO CHIPS
2 large sweet potatoes, 2 tbsps olive oil, 1/4 tsp sea salt.
Preheat the oven to 250 degrees and position the oven rack in the center of the oven. Rinse and dry your sweet potatoes thoroughly and slice them as uniformly thin as possible (1/8 inch thick slices). If you have a mandolin, use it. Otherwise, use a very sharp knife to get these uniformly thin. Know that chips that are too thick in parts won't crisp up all the way. Still delicious, just not "chip" crispiness. Toss slices in a touch of olive oil to lightly coat, then sprinkle with salt. Lay out in a single layer on a parchment-lined baking sheet and bake for about 1 hour 30 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes, flipping chips once at halfway point to ensure even cooking. Thickness of slices will impact cooking time. Check at 10 minute intervals during the second hour of cooking to ensure they aren't burning. Remove once crisp and golden brown. Some may feel a little tender in the middle but take them out and let them rest for 10 minutes or so to crisp up before sampling. Serve immediately.
TWICE BAKED SWEET POTATO WITH GROUND TURKEY
Here is another unconventional sweet potato recipe that my son John loves to make.
1 pound ground turkey, 2 large sweet potatoes, 1/4 cup hot sauce (John uses Buffalo Wild Wings Mild sauce), 1 yellow onion (diced), 1 garlic clove (minced), 2 tsps chipotle chili powder, 1 tsp ground red pepper, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp paprika, olive oil, salt and pepper.
Preheat your oven to 425 degrees. Cut your sweet potatoes in half lengthwise and put them face down on a cookie sheet. Put in the oven to cook for about 25-30 minutes depending how thick they are. You will know when they are done if they are easy to push on, on the skin side. If you pull them out early and the inside doesn't come out easily with a spoon, you'll need to cook them a bit longer. While your sweet potatoes cook, start a skillet over medium-high heat. Add a bit of olive oil to the hot pan then add your garlic and onions to start cooking down. Once the onions are translucent, add the ground turkey and use a large spoon to break it up to help cook it a bit quicker.

title: Monumental advice on eve of Trump's inauguration
author: MELINDA BURRELL
content:
Monumental advice on eve of Trump's inauguration

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MELINDA BURRELL | Section: Columns 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I love watching the brides pose for photos by the Lincoln Memorial and the teenagers wriggle through TikTok choreography near the Washington Monument. Their modern hopes breathe life into the centuries-old wisdom of our capital city.I have lived in Washington, D.C., for years and still can't get enough of it. On sunny Saturday morning walks, my pace is casual, but the insights are profound.
D.C. is a living lesson about what George Washington described as "the last great experiment for promoting human happiness."
The inauguration brings new people to Washington, and I hope they will love and learn from the city as much as I do.
One of my favorite monuments is near the Capitol. Two iron cranes stand together. Their wings thrust upward and barbed wire falls from their beaks. Around them is a complicated mix of names: Japanese Americans who died fighting for us in World War II, and the internment camps to which their families and friends had been forced.
Yet I am fiercely proud to be an American when, amidst these names, I read President Reagan's words: "Here we admit a wrong. Here we affirm our commitment as a nation to equal justice under the law."
Few countries I've lived in have the strength to admit such a grave national error.
That urge for improvement is in our national genes. As the Constitution states, we're constantly trying to "form a more perfect union."
Sure enough, a few miles away under a white marble dome stands a statue of Thomas Jefferson. He, too, speaks to us of striving for perfection: "… Laws and institutions must go hand in hand with the progress of the human mind. As that becomes more developed, more enlightened … institutions must advance also to keep pace with the times."
While I respect the somber challenge of those words, I love his next, more whimsical, sentence: "We might as well require a man to wear still the coat which fitted him when a boy as civilized society to remain ever under the regimen of their barbarous ancestors."
From a breezy hill in northeast Washington, D.C., President Lincoln also challenges us. It's the cottage where he and his family escaped the city's summer heat, though Lincoln daily commuted to the White House. His dusty horseback ride revealed the stakes of the Civil War: wounded soldiers bumping along in ambulances and former slaves surviving in hastily built camps after escaping behind Union lines.
Lincoln welcomed allies and adversaries alike to the cottage for advice, sometimes looking out from the veranda over the not-yet-completed Capitol and Washington Monument. As a modern visitor 150 years later, I can stand in the same place. The buildings are completed. But which of Lincoln's hopes and fears are still in progress?
At a newer memorial, Martin Luther King, Jr offers optimism about the timescale of our national effort: "We shall overcome because the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice."
At an even newer memorial closer to the Capitol, President Eisenhower puts a worldwide spin on our work of becoming a more perfect union: "We look upon this shaken earth, and we declare our firm and fixed purpose — the building of a peace with justice in a world where moral law prevails."
Strolling through the city, I love listening to leaders from different periods of our great experiment. I hope our elected representatives will as well.

title: State says no to granite curbs in Maryland town
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
State says no to granite curbs in Maryland town

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the struggle between historic sidewalks in Port Deposit and the Americans with Disabilities Act, the ADA wins, according to the Maryland State Highway Administration.SHA has two projects in progress in Port Deposit; one to remediate flooding and the second to make stretches of sidewalk handicapped accessible. This will mean either leveling heaving granite stones or removing them entirely.
Vicky Rinkerman, town administrator, said that in this early phase SHA engineers have reported that the town's existing historic granite sidewalks and curbing are central to the study.
"Their intent is to keep as much granite as possible," Rinkerman said. "However, they are looking for the most ADA compliant sidewalks."
That, she said, will mean a loss of granite curbing in areas where that ADA compliance will come into play. She added that the engineers offered no suggestions to the town on how to preserve what is not part of the project scope.
"We may look at other towns," she said.
One section of sidewalk on the north end of town will likely shift to skirt a utility pole. While many homes along Port Deposit's Main Street come right up to the sidewalk, Rinkerman said 145 North Main has some wiggle room. That will allow for a wider sidewalk in that area.
Meanwhile, the SHA's drainage remediation study is also early in its process but town officials are voicing concern. Rinkerman will meet with SHA March 20.
"We will be asking about the culverts," she told the mayor and town council. "We want to confirm their exact plan designs for the drain in Vannort Drive."
Questions to be answered by the SHA include whether or not there would there be a flap gate to prevent back flow, and if the catch basin and the drain pipe need to be enlarged.
Rinkerman said the town has time to prove its case with SHA since the state agency won't begin any physical work until 2027 at the earliest.

title: Civility on Easton Town Council
author: Staff Writer
content:
Civility on Easton Town Council

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 339
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Don Abbatielo has served on the Town Council representing Ward 2 for four years. During that time when the council presidency was open, his fellow council members voted him unanimously to be the interim president. He is intelligent, thoughtful, well versed in town issues, and, perhaps most important, listens respectfully to those who serve with him on the council and also to those bringing concerns to the council.He brings civility to a difficult job.
At the time, he did not run for president of the Town Council, as he was very busy with his family. Now he is ready to take on the extra work. His fellow council members are still supporting him for president. They are not supporting the present president of the council who is running again.
Don has been a high school teacher for 27 years in Dorchester schools and a volunteer firefighter for the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, where he rose in the ranks to become president of the fire department.
After knocking on a lot of doors and talking to groups, Don enumerated at a meet and greet what people care the most about and how he plans to deal with these concerns.
First, smart development which means that no more development or annexation will occur until the 1,000 units that are in the pipeline have been built. He will also see to it that the Town Council is included in any future discussions about when and where to build.Second, make it easier to access medical care in Easton. There are not enough doctors here to serve not only Talbot County but also surrounding counties whose residents come to our Memorial Hospital. He will ask University of Maryland Medical System and Anne Arundel Medical Center, what they are doing today to promote doctors to come to Easton.Finally, he also listed issues such as traffic; search for qualified candidates for Easton Police Department; and promotion of the new Easton Volunteer Fire Department training facility.Last but not least, civility on the Town Council, is high on his list.
LENA GILL
Easton

title: Ruth Candace Prossner
content:
Ruth Candace Prossner

 August 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 ROYAL OAK - We are saddened to announce the passing of Ruth Candace Prossner, age 79, of Royal Oak, MD, on August 05, 2023, due to complications of Parkinson's disease.Known for her candor and wit, Candace, lived a life centered around family and friends, especially her four boys.She was an avid reader who worked for the Talbot and Caroline County school systems before retiring as an office manager for Monnen Technology in Easton, MD.Born in Utica, NY on July 26, 1944, to Raymond and Ruth Mellen, Candace was the youngest of five siblings, all of whom have predeceased her. Candace is survived by David, her husband of 51 years, and her four sons, Mark of Great Falls, MT, Gregory (Renee) of Annapolis, MD, Brent (Stephanie) of Annapolis, MD, and Jed (Caitlin) of Kent Island, MD, along with eight grandchildren: Sophie, Paxton, Finley, Dashel, Isla, Henry, Cora and Dael.A private ceremony will be held with her family. title: Women to Watch event recognizes more than 200 local leaders
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Women to Watch event recognizes more than 200 local leaders

 April 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 713
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — More than 250 women gathered at The Avalon Theatre Wednesday to celebrate the unveiling of the annual Women to Watch magazine. From lawyers, to entrepreneurs, to nurses, to educators, a wide swath of the Mid-Shore was represented at this APG Chesapeake event.The women honored at the event were selected through community nominations, with criteria like community service, professional accomplishment and personal achievement being considered. More than 200 women from the Mid-Shore region were nominated.
"I think it highlights all the work that everybody in the community does and just how powerful our community of women are," said nominee Kari Mielke Clow, principal at Chapel District Elementary.
Of the nominees, 16 women were selected by the Women to Watch committee to be featured in this year's Women to Watch magazine, which profiles impactful work being done by women in the Mid-Shore community.
There were three featured speakers at the event — Ivette Furneisen, lawyer; Sharon Pepukayi, superintendent of Talbot County Public Schools; and Meisha Amia, nurse, author and entrepreneur.
Furneisen is from Barcelona. She used her native language, Spanish, to help the Hispanic immigrant community navigate the legal system. Being from Spain, she too had to wrestle with visas, employment authorization and becoming a resident, she said. Already a lawyer in Spain when she moved to the U.S., she had to go to law school a second time to practice as a lawyer in Maryland.
"During COVID I had this clever idea, with a 6-month-old at my house, to go back to law school," she said. "So I did it. I have been able to help a lot of people."
Furneisen recently opened her law practice, Campbell and Furneisen Law Firm, in Chestertown.
In closing she said, "It is on all of us to make sure the next generation of women are as strong as we are."
Pepukayi, who spoke after Furneisen, talked about what motivated her on her path to her position to superintendent.
She said she learned from the courage, confidence and communication skills of strong women who surrounded her.
"The courage for me to take risks, to fail forward, to laugh at my mistakes, to dust myself off and get back up when I got knocked down, to apply for jobs that I knew I would have to work really, really hard for," she said.
"The confidence to share my far-fetched ideas, to walk into a room where I was the only person that looked like me, but to know I could contribute and make a difference," Pepukayi continued. "And being communicative to share my vulnerable stories, to be transparent even when it is not good news and to meet and mentor other young women… to seek to understand rather than to be understood."
She extolled the audience to help each other and to not let jealousy get in the way. She asked them to mentor younger women as they had been mentored.
The final speaker was Amia, a writer, labor and delivery nurse, and entrepreneur.
As a travel nurse with over 40 assignments, "I treated my road trips like a 90-day evaluations on the job. I am getting things done, and I am like, 'Girl you have got to grow,'" Amia said.
"The most important thing I am going to tell you today is do not be afraid to wander. Just because your path is different, it doesn't mean that you are lost. Your path is preparing you for purpose."
There were many sponsors of the event, including Easton Economic Development, Easton Utilities, Pohanka Automotive Group, Wye Financial Partners, Queenstown Landing, Shore Legal Access, Parker Counts, The Ivy, All in the Mix Bakeshop and Ruby's.
APG Chesapeake made a $5,000 donation to Foundation of Hope, a nonprofit organization providing cultural, spiritual, social and educational trainings to girls in middle school through an after-school program aimed at helping girls to become leaders.
"The event really came together early this year — we sold out a week prior," said Betsy Griffin, assistant regional manager for sales at APG Chesapeake. "The speakers were fascinating and each offered snappy pieces of solid advice. How fun to watch the nominee's stand with a cheering section behind them during the event.
"Next year we hope to incorporate a level of mentoring for young people and are so appreciative of Foundation of Hope, as they do this type of important work," Griffin continued.

title: Reimagining Thanksgiving leftovers
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
Reimagining Thanksgiving leftovers

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 4A | Section: News 
 
 1228
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thanksgiving leftovers are just as good the next day or a couple of days later.Even Thanksgiving Eve, folks are looking in the fridge or under the covered dishes for a bite.I used to make individual platters, consisting of each food to be heated in the microwave, carried to work, or sent home with someone.Check on that elderly neighbor, or shut-in, or just someone living alone, and deliver a plate. As you sit around the table with family and friends give thanks for all our blessings, no matter how great or how small.Remember those who are serving our country at home and abroad. Remember those working Thanksgiving so we can be home.Remember the law enforcement officers, the hospital staff, the firemen and fire women, the EMT personnel - anyone who volunteered to work today so others could enjoy this day with family and others. We are all thankful for your continued service to us and our families.I know the cooks have already decided what type of meat to cook for Thanksgiving dinner, so I decided to do the leftover recipes today in preparation for the days after the big meal. We all tend to cook more than needed for two reasons - better to have more than needed rather than run out and we can eat leftovers for the rest of the weekend!Maybe you had turkey for dinner with the possibility of many dishes to create - turkey soup, hot turkey sandwiches with gravy, turkey salad, turkey chili and one of my favorites, the Bobbie sandwich.Maybe you cooked a large beef roast with plenty left over to make beef vegetable soup, hot roast beef sandwiches and beef cubes with gravy over rice. Enjoy the leftovers with much less stress. Now, let's get to some Black Friday shopping!TURKEY CARCASS SOUPPut parts of the turkey carcass in a large pot with 8 cups of turkey or chicken broth, 1 head of garlic (halved), 2 bay leaves and 2 sprigs of thyme.In a large Dutch oven, cut carcass to fit in the pot and add enough water to cover only by an inch. Bring to a boil over medium high heat.Simmer, uncovered about 40 minutes. Remove the carcass and add 2 cups dry diced turkey meat, 2 cups frozen corn, 2 cups frozen green beans (cut into 1-inch pieces), salt and pepper to taste, and 1 cup small dry pasta. Cover and cook for another 15 minutes.I usually add 1/2 cup chopped celery and 1/2 cup diced onions.TURKEY POT PIE2 tablespoons butter, 1 onion (chopped), 2 stalks celery (chopped), 3 carrots (chopped), 4 tbsp flour, 4 cups chicken or turkey stock, 2 potatoes (peeled and diced), 2 cups shredded turkey, 2 tablespoons chopped parsley, 1/2 cup frozen peas (thawed), 1 prepared pie crust, 1 egg (lightly beaten). Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.Melt butter in a saucepan, and cook chopped onion until tender. Stir in celery and carrots and cook for 2 minutes. Stir in flour and cook for 2 minutes. Add chicken stock and bring to a simmer. Add potatoes and simmer until tender.Stir in turkey, parsley and peas. Pour mixture into the casserole. Top with pie crust and brush with egg.Bake for 30 minutes until the crust is golden.THANKSGIVING LEFTOVER HAND PIESOne 14.1-ounce package store-bought pie crust, all-purpose flour for dusting, 1/4 cup leftover mashed sweet potatoes, 1/2 cup leftover stuffing, 1/2 cup 1/4-inch diced leftover roasted turkey, 1/4 cup leftover cranberry sauce (plus more for dipping), 1 large egg, 1 teaspoon whole milk, leftover gravy (for dipping). Preheat the oven to 350 degrees and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Roll out the pie crusts with a rolling pin on a lightly floured surface to 1/8-inch thick. Cut out rounds of dough with a 4 1/2-inch round biscuit cutter and transfer them to the prepared baking sheet. Gather and re-roll the scraps if necessary; you should have a total of 12 rounds. Spread 1 tsp sweet potato in an even layer over half of each round, leaving a 1/4-inch border around the edge. Top each with 2 tsps stuffing, then 2 tsps turkey, and finally 1 tsp cranberry sauce. You may redistribute some of the filling among the rounds so all the piles are even. Whisk together the egg and milk in a small bowl to make an egg wash. Brush the egg wash around the edges of each dough round. Fold over each dough round to cover the filling, creating 12 half-moon shapes.With your fingers, press the edges together to seal, and then press with a fork to seal securely. Brush the top of each hand pie with the remaining egg wash. Make 3 small slits with a small paring knife on the top of each pie to let the steam escape. Bake until the dough is cooked through and golden brown, about 30 minutes. Serve warm with extra cranberry sauce and gravy on the side for dipping.BOBBIE SANDWICHSandwiches are extremely popular for leftovers because there's usually so much turkey or ham! What makes these simple and easy is because you already have the major ingredients. A popular one in my family is the Bobbie.It's a turkey hoagie or sub with stuffing, cranberry sauce sub. Grab a bag of your favorite sub rolls or buns and use your leftover turkey dinner dishes.The ingredients you need are mayonnaise, slices of roast turkey, stuffing, cranberry sauce, salt and pepper to taste. Using a 9-inch to a 20-inch sub roll, lay the sub roll open and smear with mayonnaise.On top of the mayo, place thin slices of turkey - as much as you like. Try shredding the turkey so it looks like shredded beef or pork. On top of the turkey, place leftover stuffing and on top of the stuffing place cranberry sauce. Put as much of the fillings that you want. Roll the sandwich together and serve immediately. This sub does not need to be warm and tastes better cold.THANKSGIVING LEFTOVER NACHOS1 cup sour cream, 1 tbsp minced chipotle chili in adobo (plus more sauce for serving), 10 cups tortilla chips, 2 cups shredded leftover turkey meat, 3 cups shredded cheddar, 2 cups shredded Monterey jack cheese, 2 cups thinly sliced leftover cooked Brussels sprouts, 1 1/2 cups leftover cubed roasted butternut squash, 1 cup packaged french-fried onions, 1 cup lightly packed cilantro leaves or parsley leaves, 1/2 cup sliced black olives, 1/4 cup chopped pickled jalapenos.Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Stir the sour cream and chipotle chili together in a small bowl. Cover with plastic wraps and refrigerate.Scatter half the chips on a rimmed baking sheet.Top with one-third of the turkey, cheeses, Brussels sprouts, butternut squash and fried onions. Scatter the remaining chips on top followed by the remaining two-thirds of turkey, cheeses, Brussels sprouts and fried onions. Bake until the cheeses are melted and bubbly, about 5 to 7 minutes.Drizzle the nachos with chipotle sour cream and extra adobo sauce. Garnish with cilantro, black olives and jalapenos.I'd like to wish everyone a safe, happy and healthy Thanksgiving! Please take the time to check on your shut in or elderly neighbors as they might not be as fortunate as others. There is nothing that puts a smile on someone's face like a nice big plate of food!As you sit down together at the Thanksgiving dinner table give thanks for all that we have and bless the hands who prepared this meal. Next week we take a trip back in time to the family farm. I'm thankful for all my readers, and God bless you all. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES
 
Thanksgiving leftovers can be reimagined in a variety of ways.

title: Whoville 'Mayor' Launches Fifth Annual Family Event
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com

Whoville 'Mayor' Launches Fifth Annual Family Event

 GREENSBORO - The misting rain held off as Whoville Honorary Mayor Doug Gray of Burrsville opened the fifth annual event 5 p.m. Friday, Dec. 1, at the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company Community Hall."Behold, citizens of Greensboro," Gray proclaimed."The most magical time of the year has arrived.The Greensboro Whoville Village Holiday Park is back, more magnificent and grand than ever before.""You see our big Whoville sign, but wait till it's dark; you can see it from space, I'm pretty sure," Greensboro Mayor David Spencer said."We're really proud that the fire company has partnered with us to allow us to move over here."Despite the forecast and the light rain that began a half-hour into opening night, visitors showed up to walk the 2,000-foot winding path past inflatables, about 50,000 lights and the Grinch's lair to enjoy the free festive holiday display hosted by the Town of Greensboro."We wish the weather could be a little better, but at least it's not freezing cold," Spencer said.The event takes place over the next two weekends.For the faint-of-heart intimidated by the Grinch's dreary lair, visitors had the option of walking along the outside of it. However, the Grinch, with his trademark onion, seemed fairly harmless as he sported a necklace made of Christmas lights.Over the past five years, town employees and volunteers have put on the event, adding elements and improving the experience.This is the second year the holiday village has been set up at the hall.Potential flooding from the Choptank River prompted organizers to move the popular event to higher ground last year.Inside the hall, about 15 local vendors had set up tables. By the last weekend of Whoville, there will be about 25, according to Town Manager Tammy Kelledes. Visitors could purchase hamburgers, hot dogs and drinks from the GVFC Auxiliary.Among the nearly two dozen volunteers were Spencer's grandchildren."It's a family affair," Spencer's wife Cathy said.Also represented were Public Works Director Brandon Cunningham's son and Community Outreach Coordinator Amanda Weaver's son, who volunteered as elves.Their job? "To spread Christmas joy," Weaver said, smiling.Santa and Mrs. Claus greeted children in their cozy shed decorated by Brandon Cunningham's wife Katie Beebe-Cunningham.Although Santa Claus had seen only a few children during the first hour of the village festivities, he said he saw about 1,500 children last year on the first night of Whoville. Mrs. Claus said they usually gravitate towards her first, and then feel more at ease to visit the jolly old elf.At the end of the path was a silhouette Nativity scene set up by Greater Impact Church in Greensboro.It's been about a month of work for the town employees who set up Whoville this year.Public safety was top of mind for organizers, and Greensboro Police and Caroline County Emergency Services were on site.Although the town relies on sponsors and donations, it has yet to break even on the cost of putting on the event, Kelledes said."This splendorous affair is all thanks to the generous donations and in-kind contributions from our beloved community businesses and citizens," Honorary Mayor Gray proclaimed."It's a time to cherish with your loved ones, sip cocoa, and get lost in a wonderland of lights."For more information about Greensboro Whoville Village Holiday Park, visit the Town of Greensboro's Facebook page, call 410-482-6222, text 443-239-4160 or email aweaver@greensboromd.com.

title: Tench Tilghman: A Talbot County-born revolutionary hero
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Tench Tilghman: A Talbot County-born revolutionary hero

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 795
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — One of George Washington's most trusted men has roots in Talbot County, and this week he was celebrated by a local chapter of the Maryland Society of the Sons of the American Revolution.The SAR's Colonel Tench Tilghman Chapter honored its namesake after receiving proclamations from Easton and Talbot County for the inaugural Tench Tilghman Week from Oct. 19 to 24.
Tilghman, born in Talbot County in 1744 and educated there during his youth, was a primary aide-de-camp for Washington during the Revolutionary War. Wes Hagood, chapter president, has deeply researched Tilghman and his critical role as one of Washington's right-hand men.
In 1776, Tilghman joined Washington's staff. Washington often referred to him as "family" in written letters, Hagood said.
"He became, in a lot of ways, like a son to Washington," Hagood said. "… They carried on a relationship until Tilghman died."
Tilghman's calling card was his duty of delivering the notice of British surrender following the Battle of Yorktown. Surrender came on Oct. 19, 1781, and Tilghman arrived in Philadelphia on Oct. 24 to confirm the news to the Continental Congress.
"It's probably one of his most recognizable accomplishments," Hagood said.
Hagood described Tilghman as "hard working" and smart, adding that he "probably would have had a role in the future government had he lived." He provided leadership to patriot soldiers and often was responsible for finding food to sustain the troops, Hagood said.
In a letter to Continental Army General John Sullivan in 1781, Washington spoke highly of Tilghman.
"This gentleman came out a captain of one of the light infantry companies of Philadelphia, and served in the flying camp in 1776," Washington wrote. "In August of the same year he joined my family, and has been in every action in which the main army was concerned. He has been a zealous servant and slave to the public, and a faithful assistant to me for nearly five years, a great part of which time he refused pay."
Following the victory, a portrait of Washington was commissioned in 1781, depicting Tilghman and Marquis de Lafayette. Maryland-born Charles Willson Peale painted the portrait, which is displayed today in the Maryland State House.
Tilghman died in 1786, leaving behind his spouse, who spent many decades thereafter in Oxford on Tilghman's father's plantation. Today, Tilghman is buried at the Oxford Cemetery after being reinterred in 1971 from his original burial site in Baltimore.
MARYLAND 400
Hagood, who has read all of the letters Tench Tilghman wrote to his father during the war, pointed out the Talbot County native's critical role in the Battle of Brooklyn in 1776. At that battle, a larger and more experienced British army posed a significant threat to patriot troops.
Owen Lourie, "Finding the Maryland 400" project director at the Maryland State Archives, calls that the "first major battle." Lourie says the troops known as the Maryland 400, along with some from Pennsylvania and Delaware, reformed to attack the enemy after a damaging British charge.
While there were massive casualties, Lourie says the Maryland 400 "bottled up" the British and prevented them from delivering a "final death blow" to the other continental soldiers that were escaping.
"It is probably not too much of an exaggeration to say that they saved the Continental Army," Lourie said.
Witness to the heroic efforts, Tilghman applauded the Col. William Smallwood's 1st Maryland Regiment, Lourie notes. "No Regular Troops ever made a more gallant Resistance than Smallwood's Regiment," Tilghman wrote in a memoir.
Lourie and the Maryland State Archives are working to identify and write biographies on as many of those soldiers as possible. There were more than 1,000 Maryland troops, and his historian work has helped identify over 800. He says he's focused on "telling the small stories" of those Marylanders that may not have been thought of in hundreds of years.
Lourie is presenting a history of the Maryland 400 at the Talbot County Free Library on Saturday at 11 a.m., an event sponsored by the Tench Tilghman Chapter which wraps up Tench Tilghman Week.
Dana Newman, library director, says registration is open online at tcfl.org, with limited spots remaining. It will also be livestreamed on Talbot Library's YouTube channel.
Hagood is excited for Tench Tilghman Week to return next October and for years to come.
"What better way would there be for us as a chapter to fulfill our mission of educating current and future generations about all of this than to have a week dedicated to Colonel Tench Tilghman," Hagood said. "And this year, just start with one event. But the idea is, we'll do this every year."
Following the Maryland 400 presentation on Saturday, a free program on how to join the Sons of the American Revolution and Daughters of the American Revolution will be held at the Talbot County Free Library from 2 to 4 p.m. in the Frederick Douglass Room.

title: Maritime Museum hosts watermen's stories
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Maritime Museum hosts watermen's stories

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Business 
 
 992
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A crowd of 100 people gathered at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on Jan. 11 to hear story swaps from seven watermen.Big storms and big hauls were remembered, as were the regulations, cost of gas and Venezuelan crab meat that made net profits difficult.
These salty tales from yesterday were moderated by Brent Lewis.
This was a rock star moment for these men and one woman, who normally get up way before dawn and head out in the darkness to find oysters and crabs. The crowd listened attentively and often gave hearty laughs.
Waterman and politician George O'Donnell offered the age-old chestnut, "If you don't know how to cuss, you buy a work boat, and you will learn real fast."
The event was recorded for posterity by the museum at the Van Lennep Auditorium, and it was sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center. On top of the 100 guests present, there were another 30 on Zoom.
Being a waterman is tough. There is no job security. There is no health insurance. If they get injured, they are out of work, and there certainly is no pension or 401(k).
"If you wake up a watermen, every day you wake up with nothing all over again. You gotta be a welder, you gotta be a carpenter, you gotta be a mechanic, you gotta be a bookkeeper," O'Donnell said.
And yet there is a glimmer in the eyes of these watermen who love it.
The watermen speaking at the event included George O'Donnell, Calvert Thompson, Jeff Harrison, Rachel Fazenbaker, Eugene Austin, Joey Sadler and Troy Wilkins. From Miles River to Love Point to Harris Creek and many secret nooks on the Bay, they worked many different rivers on the Eastern Shore.
Sometimes there are big storms with 50 knots of wind and lightning. If you are out there, there is no place to hide, they said. More than one described the momentary blindness that comes after a big lightning strike out on the water.
The watermen shared the stories of times they thought they might not make it back to shore.
"I had a five gallon bucket, and I was bailing for all I could. The floor opened up and you could see where the gas had been at, but it was burning. Just flames, on top of the engine all the way to the canvas. It was a bad time for a few minutes there. I called up a friend and said, 'I have blowed up. I'm on fire' and he said, 'What?! What are you talking about?' He thought I was kidding. And then another boy up Mathews Creek he came along and towed me in after we got the fire out," Gene Austin said.
He continued, "I was sitting on the board, and I just started shaking. It just hit me. What had happened. To this day, I believe in guardian angels. When that heating block blowed up. I had a short sleeve shirt on and not one hair was burned," Austin said.
In sheer volume, the biggest waterman, Calvert Thompson, was nick named "Butterball." He had people in awe when he told the story of bailing out the cabin of a boat with five gallon buckets.
"There were 35 knot winds and seas were around 15 feet. We were early spring crabbin' in Cape Charles, Virginia. The tide ran so hard you couldn't see the buoys. You had to wait for the tide to slack up, and then you went as hard as you could go to fish your pots," Thompson said.
"And it was so rough that day that Raymond kept backing the boat up. We had scuppers in the back of the boat, when the water would come over the stern, it was just small holes in the back that would let water off of the gunnels. I had white boots on, and I had water over top of my boots from the floor up. I hollered up to the pilothouse and said, 'Raymond don't back up no more. Just sit. If he had backed up, we literally would have been gone. We were lucky."
One time when he was 23 or 24 years old, the engine died, so he stood on top of the cabin and threw the anchor as far as he could. Then he pulled the line in to move the boat. He said he went seven and half miles in two and a half hours until he was back home in Little Creek.
The one lady on the panel of watermen was Rachel Fazebaker. She could crack a joke and had the crowd going.
"When it starts blowing 20-25, I say bye boys," she said. "One time I was in five-foot seas and 30 mph winds and we were dredging. It completely unspooled, and we had to lower the boom. My knees were shaking the whole time. The captain taught me a lot that day and I said, 'I am not going out, not doing it. Not going out.' That captain taught me what not to do," she said.
As a 12-year-old, O'Donnell's mom would not let him crab out of Winchester Creek, where she could look out the window and make sure he was OK.
"Crabs were, number ones, were $8 a bushel. It was in my blood. It was all I knew. I was pretty much a capitalist, so once I found out you could make some money doing it, I kept doing it. That is all the incentive I needed, so when I went to the carnival, when I got where I could make five dollars a day, that was pretty good money," said O'Donnell.
The crowd oohed and ahhed with each story. When an hour had flown by, the master of ceremonies handed the microphone to the people in the crowd, who got to ask about five more questions, the most poignant being, "are you a dying breed?"
"Aren't there any young people doing this?"
The answer was sobering. The average age of a waterman now is 58.

 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers this session are debating their possible role in funding a high-speed rail project from Washington, D.C. to New York City, with some convinced the answer is clear: the state shouldn't have any role at all.Those who back the project continue to push for the construction of the Northeast Maglev, a high-speed rail that would run through Maryland on its course through the northeast.
But some Maryland lawmakers vow they won't let the state pay for one inch of it. Del. Nicole Williams (D-Prince George's) sponsored the measure this year that would have prohibited any state funding for the project, even though none has yet been requested.
"I felt like this project should not be built with their taxpayer money," said Williams. "It's a funding issue. It's also an impact issue of the communities that it will traverse through."
Maglev supporters consider it silly to debate a bill that would outlaw funding that no one has asked for. Williams' no-funding bill is currently stalled in committee, leading some Maglev fans to conclude a majority of the Maryland General Assembly is supportive of their high-speed rail project.
"I think the fact that the bill has been turned down (several) times tells you that it's not something that the General Assembly supports," said Wayne Rogers, Chairman and CEO of the Northeast Maglev project. Similar measures have been introduced since 2021.
For years, the U.S. has debated the idea of a high-speed rail system like the Northeast Maglev that would travel from New York City to Washington D.C. in just an hour. Maryland's leg of the trip would allow passengers to travel between Washington DC and Baltimore in just fifteen minutes, as opposed to the hour it currently takes.
High-speed transit is a popular concept, in theory. Some 63% of Americans said they would use high-speed trains if they were available in the U.S., according to a 2015 study by the American Public Transportation Association.
However, decades since the idea was first proposed, little progress has been made in constructing these high-speed railways. Lawmakers and advocates disagree about what's preventing the project from making headway, though.
In the 1970s, Robert Embry, the former Baltimore Housing commissioner, was invited to Japan to study their new railroad technology known as magnetic levitation, a step up from bullet trains. Embry came back home and promoted the Maglev project in its earliest days.
"My view was that America's ground transportation was inadequate and too slow and that this was the new technology," Embry told Capital News Service.
Embry said that even today, this sort of high-speed rail could have a "significant benefit" to Maryland, encouraging tourism and commercial growth in Baltimore.
Connecting Washington and Baltimore via high-speed rail may not be so simple, though. First, getting federal funding requires an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), said Embry. This comes from Maryland residents concerned with the project's alignment and whether it travels through their communities.
Funding issues aren't the sole reason the Maglev project hasn't broken ground yet, according to Rogers, the Maglev CEO. The project has to go through a "review and approval process with 30 federal, state and local agencies" before it can get permitted.
The Maglev project, which would run completely underground, would give commuters the opportunity to travel between Washington and Baltimore without the use of crowded roadways, Rogers said.
"We're not 10 years behind on our infrastructure, we're 50 years behind," he said. "If we don't do something, we're drowning in congestion. We're eliminating economic opportunities because we can't even connect two cities that are 30 miles apart."
As it stands, the Maglev project would not rely at all on state funding; it would be solely funded by Japanese private enterprise and U.S. government loan and grant programs. However, Maglev officials say they don't want to rule out the possibility if the project faces funding concerns in the future.
"While this project is not immediately requesting dollars from the state, the conversation is about the possibility of — in the future — the state supporting the project financially," said Maglev advocate Adrian Harpool of the Maryland Minority Business Counts Initiative.
Supporters of the project emphasized the need to keep improving transit options in Maryland.
"The bill would signal that the state is closed to innovative, future-oriented solutions to worsening transportation challenges," said Ian Rainey, senior vice president of the Baltimore-Washington Rapid Rail.
While a high-speed rail might be needed in some parts of the U.S., some question whether it's necessary in Maryland.
The sponsor of the Senate version of the bill, Sen. Alonzo T. Washington (D-Prince George's) said there are opportunities for high-speed rail elsewhere in the country, but he opposes the project in Maryland.
"It is not needed. We believe the MARC train is doing exactly what this project is trying to do," Washington said in the Senate bill hearing.
Williams said she plans to keep bringing up her no-funding bill until it passes. "I will continue to fight for this issue."

title: EPA announces historic funding for Chesapeake Bay restoration
author: BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service
content:
EPA announces historic funding for Chesapeake Bay restoration

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ARLINGTON, Va. — The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced Wednesday that $206 million in funding will be allocated towards projects aimed at continuing the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay.The historic levels of funding reflect the Biden administration's increased investments in environmental programs and infrastructure projects.
"For a long time, the EPA's budget has been so small, roughly about $10 billion a year," EPA Assistant Deputy Administrator Mark Rupp said during a ceremony at the recently-built Lubber Run Community Center here. "Between the
Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and the Inflation Reduction Act, there's now over $100 billion flowing through our agency, and it really has been a game changer."
With $96 million of the funds coming from President Joe Biden's so-called "Investing in America" agenda alone, the announcement marked the largest single contribution to the Chesapeake Bay Program in its 41-year history.
Maryland is expected to receive over $14 million from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation's share of the funds, which in turn makes up 40 individual grant projects.
Grant recipients include the Baltimore Tree Trust, which plans to educate city residents about planting trees in their communities.
The Severn River Association will be another recipient. The organization intends to increase and improve stormwater treatment practices on the Severn River, which flows into the Chesapeake Bay in Annapolis.
"Agendas matter, elected officials matter, vision matters," Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Virginia) said. "For the sake of the country, thank God we have the 117th Congress and Joe Biden to sign those bills into law."
Attending the ceremony were not only federal officials and members of Congress but also legislators from state and local governments around the Chesapeake Bay.
Libby Garvey, chair of the Arlington County Board, said funds are going to be used in her community on a small tributary called Grandma's Creek.
"(The Grandma's Creek project) is a great example of community involvement and advocacy for a beloved neighborhood stream," Garvey said. "This project is going to propose the installation of rain gardens to better manage stormwater and increase the protection of the creek."
In addition to rain gardens, the Arlington community will also have the opportunity to participate in organized tree plantings and pop-up educational events centered around nature, Garvey said. The funds for these projects will be derived from the Small Watershed Grants Program, one of three grant programs administered by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, which is to receive $193 million of the $206 million.
The NFWF already has announced it will be giving $1 million to farmers in Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia, with the intention of implementing high-priority conservation practices that improve water quality.
"There are 40,000 farms in Pennsylvania, and many of them contribute nutrients and sediment to the bay," Rep. Don Beyer (D-Virginia) said. "So anything we can do to get Pennsylvania on board with Maryland, Virginia and Delaware will be incredibly important."
The Chesapeake Bay Trust, another non-profit grant-making organization, will receive the remaining $13 million from the EPA. The trust will use the money to assist local organizations involved with improving the bay.
This could include providing operational infrastructure like computers and other hardware, or funding employee training and professional development sessions.
"We have to do better on agricultural runoff, and we have to do better on stormwater runoff. We do well on sewage treatment and on other point source pollution," Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Virginia) told Capital News Service. "This $200 million is going to be heavily focused on grants that focus on non-point sources, and we should continue to see significant improvements."
