title: Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities
author: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service
content:
Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 816
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Black and Hispanic communities are underrepresented among university faculty at Maryland's six largest public universities, according to the 2021 Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS).This analysis does not include Maryland's online universities or historically black colleges and universities.IPEDS is an annual data collection system run through the U.S. Department of Education.These findings align with trends across the country, data shows.The U.S. Census projects that 32% of Maryland's population are Black and 12% are Hispanic.At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs - University of Maryland, Baltimore County; University of Maryland, College Park; Towson University; Frostburg State University; Salisbury University and St. Mary's College of Maryland-less than 6% of the total faculty are Black and less than 5% are Hispanic, as of 2021.According to Laura Perna, Vice Provost for Faculty at University of Pennsylvania and a researcher on college access, faculty underrepresentation is a widespread issue, though the specifics differ by university.Across Maryland, faculty demographics vary widely. At Towson University, 7% of faculty were Black in fall 2021 and 3% were Hispanic. At Frostburg State University, those numbers were about halved, with 4% Black faculty and almost 1% Hispanic faculty.Prior to 2022, Maryland's education code allowed individual public universities to implement their own plans for "cultural diversity," which ranged in length and breadth. In 2022, a new code was instituted, requiring public universities to ensure that faculty, staff, and administration demographics reflect the state's diverse population.Between 2016 and 2021, the percentages of Black and Hispanic faculty at the universities included in the analysis both increased by just under a percentage point."It really is amazing how little progress there has been in some ways on this," said Perna.According to Dr. Kimberly Griffin, Dean of University of Maryland's College of Education, many people assume that faculty will diversify alongside the student body. This "trickle up" system is unrealistic, she says.The problem is multifaceted, says Griffin. Academia is tasked with generating a pool, hiring inclusively, yielding candidates, onboarding hirees, retaining them, and ultimately, promoting them. "We have to do more in all of those spaces," says Griffin, whose research has focused on issues of diversity, equity and inclusion in post-secondary education.According to Perna, one roadblock is "invisible labor" faculty of color often take on work that requires time and energy, but does not fit academia's standard promotion metrics."We should be looking at to what extent our definition of merit is very narrow," said Perna.Underrepresented minorities often spend more time serving on committees and mentoring students of color, labor that often goes unrecognized, says Perna. Come time for promotions, publications and course evaluations are weighted more heavily.As the student body has diversified, the gap between representation among students and faculty has widened, straining faculty of color.As of fall 2021, Black students made up 17% and Hispanic students made up 8% of the student body at the universities included in the CNS analysis. That was an increase of 10% and 19% since 2016, respectively.Faculty demographics remained stable.In 2021, the resulting ratio of Black students to Black faculty members was 60:1. The ratio of white students to white faculty members was 15:1.According to Griffin, while it's crucial for students of color to have role models and mentors of color, there isn't enough faculty of color to shoulder that responsibility alone."That's a load everyone should share," she said.A lack of diversity also impacts faculty of color pursuing tenure. At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs, in 2021, 71% of tenured professors were white, 5% Black, and 4% were Hispanic, according to IPEDS.A lack of diversity among tenured faculty can make it harder for some faculty of color to find mentors as they pursue tenure, though many members of academia, like Griffin, are trying to combat this by developing intentional mentoring policy."Mentorship that helps you build a sense of connection and community in your unit and in your college is also really important for helping folks get to tenure," said Griffin.Katharina Maisel, a bioengineering professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, co-authored a list of best practices for increasing diversity alongside several other faculty members in the STEM field.According to Maisel, diversifying the faculty, especially tenure and tenure track, takes intention at every stage of the process, from inviting people to apply, inviting people for internships, and checking your shortlist to make sure you're not just inviting people from Ivy League schools.But it's possible.In science, technology, engineering and math, says Maisel, a tendency to be overspecific in job listings can discourage faculty from underrepresented backgrounds.Using rubrics to evaluate a candidate for hiring or promotion can help ensure an objective set of criteria, helping reel in internal biases, Maisel said."If you as a department are really actively interested in increasing the diversity of your faculty, there are things you can do," Maisel said.

author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County Animal Shelter seeing success

 March 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 702
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County animals continue to be in "good paws" as officials presented updates to ensure the safety and wellbeing of those in their care to the Queen Anne's Board of County Commissioners Feb 27.The Queen Anne's County Animal Control Commission introduced updates to the Animal Control Comprehensive plan, Chapter 9.
While there have certainly been changes over the years, the Animal Control ordinance has never seen a line by line holistic review of documents such as this before, said Jennifer Nowak, commission chair.
"It needed a major upgrade," she said.
Revisions were especially needed to make the ordinance more applicable for animal control cases, Nowak noted. The extensive revision includes housekeeping items and definition changes to make the documentation flow better.
Updates to the animal control ordinance include three full document reviews, hundreds of hours of work and strong collaboration from officials including Animal Control, emergency services and animal services, according to Nowak.
A public hearing regarding the ordinance is expected at the commissioner's March 26 meeting.
In other business, Queen Anne's County Animal Services presented 2023 overviews and 2024 projections to the county commissioners.
Animal Services Chief of Services Kelly Hamilton presented a year in review and projections for the shelter moving forward.
The shelter continues to lead the way in providing care care for forlorn animals of the Eastern Shore with an impact stronger than ever, she said. It was a very successful year of diligent volunteers, engaging events and successful community support, and 2024 only looks to continue.
The organization considers itself a quintessential no-kill shelter of the state of Maryland and the Eastern Shore, Hamilton said, with the live release rate determined by the number of animals leaving the shelter via adoption, returned to the owner or transferred to another shelter.
The national standard to be considered a no-kill shelter is 90%, and with a 94.6% rate, QACAS is proud to be one of 12 such shelters in Maryland, she said.
A total of 1,324 animals entered the county's shelter in 2023, whether as strays, seized or transferred in, a 29% increase from 2022, according to Hamilton.
Through QACAS, 679 animals found their "furr-ever" families in 2023, she announced.
Nearly 900 surgeries were performed onsite, ranging from routine neuters to life saving procedures.
The shelter has ramped up its social media presence, including facial recognition software to instrumentally connect owners and pets and help 166 animals find their way back home in 2023.
"It's amazing, the technology is there," Hamilton said.
Hamilton credited volunteers and foster families as the "true heroes" for their tireless dedication to the animals.
"It really takes our team to invest all this time and energy in these animals to get them ready for that adoption floor," she said.
Foster families are imperative to provide valuable insight into an animal's behavior outside of the shelter to provide "purr-fect" placement for prospective adopters.
Programs include doggy day trips in hopes of enticing new foster families with a day of play away from the kennels, which can often snowball into full blown adoptions.
IQACAS participated in a National Clear the Shelter Event to roaring success, seeing nearly 100 animals find homes in a very short amount of time, she said.
Other community events include Puppy Yoga, donation drives, and partnering with the Parks and Recreation Department for the first annual "Pawing in Love" Fun Run.
Moving forward, the shelter expects to see an increase in community involvement including school education programs and "bigger and better" fundraisers, Hamilton said.
The facility has undergone remodeling to include updated in house dental machines and a new lobby layout. The shelter is now home to new cat condos, improved yard spaces, and even surround sound speakers at the dog kennels to provide calming ambiance.
With its newly improved yard space, they plan to offer additional enrichment programs for dog training including daily doggie play groups.
A complimentary behaviorist class is available for all newly adopted dogs. This program will serve residents who may be considering surrendering animals to the shelter for behavioral concerns or are in need of training tips, according to Hamilton.
QACAS looks to continue leading the pack as a local No Kill Shelter with updated technology and infrastructure improvements to provide community critters the best care "pawsible."
More information about the QACAS, including upcoming events, can be found at qac.org/1425/Animal-Services.

title: Abbatiello, Rankin, Davis sworn in as Easton's new council sets off
author: Konner Metz
content:
Abbatiello, Rankin, Davis sworn in as Easton's new council sets off

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Family, friends and residents packed the council chambers Monday to watch three Easton Town Council members take the oath of office, including new president Don Abbatiello.Abbatiello, newly-elected Ward 2 representative Robert Rankin and returning Ward 4 representative the Rev. Elmer Davis were sworn in by Mayor Megan Cook, marking the start of council's first meeting with its new makeup.
Abbatiello defeated outgoing president Frank Gunsallus in a heated election on May 6. But all was cordial Monday night as Abbatiello shifted from his Ward 2 chair to the center seat on the dais.
The new council president thanked his wife and two kids, mother and sister, and town residents for their support during the campaign.
"We're facing a lot of challenges as a community," Abbatiello said. "Growth, housing, access to medical care, traffic — these are just some of the things that we heard during the campaign that people are really concerned about. We do have some challenges ahead of us. And I'm looking forward to working toward solutions to those challenges."
Abbatiello added of Gunsallus, "Even though we disagreed and were at odds during the election, I want to thank Mr. Gunsallus for his service to the community over the last two years."
Gunsallus, whose term as president began in 2023, provided remarks before shaking hands with the rest of the council at the start of Monday's meeting.
"We haven't always agreed, but we've always shared the same goal: to do what's best for Easton," Gunsallus said. "And for that, I am proud."
"To the new council, I wish you nothing but success as you take on the important work ahead," he added. "May you lead with wisdom, listen with compassion and help Easton grow in a way that honors its past and embraces its future. I have every confidence that this town is in good hands."
Easton residents came out in droves to vote on election day, with over 3,200 ballots cast, a town record for a municipal election. All three races were contested, but Abbatiello and Rankin secured decisive victories (69% of votes each) in two-person races while Davis won comfortably (54%) in a three-person race.
After the swearing-in ceremony, Cook said she believes voters "sent a clear message."
"They want to see respect and civility restored," Cook said. "They want their local leaders focused and working together collaboratively to address the needs of our community."
Following the meeting, council members shared excitement for the work ahead of them.
"I applaud all three of you for how you ran your campaigns, and I am delightful at the outcome," said Ward 1 representative Maureen Curry, who endorsed Abbatiello. "And I am so looking forward to working with all of you."
Ward 3's David Montgomery, who made a somewhat surprising endorsement of Abbatiello during the campaign, said voters demonstrated a want for "integrity, openness (and) clarity."
"I am looking forward very much to the next two years of working on this council and working together cooperatively, in a friendly manner, with respect for each other, even when we don't necessarily agree on everything," Montgomery said.

title: Frederick Douglass' Valentine's Day birthday honored by his family
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Frederick Douglass' Valentine's Day birthday honored by his family

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Frederick Douglass never knew his exact birthday.Like many born into slavery, the exact date was never recorded. Douglass knew it was sometime in February but not the exact day.
Douglass chose to celebrate on Valentine's Day because his mother called him her "little Valentine."
"Yes, he celebrated his birthday on Valentine's Day," Douglass' five-time great nephew Tarence Bailey Sr. said. "Feb. 14 through Feb. 20, you can say it's the most important week of Black History Month because that's the week of Frederick Douglass' birth and death."
Douglass has strong roots in Talbot County and throughout the Eastern Shore.
Born in Talbot County in 1818, Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey Douglass was enslaved for 20 years in Baltimore and on Talbot County farms. He fled north in 1838 and changed his name to Frederick Douglass. His brilliance, eloquence and courage, quickly brought him to the forefront of the abolitionist movement.
He was known for his skills as an orator, with many of his speeches remembered to this day.
"He spoke in Denton on Halloween 1883, and Douglas took the train from Wilmington to Denton," author and historian John Muller said. "Then when he was leaving and he spoke in front of the County Courthouse in Denton... there was so many people they didn't fit inside. The crowd had to go outside."
According to Muller, Douglass also spoke in Cambridge, St. Michaels, and many more Eastern Shore locales.
Douglass and his work are inspirational to many Americans, but it goes deeper than just inspiration for the Bailey-Groce Family Foundation, Bailey said.
The Bailey-Groce Family Foundation is run by multiple Douglass family members who grew up on the Eastern Shore. It is one of two family foundations operated by descendants of the Douglass bloodline.
"I think for my family here from Talbot County and from Eastern Shore as a whole, it's a whole lot different for us," Bailey said. "Being raised on the Shore and then having the relative like him, you look at it differently than the average person does."
Three years ago, the foundation started hosting a birthday celebration for Fredrick Douglas between Feb. 14 and 20, close to his birthday and the anniversary of his death. This year's celebration will be held on Feb. 22 due to a scheduling conflict.
The birthday celebration is held to help fundraise for an African American Cultural Center and an African American Historical Society, institutions the foundation plans to establish in Talbot County.
The event will begin at the historic Avalon Theatre at 3:45 p.m.
This year's event will feature a homecoming performance by Ayla Dennis, who was featured on American Idol.
"She's actually a Bailey family descendant," Bailey said. "So it's going to be a history making to have her singing at the Avalon, which was a formerly segregated theater down the street from where the slave auction once was, right there by the courthouse where Frederick Douglass spoke, having his relatives actually headlining for his birthday in a formerly segregated theater."
Other entertainment for Douglass' birthday celebration includes a county group from Atlanta, Georgia; a concert violinist from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; a featured poet from Brooklyn, New York; and many more.
After the performances, the foundation will host a VIP dinner at the Waterfowl Building in Easton. The foundation wants everyone to wear African-style clothing to honor Douglass' heritage.
"Frederick Douglass was a very classy dude. We like to keep his birthday the way he would want it," Bailey said. "He was John Q when it came to his clothes. Everything he wore was Brooks Brothers. So he was always dressed to the nines. So I know that at his birthday party, he would want everybody in there dressed as well as him."
The Foundation continues to host these types of events not just to raise funds, but to keep Douglass' legacy alive, Bailey said.
"Uncle Frederick is the main reason, the only reason that I that keeps me going, that keeps me pushing," Bailey Sr. said. "The goal is much bigger, Fredrick Douglass himself is the inspiration, because if it wasn't for him I don't know if we would have made it this far."
For more information about the celebration or to purchase tickets, visit avalonfoundation.org/events.

title: House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan
author: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The House Committee on Education and the Workforce has advanced a Republican-sponsored bill that includes measures repealing key aspects of the Biden administration's plans to make college more affordable.The College Cost Reduction Act, introduced by the panel's chairwoman, Rep. Virginia Foxx (R-North Carolina), passed on a party-line 22-19 vote.
The measure presents numerous programs intended to strengthen the integrity of higher education institutions across the country, but also would gut much of President Joe Biden's efforts to help students afford college. Democrats on the committee offered a series of amendments to the bill aimed at blocking the GOP repeals, but all were defeated.
"Unfortunately, President Biden has decided time and time again that the executive branch should also hold the legislative pen," Foxx said, "Congress has the task of creating laws that reflect the interests of the people. It is not the role of the executive pen."
Last August, the Biden administration launched the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) program, aiming to cancel debt to borrowers who originally owed $12,000 or less in loans and had repaid at least ten years of those loans.
The program is slated to begin in February, with 6.9 million Americans already enrolled, according to the White House.
Biden's original plan, as laid out in his 2022 executive order to cancel up to $430 billion in student loans, was blocked by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision last June. The court determined that the secretary of education lacked the power to issue debt relief on the scale described in the administration's plan.
Last September, Foxx introduced a resolution with Rep. Lisa McClain, R-Michigan, to nullify the SAVE plan, but the full House never voted on it.
Foxx's College Cost Reduction Act, introduced in January, would establish a streamlined data system to convey information about colleges, create a performance-based grant program, and hold academic institutions responsible for unpaid student loans.
In the committee meeting to consider the bill, Democrats introduced 30 amendments to alter some fundamental aspects of the legislation.
Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Virginia) praised parts of Foxx's bill, "such as codifying Postsecondary Student Success Grants and eliminating interest capitalization and origination fees on student loans," but the panel's ranking Democrat objected to some provisions that he said would make it harder for people to go to college.
Rep. Kathy Manning (D-Michigan) offered an amendment to strike language from the bill repealing Biden administration regulations to protect student borrowers during changes in ownership of academic institutions.
Another Biden administration regulation the Foxx bill aims to repeal is the 90-10 rule, which requires for-profit universities to secure at least 10 percent of their funding from non-federal sources. Rep. Mark Takano (D-California) introduced an amendment to strike this section from the final bill but was rebuffed by the GOP majority.
Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minnesota) offered a motion to remove the bill's rescission of Biden's SAVE plan, but that motion was defeated.
"The new (SAVE) program created by the Biden administration… creates a generous IDR (income-driven repayment) plan that Republicans now want to strip away," Omar said.
Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-Michigan) unsuccessfully tried to amend the bill with language streamlining the process of finding on-campus accommodations for students with disabilities.
Bonamici's proposal is part of a group of bills unveiled Monday by Democratic members of the education panel referred to collectively as the Roadmap to College Student Success.

title: Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police
author: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service
content:
Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Top state officials approved a $2.75 million settlement on Wednesday after a federal investigation turned up evidence of discriminatory hiring practices by the Maryland State Police.The U.S. Department of Justice conducted a two-year investigation into state police hiring practices for a violation of Title VII, which prohibits discrimination against employees or applicants based on race, color, religion, sex and national origin.
The investigation found that the state police engaged in discriminatory practices against Black and female applicants, agency officials acknowledged in a meeting of the Maryland Board of Public Works on Wednesday.
The DOJ said that MDSP written tests disproportionately impacted Black candidates, while their physical fitness tests disproportionately impacted female candidates. The tests discriminated against candidates while failing to "meaningfully distinguish between applicants who can and cannot perform the position of Trooper," according to a Department of Justice press release.
"Discrimination in any form has no place within the Maryland State Police, and it will not be tolerated," Col. Roland Butler Jr., superintendent of MDSP, told the board Wednesday. "We're committed to making meaningful and lasting change … [and] to develop new policies and procedures that ensure equitable treatment for all applicants."
The board — made up of Gov. Wes Moore, state Comptroller Brooke Lierman and Treasurer Dereck E. Davis — signed off on the settlement. The agreement must also be approved by a federal court before moving forward.
In response to the investigation, MDSP will change its current testing methods to prevent future discrimination in hiring, but the new practices will not be ready until after the next two MDSP classes start, Butler said. To adapt, he said, MDSP intends to change existing standards, including eliminating time requirements from different portions of the physical fitness tests.
Members of the Board of Public Works raised concerns about this interim period, with Davis questioning whether the unclear guidelines would lead to more discrimination.
"Now it becomes subjective, so doesn't that lend itself, potentially, to be more discriminatory?" Davis asked. "Now we don't know what's good or what's not as it relates to that time."
Butler assured Davis that strict monitoring of who passes and fails the tests would be in place, allowing MDSP to monitor areas of improvement.
"We won't have the other test in place at this time," Butler said. "However, we're relaxing the standards that we have … We will be allowed to use those tests under the condition that we provide strict monitoring to see what the results are, to see who's passing, who's failing and we do think that we'll get a larger pool of applicants when we start to look at how we measure that test and how we evaluate it."
Officials said the new tests would emphasize fairness while maintaining safety requirements, including a test that would receive ongoing validation to guarantee it was modern, fair and relevant, as well as an aptitude test to look for integrity, self-motivation, critical thinking and judgment skills.
The settlement involved 48 Black and female individuals who were prevented from becoming state troopers due to the discriminatory practices, according to Butler.
Since his appointment in 2023, Butler said, he has worked to evaluate and modernize the agency's practices.
"I remain steadfastly committed to cultivating a culture that will ensure inclusiveness," Butler said, "one that allows the fulfillment of our mission, of values centered around integrity, fairness, and service."

title: Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers

 EASTON - Securing funding for the new regional medical center and addressing local impacts of last year's juvenile justice reform laws are priorities for Mid-Shore lawmakers heading into the 2024 General Assembly in January.During a Tuesday meeting with the Talbot County Council and local stakeholders, the three Mid-Shore legislators, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Reps. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson, tackled a number of issues affecting the district, discussing ways to advance their progress in the upcoming legislative session.REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTERSecuring financial support for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center has long been a top priority for local legislators.The proposed 147-bed hospital and medical office building are slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S.Route 50 in Easton.The start of construction is dependent on the project receiving a Certificate of Need from the Maryland Health Care Commission.The hospital system filed the CON application in January and anticipates a response in December or January, said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health.In a separate process, the hospital system is working with the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the state's rate-setting authority, to see if rate relief can be obtained to offset the cost of interest and depreciation for the project.However, MHCC will first need to hear from HSCRC to determine if the project is financially viable before making a decision on the application. Uncertainty lies in how much the HSCRC decision will weigh on the health care commission's answer, Kozel said.That relief, along with government funding, is key to moving forward with the regional medical center.Former Gov. Larry Hogan earmarked $100 million last December for the project in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget.During this year's legislative session, lawmakers secured $10 million in the budget for the new medical center, which the hospital system must spend by June 30, 2024, Kozel said.There's also a pledge for $20 million in fiscal year 2025, though it's subject to change, so the hospital system is asking Gov. Wes Moore to solidify that allocation, along with the remaining $70 million, he added.The county council and lawmakers can write letters of support to help ensure the governor is aware of the project, Kozel said.Del. Chris Adams (R-37B) expressed his vote of confidence and support."We want this project to happen as much as you do and as much as every elected official does," he said, "And most importantly, as much as every citizen that will stand to benefit from the delivery of the services that are possible in a brand new facility and the quality that you get from your organization."JUVENILE JUSTICETalbot County Sheriff's Office Capt. John Bollinger and Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised concerns about the significant impacts resulting from the passage of juvenile justice reform measures last year.Bollinger said the legislature was "wrong" for passing the laws last year, highlighting a 42% increase in youth crime in schools and two provisions of the laws that have been particularly burdensome for local law enforcement.One provision bars police from being able to charge a child under 13 years old with a crime unless it's a violent crime, such as murder, attempted murder or rape."The worst part is that these kids know that, and the criminals know that," Bollinger said, suggesting that 12-year-olds could be implicated in illegal activities and not be punished for their involvement."They can do it in front of our face, and we can't do anything other than tell them, 'That's bad, you shouldn't do that,'" he said.Under another law, police are not allowed to interview a child after they're arrested until the child has an attorney to represent them, even if it's to get more information or to find out if others are involved."I'm here to tell you that there's not a lawyer anywhere that's going to say, 'Sure, tell the police everything,' - they're going to shut them down on the phone without even meeting them, knowing nothing about the case, and then our hands are tied," Bollinger said.The increase in crime in schools is mainly from the county's middle and high schools, and the majority of the crimes are assaults, he said. And out of 114 reported assaults in the schools in the last year, 40 of them involved children under 13.However, Talbot County is experiencing less youth crime than some other Shore jurisdictions. In Dorchester and Wicomico counties, the number of assaults on both students and staff are "dramatically higher" than previous years, said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B)."The good newsis every county is now talking about it," he said. "The county executives on the western shore are talking about it, butis anybody going to want to make a change?"COUNTY INITIATIVESWhile there are no specific Talbot County bills being proposed for consideration by the state legislature so far, the county is supporting the Maryland Association of Counties' 2024 legislative initiatives.Those initiatives include launching forward-thinking firefighter and emergency medical services incentives, providing transparency in education spending, modernizing local revenue structures and advancing comprehensive housing solutions.

title: Oxford awarded federal grants to elevate homes, address sea level rise
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford awarded federal grants to elevate homes, address sea level rise

 April 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 542
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The Town of Oxford has been awarded two grants from the federal government.At a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Tuesday evening, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis detailed what those grants are and what the town knows about the awards so far.
"This is exciting because we've never been in the federal budget," she said.
During Lewis' explanation of the grants, Commission President Tom Costigan turned to the residents in the room.
"I hope you all appreciate just how gigantic this is," he said, which was followed by applause.
The first federal grant of $2.6 million is for the elevation of 14 Oxford homes. Lewis said the town had spent time looking for interested residents, and it found 14 who were "willing to sign on the dotted line."
Those 14 residents agreed to committing 10% of the cost for their home to be elevated, Lewis said. The other 90% of the cost will be paid by the federal government. Lewis said one of those 14 homes is currently being elevated.
Although she is not yet sure of exactly how this process will go, Lewis said she knows the money will go from the Federal Emergency Management Agency through the Maryland Department of Emergency Management.
The town was also awarded $143,000 to go towards the cost of doing these elevations to the town, Lewis said.
"Until we get some detail, (we) don't know how that exactly works," she said. "But that was the notice."
Lewis said the town hasn't been contacted by anyone from the federal government yet regarding this grant award. She said someone pulled out the line items from the budget and sent it to the town.
Costigan asked if there is a time limit on elevating the homes and spending the grant money.
Lewis said the government says to spend it in a year, but added that the town requested getting three years to spend the money in its grant request.
The second federal grant the town is receiving is for sea level rise adaption efforts. Lewis said $1.06 million will be put toward building the Eastern Shore's capacity "to plan and mitigate impacts of coastal flooding and tidal inundation."
Specifically, it will increase the capacity of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's research in addressing sea level rise. Lewis said there will be two scientists at the NOAA lab in Oxford working on this, as well as a liaison specialist for the Town of Oxford and a liaison specialist for the broader Eastern Shore.
Lewis said that this project aims to help other Eastern Shore communities, too.
"The idea is to take what we do discover and what we are able to do here and carry it to places that don't have the ability," she said.
Costigan asked if this means Oxford will become the "epicenter" of sea level rise studies on the Eastern Shore.
"You know, it's $1 million for that purpose alone," Lewis responded.
Lewis said this project will also study the town's living shorelines. She is hopeful Oxford will receive a tidal gauge as part of the project.
"It is written into this grant, so we have high hopes," she said about the tidal gauge.
Lewis is still unsure of exactly how this grant will be handled, but said she assumes the town will need to pay the invoices and get reimbursed by the federal government.

title: Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — On May 20, while Cherrywood Solar workers were at Ronald Spearing Farm, human remains were found."They found that while they were conducting grading activities at the Spearing Farm on Bridgetown Road, and they immediately stopped work, secured the area and went to their plan," said Crystal Dadds, Caroline County director of planning and codes.
"Cherrywood has a plan when anytime they come across what's called an 'unanticipated discovery,' they made all the proper notifications contacting Public Service Commission, the Maryland Historical Trust, the sheriff's office, the state's attorney, the planning and code, the health officer, roped off the area, covered the area with tarps to protect it because we did have bad weather."
Cherrywood then brought in Search, an organization that has an archeological team to do a preliminary assessment of the area where they presumed remains were found.
The Search team then made a determination that there were human remains at the site. Five burial plots were discovered.
Cherrywood Solar brought the team back to do an ground-penetrating radar to see if there were any more potential burial sights. Once the final report from that test comes back, the Burial Sites Preservation Board in Caroline County will review that data and make a recommendation of what area needs to be protected.
Cherrywood Solar, produced by NextEra Energy Resources LLC, is a 145-megawatt project in Caroline County.
NextEra Energy Resources sent a press release to the Star Democrat Wednesday stating, "We are cooperating with Caroline County and other pertinent agencies on the investigation. Once we receive clearance from the relevant authorities, we will resume construction activities."
All parties involved believe that there was no foul play involved. They are believed to be human remains of family members from previous property owners.
"Given the fact that the house on this farm is a late 1800s house, most likely it was a family burial plot that could date back that far," Dadds said.

title: One Book One Maryland presents “Kin: Rooted in Hope” author talk at Chesapeake College
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
One Book One Maryland presents “Kin: Rooted in Hope” author talk at Chesapeake College

 October 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Exploring family and freedom, 2025 One Maryland One Book author Carole Boston Weatherford and illustrator Jeffery Boston Weatherford presented a discussion on "Kin: Rooted in Hope" as part of the state's largest annual reading and discussion program at Chesapeake College on Oct. 7.Originally published in 2023, "Kin: Rooted in Hope" is an illustrated verse novel that serves as a work of art, history and personal genealogy through the authors' search into their family tree.
Conjuring ancestors and tracing historical roots from the Maryland plantation where Frederick Douglass was also enslaved to Civil War battlefields and to the founding of a black, Reconstruction-era village, "Kin" interweaves rhythmic poetic imagery verse and stunning visuals to give voices through multiple perspectives.
Author of 80 children's books, Carole considered poetry her "first literary language," which lends itself to a different flow of words to convey emotions for her than traditional prose.
Carole is no stranger to addressing tough topics for young people in verse, including her 2021 picture book "Unspeakable: The Tulsa Race Massacre."
Carole said it is important not to shy away from telling children the truth and to ensure critical thinking and socially responsible civic contribution.
A pin drop could be heard in the Todd Performing Arts Center auditorium as Carole recounted tracing her ancestor's lineage back to the Wye House plantation in Easton.
Visiting the Wye House for research, Carole noted moving moments and powerful connections, including holding the enormous iron antique key to the home, something her ancestor must have held as well.
Carole recounted visiting the plantation's burial ground, now hallowed with a plaque marking where the enslaved people of the house were laid to rest.
"I knelt down and cried and it was almost as if my ancestors had said, 'We have been waiting for you,'" Carole said.
Carole learned of an ancestor, Isaac Copper, mentioned in Frederick Douglass' autobiography, who was enslaved at the Wye House at the same time.
The Weatherfords' ancestors went on to fight for the Union in the American Civil War and helped found the historically black communities of Unionville and Copperville.
In creating the book, the Weatherfords came to discover, "Knowing your history is generational wealth," Carole said.
The mother-son duo were proud to collaborate, and Carole said it was a dream come true to experience it all with her son.
In reconnecting with ancestral roots, the two's travels included the Door of No Return at Gorée Island, noted as the last thing Africans of the area saw before they were enslaved and shipped away from their home.
Jeffery utilized a scratchboard medium to "bring people out of darkness into the light" and often used his own family as character models.
Jeffery said working on the book gave him a greater appreciation and understanding for the work his mother has been doing since he was a child.
One of the biggest challenges faced while working on the book was connecting the dots, Carole said.
Comprehensive research brought Carole's nose into captain ship ledgers and the meticulous records kept by the Lloyd family, owners of the Wye House plantation.
Carole noted the emotions in seeing the names of ancestors inscribed in estate inventory alongside bought and sold goods.
Some information remained out of reach, like the exact ship names that brought her enslaved ancestors over, she said. Along with the tremendous amount of research that went into every page also came a certain amount of artistic license to create stories, she said.
For those piecing together their own family tree, Carole gave permission for imagination as long as it fit the narrative historically.
"Informed by facts, it is up to you to fill in the gaps," she said.
Carole encouraged everyone to know their own history and seek out their own family stories regardless of ethnicity to inspire future generations.
Amateur genealogy hunting doesn't have to break the bank, she said, with public libraries a wealth of information and often having access to ancestry data resources.
"When you are the only one who knows, you tell somebody," she said.
Stories are essential to know exactly what ancestors went through. "Without stories, a family tree is just a map," Carole said.
"All of our histories are intertwined," Jeffery said, and by connecting with history, warts and all, we will find we have more in common than different.
"Names, dates and places are the branches of a family tree," according to Carole. "But stories are the leaves that bring the family's past to life."
"Kin: Rooted in Hope" is the winner of a Coretta Scott King Honor, the Claudia Lewis Award from Bank Street College of Education and the Boston Globe/Horn Book Award.
The Weatherfords have toured across Maryland to discuss the book as part of the One Maryland One Book program to encourage a love of reading and develop a deeper sense of community through connecting events.
The event at Chesapeake College was made possible in partnership with Eastern Shore Regional Library, Washington College, Caroline County Public Library, Kent County Public Library, Dorchester County Public Library, Queen Anne's County Public Library, ShoreLit, Talbot County Public Schools and The Needle's Eye Academy.
More information about the Weatherfords can be found at cbweatherford.com.

title: Wheatlands development agreement shapes up
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Wheatlands development agreement shapes up

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — The Wheatlands project adjacent to Route 50 is growing closer to fruition as the Queenstown Town Commissioners discussed developer rights and responsibilities for the proposed mixed use residential and commercial community development Feb. 28.A concept plan proposes 79 townhouse lots, 20 cottage court units and 77 single-family home lots for developers Waterman Family Limited Partnership to build Wheatlands on a 148-acre tract of land, directly across from the Queenstown Premium Outlets.
Queenstown Town Manager Amy Moore presented a development rights and responsibilities agreement draft for review including outlines of impact fees and donations to the local fire departments.
The town is currently working with the developer on infrastructure needs and the development's contributions are detailed in the agreement, according to Moore.
As part of the agreement, the developer will also give two one-acre storage land parcels for town use.
Wheatlands has been in the pipeline since 1992, when the Waterman Family Limited Partnership bought the land.
The land was annexed into Queenstown in 2014, which had the backing of the Queen Anne's County Commissioners at the time. But new members won election to the county seat later that year, and they reversed approval of the development.
Waterman and Queenstown fought the reversal but ultimately lost in court, with the Maryland Court of Appeals enforcing a five-year stay on the zoning of the property.
When those five years were up in November 2019, the development proposal moved forward introducing concept plans and architectural guidelines in 2020.
The master concept plan approved by Queenstown in 2021, showed no strong opposition to it from local residents.
Public hearings were held after planning commission members found the master concept plan consistent with the town comprehensive plan.
During those hearings in 2021, Barry Waterman, the proprietor of Waterman Family Limited Partnership, the property owners, told the commissioners, homes will vary in size but will resemble the historic architecture of Queenstown.
More discussion and potential agreement approval is expected at the commissioner's next meeting March 12.

title: Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first classical public charter school in Queen Anne's County hopes to open in the fall of 2026.Queen Anne's Classical Charter School (QACCS) is a proposed tuition-free pre-K through eighth grade school to provide an alternative educational approach and complement the work of other public schools to over four hundred students.
The drive for QACCS was formed by local parents, educators, business, and community leaders to provide an educational alternative within the public school system to ensure Queen Anne County students are reaching grade level proficiencies, according to co-founder Audrey Scott, of Queenstown.
Disillusioned with national grade level proficiencies in which a concerning percentage of students in any grade were not meeting grade level expectations, QACCS was founded through the support of local parents, grandparents, and community leaders, seeking to provide alternatives, Scott said.
"If you're aware of what's going on with the education system, you've got to take action," she said.
Researching where students were more likely to perform at grade level and above led Scott to identify classic charter schools of Frederick and Anne Arundel counties with proven track records of proficiency.
"Classical charter schools are rapidly gaining national attention for higher student performance and cultivating character and critical thinking," Scott said.
Scott is a former teacher who said the proposed charter school will provide parents educational "alternatives and enhancements," while still being part of Queen Anne's County Public Schools.
The classical charter school curriculum will include a focus on phonics, Western civilization, cursive, as well as Spanish offered in addition to Latin as part of language arts, she said.
With a board made up entirely of parents, charter schools offer more hands-on opportunities for "tremendous parental involvement," which can make a significant difference in performance, Scott said.
Queen Anne's County Commissioners have been supportive of the initiative and presented a $20,000 grant for an application consultant, she said. This application is due in March, she said.
Students will be selected for enrollment via lottery, with all county students eligible to attend, she said.
Options for school facilities are still being explored with the hopes to mirror Frederick County and Anne Arundel counties' business park locations, Scott said.
"It would be a real feather in the cap of Queen Anne's County to have the first one on the Eastern Shore," Scott said.
A public meeting about QACCS welcomes the community to learn more Jan. 25, 2025 at 10 a.m. at Kent Island Fire Department, 1610 Main Street in Chester.
More information including a petition of support can be found at QueenAnnesCCS.com and its Facebook page.

title: Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During Wednesday's meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education added a day onto the end of this year's school calendar following last week's snowstorm.Talbot County Public Schools was closed Monday through Friday last week due to snow that blanketed the Mid-Shore. However, the 2024-2025 school calendar only had four inclement weather days built in, meaning an additional day was needed to comply with the state's 180-day requirement.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, recommended that a day be added in June, moving the last day of school for students to Friday, June 13.
The last day for teachers would be Monday, June 16. Einhorn said that historically, most teachers complete mandated training that affords them with not having to come in on the last day.
The board unanimously passed the adjusted calendar for this year.
2025-26 CALENDAROn Wednesday, the board also chose the district's calendar for the 2025-2026 school year.
At last month's meeting, Einhorn presented a draft calendar with two days off in March and a five-day spring break, which was the recommendation of the calendar committee. Board President Emily Jackson, however, expressed frustration there weren't multiple options posed.
This month, Einhorn returned with three draft calendars. The first was similar to what the board saw in December, with a four-day weekend in March and the shorter spring break. The second draft removed the off days in March and had an eight-day spring break.
A third draft included both the March break and an eight-day spring break, pushing the last student day back to June 10, 2026.
All three drafts included the typical days off in November for Easton's Waterfowl Festival, as well as a winter break from Dec. 20, 2025, to Jan. 4, 2026.
"There is no calendar that we're going to create that is best for every single person," Jackson said.
Jackson said it's clear — based on previous polling and community input — that most families favor the extended spring break. Board Vice President Amy Dodson suggested the board move forward with the second or third calendars.
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry said she preferred the first calendar with the shorter spring break.
"You're losing a lot of school time for eight days off for students," Wieland-Cherry said. "You're losing a lot of momentum. And plus you're concerned with providing day care. Not all employers are going to allow that. That's quite a long time to take off of work and find day care and so forth."
She added that not all families are looking for a longer spring break.
"My only concern is that if 59% of our students are at the poverty level, we're really talking about more of a smaller group who are really going to financially be able to afford an Easter holiday," Wieland-Cherry said. "… You really could possibly potentially be causing more hardship for something that's more an elitist type thing, quite honestly."
Jackson said while she agrees with Wieland-Cherry's point, she has "to go with what the community is saying."
"We have asked again and again, and the majority of the respondents to any time we've asked this have said they like that spring break," Jackson said.
Following board discussion, Jackson motioned for approval of the third calendar featuring two off days in March and five days for spring break. Her motion included an amendment to the calendar that the March days off serve as two of four inclement weather days for the district.
By a 6-1 vote, with only Wieland-Cherry voting against, the board approved the 2025-2026 school year calendar.

title: Oxford commission approves changes to floodplain management
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Oxford commission approves changes to floodplain management

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The Commissioners of Oxford approved an ordinance to amend the town's floodplain management ordinance. The changes would loosen requirements for residents seeking to make significant improvements to buildings.Commission President Norm Bell opened the public hearing for Ordinance 2416 and shared additional information on the changes made.
Previously for buildings in Oxford, owners were required to track and calculate the costs of any construction made since July 1, 2013 prior to making changes to the structures.
If all those improvement costs equal or exceed 50% of the market value of a building prior to the start of the construction, it would require the building to be up to code and raised in elevation.
The amended ordinance revises the definition of "substantial improvement," removing the 2013 date and substituting "the previous five (5) years."
Bell said the revision allows for a lean way for owners to make improvements on their buildings.
"What this is saying is we're only going to go back five years, or 1,825 days," Bell said. "So it's shortening the period that you can take a look at the 50% requirement. It's liberalizing it."
An additional change in the ordinance was the revision of the "agreement to submit an elevation certificate."
An elevation certificate is a form on which applicants for a permit to construct a building or structure show compliance with floodplain management legislation.
Previously people looking to make substantial improvements to buildings would need to submit an elevation certificate with a building permit application upon the construction of the foundation and prior to further vertical construction; and prior to the final inspection and moving in.
The revision removes the requirement of submitting the form prior to placement of the foundation and further vertical construction.
According to Bell, the changes would make it cheaper for owners to have engineers/surveyors certify that the floor of buildings seeking improvements is above the mean high water mark and it lowers costs of the certification by a "couple of hundred dollars."
After answering clarifying questions from the public, commissioners unanimously approved the ordinance.

title: Cambridge City Council talks about amending CWDI Articles of Incorporation
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge City Council talks about amending CWDI Articles of Incorporation

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Changes to Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Articles of Incorporation could be coming down the pike.During a Cambridge City Council work session on Nov. 4, City Attorney Patrick Thomas outlined proposed changes to the document and detailed the steps necessary to make those changes. He said that if the City Council, state and Dorchester County Council all favorably recommend the changes to the document, those changes could then be adopted by the CWDI board.
In September, a group — which included Thomas, Cambridge's mayor and city manager, Dorchester County's manager and Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) — met to discuss proposed revisions to the Articles of Incorporation.
"So out of that came a working draft," Thomas said.
This is not the first time in the past year that there has been discussion surrounding CWDI's Articles of Incorporation. In April, Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout proposed amendments to the document that he felt would make the Cambridge Harbor project more likely to succeed.
Spearheaded by CWDI, the project is intended to develop land along the Choptank River.
Rideout's efforts to amendment the Articles of Incorporation were postponed in May when, in the midst of a lawsuit filed by the city against CWDI regarding a transfer agreement, the two parties entered into mediation. The lawsuit was settled in August.
PROPOSED CHANGESThe current proposed revisions to CWDI's Articles of Incorporation would address membership, board membership and the process of amending the Articles of Incorporation.
Specifically, if adopted, the amendments would clarify that the CWDI Board of Directors has the authority to amend the Articles of Incorporation as long as it provides the amendments to CWDI members (which are comparable to the shareholders of a company) for approval first. It also clarifies that the board of directors can amend its bylaws as long as advance notice is provided to CWDI members.
Another proposed revision expands the board of directors from seven to nine members. The two additional seats would be for the city and county managers. Thomas said the managers would serve in "an ex-officio, non-voting capacity," and would be entitled to attend all meetings, including closed session meetings.
The proposed amendments also include two new sections regarding the removal of directors. They state that if the board of directors declines the removal of a director, then the appointing authority, such as the county or city, has the ability to remove them. This authority can only be used if the board member hasn't been attending meetings, has acted unethically or unlawfully or has an unresolved conflict of interest.
Another revision would change the resident agent from the city's legal counsel to CWDI's legal counsel.
The last change would make it so that the number of CWDI members is increased from one to three. Currently, Rideout is CWDI's sole member. Having three members would make it so that the city, county and state can be represented. Thomas said that for the city or county member to vote on a particular item, a majority of its commissioners or council members would have to vote on the issue first.
"So any action taken by the city member would reflect the majority of the council," Thomas said.
During the council meeting, Hutchinson said that from the state's standpoint, for the state member to vote on a particular item, a majority of Dorchester County's state delegation should have to vote on the issue first. He said if a tie-breaker is needed, Maryland Secretary of Housing and Community Development Jake Day should take that role.
At the end of the meeting, CWDI board Secretary-Treasurer Frank Narr said CWDI's goal is to make sure the Articles of Incorporation continue to reflect "the original intent" of CWDI's formation.
"And I think this moves in that direction," he said. "So I appreciate everybody's willingness to work together on this, and I look forward to a true partnership going forward."

title: Colorful kites mark 20 years of Cambridge fest
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Colorful kites mark 20 years of Cambridge fest

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Dorchester 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Colorful kites dipped and darted in the skies above Sailwinds Park Sunday during the 20th annual Kitefest.A stiff breeze ranging from 15 to 17 mph provided enough wind to keep the kites airborne but was not strong enough to cause problems, particularly for some of the larger inflatables.
"You need a steady breeze," said Kitefest organizer Chad Malkas who added that the event was expected to draw between 500 and 1,000 kite fliers and spectators.
The event drew people from across the Delmarva region and featured carnival rides and RAR burgers. Volunteers from Baywater Animal Rescue brought a couple of puppies.
But the big draw was the kites.
Wings Over Washington brought a half dozen people who were flying small kites synchronized to music.
"We are a very active club," said Paul Dugard, who headed the Wings Over Washington team at Sailwinds on Sunday.
Dugard and three other kite fliers stood side-by-side and flew their four kites in tightly choreographed moves with Dugard barking commands into a headset much the way a square dance caller shouts moves to dancers.
"We've been fliying together for many years," he said, adding the group first started flying together in the 1980s.
Their years of experience showed as their kites crossed lines and then uncrossed. The four kites would climb into the sky together and then circle one another before reforming in a line, much like the precision flying of the Blue Angels or Thunderbirds.
